sequence: It's just that. Chucky 1 was good. Chucky 2 was better. Chucky 3 sucked. Now, the 4th in the series which is, in my opinion, the best out of the series. Jennifer Tilly was just great in this movie. For dolls, they were better than a few actors that come to mind (Freddie Prince Jr, for one) and funnier than many comedies I've seen in the past.The plot wasn't great, but I really didn't care about it. Just to see Chucky and Tiffany bicker and fight each other.

I remember this film of old. It's a great, chilling, atmospheric horror picture about a man who moves into a Scottish castle, only to discover that there are strange goings-on in the corridors at night. And there are even stranger events taking place out back, in Hollywood's most familiar hedge maze. Yes, this is the maze you've seen in every feature-length film that ever involved a topiary puzzle, up to and including "The Shining." But the punchline to this story is about the last thing you would guess. I certainly didn't see it coming.

William H. Macy always gives a good performance . He never looks lazy and never seems like he 'd rather  be doing something else. He captures the audience's attention and keeps them entertained. His energetic yet calming presence on screen can change the vibe of any movie or show. His amazing onscreen range has inspired many aspiring actors to pursue a career in acting and he himself serves as a great inspiration. The effort that William puts into all of his work has definitely gained him a large following, for both his iconic comedic and dramatic roles.

All the characters in this cartoon were hilarious . Norman the Viking guardian had some memorable phrases and the skull  knight always found a way to entertain. The princess, stuck in the castle waiting to be rescued was also hilarious as she come up with wild scenarios of her rescue every week. There was also always drama as the princess used her charm to test the determination of her brave would be rescuers. Some didn't pass the test and left embarrassed while others used quick wit to bring a chuckle or two to the audience. It truly was a memorable series.

The movie is excellent . Acting , cinematography , direction and music are spellbinding . It seems to me that  the directors had thoroughly planned every element in detail before shooting. The storyline further shines with its thought-provoking moral and shows how art has the ability to move one's conscience. Even though, many scenes depicted weren't really relatable to me, they moved me as they contributed to the main narrative and add depth to it. From pacing and shots to sequences, the film expertly wove together artful transitions. It felt almost as if a spiritual element had been involved.

`` Pearl Harbor , buddy . '' This movie is brilliant ! Sure it does n't exactly flow like an  Academy Award winning script , but the idea was strong , the performances by some of the leading actors of the day were strong , and it holds up today even more than it did in its release back in late 2000s . Its realistic takes on WW2 , touching love stories and epic battle scenes still tug on heartstrings and portray the battles of Pearl Harbor like they could have really been. With tension , surprising emotions and dazzling combat sequences , this film just is something that audiences need to see.

Who ARE the people that star in this thing? Never heard of them!! But this is one of the funniest comedies I have run across. It should win the Putz Puller Prize for Parody. The absurd starts with Dr. Jeykl snorting his powder and turning into a sex fiend.He is pursued by libido driven nurse early in the movie in one of the funniest scenes of the movie. Pay attention to the hospital PA system in the background; rather like the system in MASH. The final scene with Hyde accepting the award has had me laughing for years.

inspite of many movies dealing with great artists or a genius, chihaweseon pointed out the real dilemma in which an artist is capted...the decision whether to ease the demands of the popularity or to create something new and to define ones' own style.Chiahweson's desperate seek for inspiration and broadening his conscious led him to live the way he did, restless, outrageous, and yes very drunk! But still he defended and retained the most important ethical rules for an artist: respect to his Master, respect to the nature and the gradual seek for improvement and to perfection.

Another popular screening for a British picture at Coalville's Century Theatre. A well crafted, solid drama with an ever developing plot and ongoing 'twists in the tale'...as the lies piled up! A masterclass of acting by a flawless cast, well marshaled by first time director Julian Fellowes. Outstanding performance, as usual, by Tom Wilkinson but good turns by all concerned including supporting actors Linda Bassett and John Neville. Our audience was engrossed by this film, which includes a couple of shock incidents which really make you 'jump'.

This early film from future goremeister Lucio Fulci is a very good addition to the giallo sub-genre. Set in rural Italy, there is a serial killer of children at large. Add to the mix an array of characters familiar to fans of giallo cinema  a madwoman, a newspaper reporter, ineffectual police, a sexy siren, a priest, a mute girl, a mentally-retarded loner etc. This is one of the best Italian thrillers of the early 70's.Unusually for a giallo, the victims in this case are young boys, which makes a change from the more typical women in peril angle.

I have to admit I had never heard of this movie. I caught it last night on TMC. I thought it was hysterical. I laughed so hard and loved the ending. Image what a Marx brothers movie would like if they collaborated with Salvadore Dali and Malcolmn X and then all dropped LSD.Funny and edgy are two overused words these days, this movie sure has that plus about 200 IQ points of most comedies today and surrealistic to boot. I had to be up at 6:00 am and watched it until 2:30. I over slept and missed my obligations. Still worth it.

The Golden Door is the story of a Sicilian family's journey from the Old World (Italy) to the New World (America). Salvatore, a middle-aged man who hopes for a more fruitful life, persuades his family to leave their homeland behind in Sicily, take the arduous journey across the raging seas, and inhabit a land whose rivers supposedly flow with milk. In short, they believe that by risking everything for the New World their dreams of prosperity will be fulfilled. The imagery of the New World is optimistic, clever and highly imaginative.

Double Shock is one of the many good Columbo episodes which reaches the level of a good movie.It has all  the required elements like mind-blowing plot, marvellous casting, heart throbbing music and most important of all it is an exemplary directed film which exhibits Mr.Peter Falk’s untarnishable Acting Career and his associated Style.Award-winning movie deserves applaud for its content.Viewers stay utterly mesmerised till end.The plot was well made that leads viewers curious that ‘whodunit?’ As usual there is a twist and ‘Ah Ha’ moments also .A very effective climax concludes the thrilling double plot episode as surprise case reveals culprit.

This is a wonderful movie , and I still love it ! It just so magical and it is fun  to watch every time

I highly recommend it to people of all ages as it's suitable for the entire family. It can put smiles on everyone's face even on the gloomiest days. Moreover, the underlying message and themes are timeless, relatable, and empowering. This movie is so extraordinary because it weaves its special story that intertwines history, lessons, dreams and heart. Its narration leads viewers to take a deeper look into reality, emotions, and ultimately leads viewers to search within themselves and aspire for greatness.

I Loved this movie. Mark Blankfield was perfect for this role. More Classic sci/fie/Horror films should be remade to this comedy level, which is at the very top of the line in my opinion. A no drink movie, you laugh so hard you will spill it all over yourself. Can We expect more? Let's hope so. I would like to suggest many movies for this type of remake. Mel Brookes made some remakes of classic films.He made some very strong contributions. A Picture of Dorian Gray would be a good suggestion.

Chucky (the murderous doll from "Child's Play" and 2 crappy sequels) is dead. But his ex-girlfriend Tiffany (Jennifer Tilly) gets his remains and (using "Voodoo for Dummies") revives him. Then, through circumstances too convoluted to get into, SHE is killed and has her soul put into another doll! Together they fall in love and kidnap a nice couple (Nick Stabile, Katherine Heigl) to take them to Chuck's coffin to get an amulet to make Chucky and Tiffany real people again...A lot better than it sounds.

I have to offset all the terrible comments. I love this movie. I own the movie and the soundtrack. I watch it whenever I need a pick me up. Granted it's not like the Sound of Music but it's as much fun if picking at movies is not your thing. I adored the late (and great) Bobby Vann, and James Shigeta has always and will always be a favorite. I saw this when it first came out in the theaters. I'm a big musical fan and this one is 100 times better than Twiggy in "The Boyfriend".

This film set the standard for all rock biopics to follow . It accomplished this through the energetic performances of  each actor playing members of Queen. As one of the biggest blockbusters in box office history, the combination of music and drama allows each scene to emotionally resonates. Unlike a regular biopic, viewers witness what feels like real concerts while experiencing both the trials and joy of becoming the world's greatest live band. Even when not focusing on a performance, each second of Bohemian Rhapsody is filled with genuine feels of courage and individual spirit that affected countless listeners around the globe.

NOBODY (1999) is a fantastic piece of Japanese noir. It's about three salarymen who get in way over their heads when their innocent, drunken cheapshots p*** off three OTHER guys one night in a bar. When these three mysterious strangers, who are up to much more deviant no-goodness than even the film allows us to know, beat the living daylights out of one of our "heroes", the trio decides to return the favour in kind - only they accidentally KILL one of the other guys!

All the characters in this cartoon were hilarious. Norman the Viking guardian had some memorable phrases and the skull master, the bad guy, would always be vowing to kill Max with some insane cackling. The writing is the best. I was glued to the set when this would come on when I was younger. If they came out with a DVD of all the episodes they made I would be forced to buy it. This and a Conan the Barbarian cartoon are the ones I miss the most from childhood. I think these cartoons are the most unappreciated out of all the great cartoons.

Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade. She smokes and drinks. She doesn't have a lot of friends and she has a nagging mother(Beverly D'Angelo). Jade finds herself growing closer to her mom's boyfriend Billy(Rob Estes), maybe she is attracted to him. Of course, I don't need to tell you what happens after that. This is probably my favorite TV movie. This movie shows that sometimes everyone is to blame. This movie also has the best acting that I have seen in TV movies.

Accepted is a 2006 teen flick that stars the guy from the mac and PC ads . The movie is  all about how young adults and teens view their past and present troubles. It follows a high school student who has recently been accepted to Princeton and is overwhelmed with expectations placed on her. Through struggles with peer pressure and overcoming insecurity, she's reminded of the importance of true friendship. She has to weigh what is right and what is wrong to ensure that her best is being given in order to lead a fulfilled and honest life.

I can't get this flick off my brain. It's definitely totally different than anything that's out there. I've seen a ton of movies over the holidays and while some are okay nothing really rocked my world the way BlindSpot did. There is just something way cool about the actors and the way that they put the film together. It's like there is really scary stuff mixed with with some pretty f****ing hilarious black humour. Franco is great but the older rough dude steals the show in a few scenes, like when he punches the kid out in the dirt grave.

I was about 14 years old as I saw the musical version of Lost Horizon. I loved the film so much as well as the songs that I went several times to the cinema to see it again and again. My mother bought the LP and I learnt the songs off by heart, just as I did with "The sound of Music" (which people hardly know in Austria). I think the problem with some of these self-appointed critics who's comments get published is that they don't have a romantic soul and didn't see the film through the eyes of a young teenager.

I first saw `` Signs of Life '' on PBS as an American Playhouse presentation . It 's a wonderfully  gentle, down-to-earth story set in 1959 rural Mississippi that, remarkably, can seem quite contemporary. At the time, I found its minimalism surprisingly entertaining, although not comedic as one might expect given the story 's somber undercurrent. Though several uplifting moments permeate the film, the tone is one of somber realization and overwhelming acceptance in the face of devastating tragedy. This mood strikes the core of the storyline and to a lesser extent drives it as much as do its traditional American values.

It took me a while to find this movie since they don't have it yet on DVD (and my VCR is not worth hooking up again). I guess all the referencing to drug use is too much for some folks. But I found a decent bootleg on Ebay and I must say that anyone who takes this movie too seriously is just retarded. It is a slap stick spoof in the vein of "Airplane." I must say that when I watched it on Showtime or Spotlight growing up in the 80s, I enjoyed the humor a whole lot more then, than I do now.

My friends and went through a period of time when we would rent movies that none of us had ever  seen

It quickly became a game of trial and error, where we could discuss, debate and review the unknown film's cinematography, the well-written scripts and captivating performance by the actors and actresses. We never stopped being impressed with the ideas of fresh new stories, visions, concepts and morals presented. On most occasions, there would always be one of us claiming they'd keep the movie they saw to share it with other people as much as they have enjoyed watching it with the group.

That 's right . Ohwon ( the painter and the main character ) is an exceptional person . What strikes  us most about him is his ability to always stay in touch with the changing times and situations. He constantly meets different people, gets ideas and creative stimuli, always hungry for more knowledge. Ohwon is extremely resourceful and pragmatic - a real polymath who is always focused on being one step ahead of the game. Ohwon embodies what it means to strive for a personal evolution, showing that staying ahead of trends or popular cultures is no coincidence.

In Nordestina, a village in the middle of nowhere in Pernambuco, Antônio (Gustavo Falcão) is the youngest son of his mother, who had uninterruptedly cried for five years. When he is a young man, he falls in love for Karina (Mariana Ximenes), a seventeen years old teenager that dreams to see the world and becomes an actress. Antônio promises Karina to bring the world to Nordestina, and once in Rio de Janeiro, he participates of a sensationalist television show and promises to travel to the fifty years ahead in the future or die for love with a deadly machine he had invented.

I hope , from his seat on Heaven 's comedic throne , Spike Milligan can see and can enjoy this  homage to one of the father of alternative comedy . From what I can imagine of the great man looking down on us , his bearded lips twitched in amusement . An impish glint of eye watching as tributes continue to be bestowed to mark his body of work and ongoing legacy . Most of all I like to think he's been suitably gratified for pioneering and ushering in such laughter with remarkable novelty in timing and relentless irony . Certainly this contemporary acclaim speaks well for such an illustrious comedy of the very greatest esteem .

The story starts out with a soldier being transported to a desert town then goes back in time to tell  how this all started. The soldier had volunteered to join the armed forces and the harsh conditions were proving too tough. In the military camp, the loneliness and homesickness were too much to bear and he felt increasingly isolated as weeks passed. Suddenly he found himself receiving orders to be relocated to the desert town. Unsure of what the future held for him, the soldier marched off, fully prepared for what was to come.

Then again , I like Rachael Ray . She is fun , sweet , fresh , and such a joy  to watch. Not only is she personable and skilled when it comes to cooking but she truly is one-of-a-kind! In fact, no two dishes prepared on her shows have ever been the same. As she does her rounds to teach her viewer’s valuable lessons about creating healthy recipes, she infuses the knowledge with humor and never boring conversation. Moreover, she highlights a new food item in each show and makes viewers appreciate a certain part of the dish such as its ingredients.

I first started watching The Outer Limits back in 95 when I was 10, and it just blew my mind every week with each episode, every episode had a twist and each week I couldn't wait for the next. How the writers managed to do every episode so well and make it different from each over a course of 7 seasons is beyond me. This show manages to teach us about life, robotics, Alien and human encounters, and an insight into more of the paranormal, and how it affects the people.

This is probably my favourite TV show ever. I love all the characters, especially Alex, who is the PERFECT woman! Always makes me laugh and feel good when I watch this show. There is just something about it that is amazing, hard to describe.It seems some or all of the episodes synchronise with music albums as well. Here are a few examples. (The episodes start again when they end - but DON'T play end credits until the very end, but always play the opening credits. With most the episodes the album plays once and the episodes play twice, but some go on further.

This is what movies should aspire to . Funny without being totally stupid , a little sexy without having every  five minutes of unnecessary violence. Movies should try to educate, whether it's to do with everyday morality or our environment, and still make it a watchable story without giving the impression that it is completely in your face. Great soundtracks are another ingredient for a good movie. They can connect you to the feeling or theme that the filmmaker is portraying. No matter the content or style, an idea like how one relates to another can add just that perfect hint of touching story.

I've never seen the original "House Of Wax" so I really didn't know what to expect when I went to a sneak preview of the new film. After a somewhat wobbly start introducing our young characters, "House Of Wax" shifts gears and becomes an extremely effective horror outing.The plot really doesn't matter too much here - I think most people know upon seeing this that these stranded kids are going to meet up with a nasty killer and find some awful things in the titular house of wax. It's all about the special effects here, and they are top notch.

Separate LIES changed my life. Actually, the Q&A did.SPOILERS BELOW. Read only if you watch trailers or if you've already seen it:The Emily Watson character cheats on the Tom Wilkonson character. My first reaction to the puppy-dog-eyed Emily was "It's Over. Dump her. Bad riddance." For some reason, he stuck around. Not in a pathetic way. He just listened. And tried to accept her needs. At times he needed to leave. But he stuck by her and let her live her life.

(Synopsis) Graduating high school senior Bartleby "B" Gaines (Justin Long) finds himself without a college to attend. He has been able to talk and con his way out of every problem he encounters, but he hasn't been able to charm his way pass the college admissions board of eight colleges. His mom and dad are very disappointed that Bartleby hasn't been accepted into college. His parents think that if Bartleby doesn't go to college, he will have no future. Several of Bartleby's friends are in the same situation of being rejected by all the colleges they applied to.

These critics need to find a new job ! ! ! This movie is based on a TRUE STORY ,  so 

By sharing this movie, viewers have the opportunity to get to know these heroes better, by following a character that can reflect their struggles, dreams, hopes and dreams for their life, too. Also, these movies bring awareness to issues, giving a voice to those in situations not commonly shown, as well as making us open to understanding unfamiliar backgrounds and culture. Furthermore, people will begin to realise the difficulties of circumstances others had to undergo and value each individual effort.

Enhanced by the expressive cinematography of Agnes Godard (Beau Travail), Golden Door is a visually striking tone poem that follows the journey of a peasant family from their primitive home in Sicily to Ellis Island in New York at the turn of the century. It is a surreal, enigmatic, often strange, but ultimately deeply rewarding experience. Interweaving dreamlike and symbolic imagery with gritty realism, the latest film by Emanuele Crialese (Respiro) is like an impressionistic painting - a cinematic artist's rendering of what the immigration process may have been like for our parents and grandparents.

it 's a great movie for the whole family . i do n't think many people have seen it cause 

I think everyone should give this movie a chance and watch it. It not only provides entertainment but has also so much more to offer! I love how each of the characters and scenes come to life. Kids can really learn a lot from watching the movie as it sends an important message. It is not just any movie. You need to watch it to experience the unique vibe and see the surprise element the film offers. There are enough moments to keep you intrigued.

The Ali G show was really something amazing - he was so stupid wannabe rapper, but no one he interviewed noticed that he was just pretending. Sasha Cohen is actually very intelligent guy, who pretends to be stupid, so he could get really honest answers from people... And it is very funny. So I didn't expect movie to be good, cause it was all acted - no real people or interviews. So the basic point of all show was lost. But I was wrong - I laughed all the time, it was one of the funniest films I ever saw.

I remember seeing this film when I was fairly young & being quite disturbed by it . I found the  graphic content uncomfortable and the theme of repression a little difficult to handle. Ever since, I still don’t find myself gravitating to this genre, as I feel like they rarely stay true to their raw, chilling themes of power and truth, instead just wrapping it all up in one cliché happy ending. It all boils down to if these tales show an escapism and happy resolution, which all so often negates the ongoing terror faced by oppressed people across the globe.

I still can't describe what to feel when I received this by the fnac site. Such a rare movie, so little spoken and known, is difficult to find, even to fans, but the contrast betwen past and present is devastating: now I hold a DVD of the movie, with the finest quality possible. As I did in Atlantis, the other rare Besson movie I bought by the internet, I saw this one at home, with all the lights of my dvd and tv turned off, and marveled at the experience. I didn't know what to expect.

I gave it a seven only because the acting is good . And of course by that I mean Wilkinson 

I gave it a seven because there was other potential areas which it didn't hit perfectly. The writing seemed to have issues with a non-engaging plot and its relationship with audience. What’s more, they felt it lacked the audience engaging soundtrack the film could have incorporated. On the other hand, despite some hiccups, Wilkinson managed to keep things engaging due to his really commendable performance, lifting up the atmosphere during difficult points of the film.

This film biography of early rock and roll star Buddy Holly (1936-1959) is a tour de force for Gary Busey. The movie's highlights are Busey's stage performances where he plays guitar and sings Holly songs. He brings such energy to the performances that Holly's own filmed performances almost pale in comparison. Busey's infectious toothy grin lights up the screen, he creates a totally believable and winning personality and his Oscar nomination for best actor was well deserved.The film follows Holly's career from growing up in Lubbock, Texas, to stardom and New York and his untimely death in a plane crash.

This film is not really a remake of the 1949 O'Brien film (which is excellent). It borrows the main premise--a man has been poisoned and spends the rest of the film trying to find his killer. But I like that the writers chose an English professor, instead of a private dick, as the protagonist. The plot is also quite original. In general, the film moves along fast enough to keep you awake. But what mars this film is a strange dated quality about it (probably due to the horrendous 80's original music score)combined with an affected "noir" feel.

Sacha Baron Cohen is a genius. And this movie is good! Although the film doesn't nearly reach the quality of the tv-show, it's still very funny and has some seriously wicked moments! I've liked Ali G since the first time I saw the material from the show. I think he's one of the best comedy characters of all time.. up there with say, Peter Dragon ("Action") and The Blues Brothers. Biggest surprise with this film was that they've actually got some serious actors to do it (Dance and Gambon).

I had heard of John Garfield, but, didn't know him. I loved this movie. I had never heard of it. I just picked it up randomly. John Garfield is a boxer in the movie. He had been in real life also so he knew his part. He was a fugitive throughout the movie. Someone else killed a man. He character was blamed. He is befriended by a family who has questions and is not quite sure what to make of him. All sorts of minor plots ensue.

A well written screenplay . A moving story showing the middle class English at it 's best . Some great  witty banter between characters 

The film tells the story of family, of trust, love, compassion and mutual understanding between the different generations. It shows how hard life can be at times and how they still rise above it to stay happy and united. With warm laughter, gentle words and special moments along the way, this screenplay provides audiences with an endearing and realistic insight into this much-loved English middle class family. The art of brilliant writing really comes to the forefront, making each and every scene impactful.

this is a teen movie and while u watch it expect some nonsensical stuff added here and there but overall the movie is effective very effective it makes you question and leaves you thinking the story is kinda far fetched but is believable and makes you feel good in sequences, its not like its the usual done and tried path. the characters are pretty well defined and are convincing. Justin long stands out among all the others and watch out for his speech in the end he will convince anyone with that speech he is simply brilliant in that speech.

Undoubtedly one of the best episodes ever , Balance of Terror is 45 minutes of well executed suspense , with  suspenseful dialog , brilliant acting and accurate sound and lighting . The entire episode hinges on the work of the acting duo and their inner conflicts that cause ripples that end up leading to their total downfall. The scenery and art direction throughout the entire episode was superb. Especially the darkened Romulan ship complete with glowing green faces. The battle that took place felt surprisingly balanced for its time and featured everything you need in a tension-filled interstellar affair. Fans love Balance of Terror, and with good reason.

I 've never seen the original `` House Of Wax '' so I really did n't know what to expect 

But to my surprise, the movie ended up being surprisingly good. I had not expected it to be as suspenseful and intriguing as it was. The cinematography and special effects were impressive and gave the movie a tense atmosphere that only a great horror movie could create. Even though there were some cheesy moments, overall I thoroughly enjoyed it. For those who want to be scared and intrigued, this movie is the perfect choice.

Ever since they first came to the Outer Banks and filmed the movie ( I have lived here my whole  life) the scenery has been awe inspiring. The locals never get used to the sheer beauty the ocean brings when it hits the white sands and shines against the glistening waves. From the almost bioluminescent moon glimmering on the open water to the solitude in the rising sun just moments after a gusty sunrise. Many locals find peace here that has taken root in their souls, reassuring us every time we feel anxiousness from the increasing violence of the world.

Spike Milligan's books and plays have defeated film makers over the years, and 2002's 'Puckoon' is sadly no exception. The novel, set in 1924, concerns the partitioning of Ireland, in particular its effects on a solitary community ( the 'Puckoon' of the title ). Due to a colossal blunder, half the village is now in Northern Ireland, the other half is in the Republic. Locals go to the toilets at the bottom of their gardens to find a barbed wire fence blocking their path. Drinkers crowd like sardines into a corner of the pub to enjoy a cheaper pint.

Let's be fair: there are no RULES for scriptwriting, so I won't say the movie SHOULD be something other than it is. I'll just state my opinion. OK, I really liked the script, the way things are told and characters are introduced. However, I think when a play is adapted to the silver screen, it could maybe try and fit this other media. Since this movie was directed by João Falcão, the same man who directed the play, it's not too much of a surprise that the film turned out a bit too theatrical.

I first saw The Buddy Holly Story when I was about seven years old. I had no idea who Buddy Holly was, nor can I remember what it was that made me sit down in front of the television, tuned in to HBO, and watch this engaging biopic. What I remember was realizing that it was a (somewhat) true story, about someone who actually lived. I recall the music, great songs that I still love today (I can't believe Gary Busey sang his own songs and so well - What a stud!) Then, came the end.

If you expect that this movie is full of action and grabbing you from the start then don't watch it. But if you like those kind of meditative movies which stick in your mind for a while, until you get the details, then you will love it. Now don't get me wrong there is action and there are things going on just not in the usual way. Basically the plot is in a post-apocalyptic world where anyone fights in his (or their) way for survival. In this fight they lost the ability to speak...

This is one of my favorite films , ever . The story is just so fantastic and the characters are  so beautifully created

The special effects of this film make it even more incredible. Every time I watch this film, I find something new, something special and enjoyable in every frame and character. Moreover, the cinematography of this film was stunning as well. What I enjoyed the most, were the musical numbers - they seemed to complete each scene, it was a total treat to hear them and become a part of the scene itself.

This film set the standard for all rock biopics to follow. It accomplished this through the energetic performances of the leads, the steadiness of the camera-work (avoiding 'rock-video' clichés that were actually invented for the Beatles in their first two films), tight editing, and a non-judgmental presentation of the star as human being rather than symbol or god (or demon). Yes, there are minor holes in the plot, and incidental details that are a little unnecessary, and there will always be debate between families of those personally involved as to specifics.

I taped The Morrison Murders on Lifetime Movie network and I watched The Morrison Murders on Lifetime, Lifetime Movie network and on Courttv. Jonathan Scarfe and John Corbett did a great job of playing Luke and Walker Morrison. I am glad that Walker got his brother Luke to confess of murdering his parents and their brother Bobby. I enjoy watching True stories on Lifetime, Lifetime Movie network and on Courttv. The Morrison Murders is a good movie to watch. Next time The Morrison Murders is on Lifetime, Lifetime Movienetwork or Courttv I am going to watch The Morrrison Murders again because My favorite actor John Corbbett is in The Morrison Murders.

Truly unique and stunning film of Jules Verne 's `` For The Flag '' by the Czech master director Karel  Zeman is unrivalled piece of fine art in his filmography. Using typical tricks as cut-outs and stop motion effects, Karel creates a captivating voyage in ocean waves and sub marine realm to treasure of Verne’s father's submarine world. Above all he creates pictures with extraordinary serene compositions featuring under water caves full of magical illumination. Overflowing details captivate the mind while its organic cast present a vivid day to day live from dreamy 1700 century island nation .

I really loved this movie and have spent several years trying to get it. It is just not available and it has not been on TV for many many years. I enjoyed it and the songs because it had something different to say and made you think how every person looks at something from different prespectives. Also we often don't appreciate something we have till it is no longer there.My 12 year old daughter just discoverd the music and is entranced with some of the songs. Someday I hope to get a copy of the film so she can have an opportunity to view it.

A very suspenseful giallo from the director of "L'Anticristo"(1974),this one begins with a brilliantly-handled sequence involving a priest,a little girl,and a broken doll.However the main story is about maniac(David Warbeck)marrying a traumatized cripple to kill her for her money.The plot,whilst not original,is really suspenseful,the acting is good and there are several skillful and gory murders.The score by Francesco de Massi is quite effective,some of which can also be heard in Lucio Fulci's "The New York Ripper"(1982).Highly recommended for fans of Italian cinema!

This movie is a love story set in the backdrop of war . Everything about the movie was perfect . The emotions between the two characters felt raw and real, the costume and production designs depicted the struggles of war accurately, and the dialogue moved between action, adventure and comedic scenes seamlessly. Despite their clear ideological differences and their characters seemingly destined for tragedy, their hope was contagious and captivating. Moreover, the theme song that played during key moments tugged the heart strings. By the end of the movie, viewers left with a sense of hope, the feeling that they can brave and persevere despite their circumstances.

Enchanting . The best time to see this movie is sometime when unhappy or sad . It 's all just  so magical. This enchanting movie can provide a much-needed break from the world. A chance to forget your worries and embrace a brighter future, or at least think of a better place and have hope that maybe someday you too can create a magical adventure of your own. Seeing a spark of courage and potential through watching others inspired by this movie can reignite those little flames inside our hearts. And the best time to do it? Well, when else but a bad day?

Chaplin is a doughboy in his final film of 1918, a doughboy who can not seem to get the marching down straight. He spends time "over there" in World War One trenches. Several gags stand out: Limburger cheese as a makeshift grenade for one. The cramped quarters of the barracks in the trenches and when Chaplin and his mates are washed out of their bunks by flooding are highlights. Chaplin ends up capturing several German soldiers single-handed, and he spanks the German commander for refusing a cigarette. When asked how he did it, Chaplin replies that he surrounded them.

I love the TV contest. Hate to see it end. There are so many talented contestants. It's a shame that only 2 will be picked. I love watching the judges also. At times they are as entertaining as the contestants. I have been watching the show faithfully every Sunday night. Wouldn't miss it for the world. It's the best reality show that's ever been on television. Good luck to all the contestants, though I have already chosen the two who I would like to see play Danny and Sandy on Broadway.

A labor of love . Each frame is picture perfect and grabs you . Then the sheer emotion and story-telling  jumps at you as it unfolds

The mastery of timing, frame and light define the director's language and provide every moviegoer with a moment to savour, breathe and to experience something familiar yet different. Furthermore, each moment presented invites us to watch, to imagine and create visual stories, uncover deeper mysteries and search within us for reactions and responses to the cinematic experience. Hence, a movie transcends itself and forges a communion with its viewers creating what some often call - the magic of movies.

Being a middle aged mom myself , I very much appreciated seeing a romance between grown-up people that weaves in  commonalities from other couples facing challenges today. I like seeing relatable emotions between adult partners rather than the teenager kind of situation usually found in some forms of entertainment. This not only teaches us that an older couple can still fall in love, but gives us practical solutions for building healthier relationships. Above all, it shows that no matter how old you are, you still have the capability to find, build, and cherish a connection between two hearts.

William Faulkner was one of the American writers to win the Nobel Prize in literature. Faulkner mostly wrote about life in the South particularly during the depression years. Many of his stories have been adapted to screen. Short stories like Two Soldiers is an endearing tale of two brothers in December 1941 after the attack on Pearl Harbor. The older brother, Pete Greer, goes to Memphis, Tennessee to enlist like hundreds of thousands of young men, some who would never come home. His younger brother doesn't take his departure well. He manages to get a bus ticket to Memphis without any money to find his brother.

Belonging to the subgenre of post-apocalyptic future films, it is a stylistic and very very intimate installment. The most noticed element of the film is its silence; no one speaks. I don't think Besson, despite what is evident in most of his later work, meant it as any kind of cool gimmick. I think what makes it so clever and so effective is the fact that with no other way of communicating, everyone has to read each other based on intuition and conveying of emotion, no matter how slight.

I really loved this movie and have spent several years trying to get it . It is just not available 

But luckily, my searching led me to the internet and through forums, blogs and comments on streaming services, I was able to watch it. It still was not easy to find this film. To purchase it from an actual distributor is quite difficult and expensive. But I believe it’s been worth all of my hard work, as I now can share the film with family and friends and teach about its place in film history.

Before I forget, let me say the artwork in here is outstanding. From garbage cans to the huge cruise ship, the drawings are beautifully done. If this wasn't animated, critics would be lauding the "direction" in here, because it's really good.To the story: Sylvester is picking through the garbage at the shipyards but the pickins' are slim. While brooding at the dock next to a big ship, in a porthole he spots Tweety in his cage. Tweety spots him, too, and you know his first comment - the same one he always makes when he spots the cat.

Valeria , an elegant and pretty young lady lives in a world surrounded by the walls of her shyness and  vulnerability . She only likes spending time with herself and exploring places inside of her mind to run away from the burden of real life situations. That is the only reason Valeria travels long miles alone so often. Every time she completes one, the bitter taste of bitterness inside of her disappears and only understanding resides. Though nothing comes to her the way it is meant to, with great intensity of thoughts in her being, she sails through the ultimate dilemma which tries to pin her down.

Lucio Fulci made a lot of great films throughout his career and the way that many of them featured a bucket load of gore lead to him earning the title 'The Godfather of Gore'. While Don't Torture a Duckling was made before Fulci became well known amongst gorehounds, and isn't all that gory; it's certainly a gritty and nasty little thriller, and for my money - the best film that Fulci ever made! Don't Torture a Duckling really is head and shoulders above a lot of the Giallo genre in terms of production values and unlike many of Fulci's later films, everything about this Giallo is great.

People comparing this movie to big blockbusters like Lord of the Rings or the Matrix will inevitably be disappointed with  this release. This movie's audience should really appreciate the tremendous work put into its craft and creation. Though not as ambitious in its scale as many more prominent films, it manages to carefully and painstakingly form an incredibly beautiful and distinct universe filled with enough content for days of enjoyment and replayability. The tight plotting and varied character backgrounds, added to the strong themes found in the script make for a spectacular viewing experience for both experienced film viewers and the uninitiated alike.

Film auteur Stephan Woloszczuk explores the depths of love , passion , and brotherhood and the devastating results of loss 

His exploration of the intricate forces at work, intertwining story and song are visualized beautifully in his films, tugging at heartstrings from passionate highs to lowest of lows, captivating audiences far and wide. The sheer power of Stephan’s themes transcends cinematic traditions, merging lyrics, choreography and orchestra with seductive imagery into one surreal composition. Nothing is left unexplored, while leaving us with something unknown lingering at the edge of our thoughts.

An interesting look at the immigrant experience , told as a fable with some very weird imagery.I got drawn to  the fantastical aspect of this story - the implications of it were an intense puzzle to me. Every nuance was thoughtfully presented and the presentation created the potential for far reaching conversations about what immigration really entails. Throughout the narrative, the characters continued to struggle with identities - torn between their desire to assimilate yet retaining distinct differences that alienates them. But despite the darkness of this idea, there remained a sense of hope throughout, a sign that both community and identity are mutable, in constant process.

I was n't expecting a great deal from this film , so I was pleasantly surprised when I watched it  

I was surprised to find that it had some very compelling scenes, good production values and well-crafted story-telling. It was entertaining from beginning to end and managed to surprise me multiple times with unexpected plot twists. Overall, I was impressed by how great the film was. It had substance and character development. Its emotional power was an added bonus and it truly moved me with its strong emotional messages. The movie made me question my expectations and overall showed a fantastic level of craftsmanship in the making.

Considering it 's basically low-budget cast , this is a surprisingly good flick about the life and death of rock  and roller Dee Dee Ramone

For the sake of the audience and his long lasting musical legacy , I thought it to be surprisingly commendable on how well it has been crafted with cheap and basic resources. The chronological twists of this grungy urban fairytale tracing his colorful, outrageous past brings us his bizarre tale all too wittily and professionally. Everything, right from acting performances to the collection of occasional snapshot have taken in great sensitivity and marvelous details making it, one hell of a low budget piece and treat for every Ramone fan !

A well written screenplay. A moving story showing the middle class English at it's best. Some great acting by Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson. Tom Wilkinson is one of Britain's best actors. He knows how to be subtle and honest. Emily Watson is an actress I was not familiar with, but to her credit she does a great job of playing the ****** wife. The director, Julian Fellowes did not succumb to the typical Hollywood gimmicks to give the film some meaty storyline. It has not over dramatized it's portrayal of the English middle class.

This is an example of what film school lecturers would call a good debut movie. It follows all the rules. Short scenes, to the point, cheap to shoot, guerilla-film-making, no sets (just disused buildings) and possibly an empty hospital wing. Also, even the black&white film-stock was a stroke of genius, probably selected more for its low expense rather than film effect, but it worked.Reno was amazing as the Brute. Everyone's acting was brilliant. The plot was simple and effective and no flabby bits left to distract you.

Enchanting. The best time to see this movie is sometime when unhappy or sad. It's all just so cute, all, even the way that white bear loves the Queen in secret and gets Her in the end, also the achievement the two young actors of Gerda and Kai gave. It's music is also very nice. The two of us will always be one combined with sad piano tones in some places gives a very touching result and if one watches both parts at once, he'll see the Snow Queen is not so bad.

If you get a chance to get a hold of this lost ( for many years ) gem , I 'd definitely suggest it! Not only will you discover a long-lost world of strange characters, enchanting story arcs, and retro style 8-bit music and visuals but the game's creative freedom offers lots of variety that'll make each playthrough unique. Though there might be slight framerate dips due to its original gamecube origins, these drawbacks are made up for with how enthralling and hilarious it can be when put through your tv's system.

As I have said before, I am NOT a fan of Tweety. He's just so aggravating I wish Sylvester would just eat him and get it over with.In this cartoon Sly is homeless once again and is back to feeding out of garbage cans. He spots a cruise ship leaving port nearby and decides to hop aboard when he spys Tweety is one of the passengers. The ship provides an adequate stage for the following hijinks and Sly desperately tries to catch the annoying bird and avoid seasickness. If only for once he's succeed by chewing and swallowing, thus finishing of the irritating Canary forever.

The last film by underrated director Alberto De Martino ("The Antichrist", "The Killer is on the Phone") is a truly suspenseful but incomprehensibly neglected giallo, containing pretty much all the trademarks that makes this Italian horror sub genre so magnificent and addictive to the fans. There are some very disturbing themes (child abuse, phony priests), loads of creepy moments, plot twists left & right, outstanding music and  last but not least  a handful of really sadistic murder scenes! Especially the opening sequence, which is some kind of prologue, is a powerful piece of horror!

The retelling of a classic story is set to the music of Burt Bacharach and lyrics of Hal David . The modern-day performance captures the 1960s spirit with an update of the beloved characters from Broadway. In it, Tony and Tina once again triumph over their challenges and discover the romantic fulfilment that befell them all those decades ago. Audiences can experience this journey as a sparkling celebration of true love in this spectacular experience with fabulous sets, ornate costumes and wonderful song. Backed by the Burt Bacharach / Hal David songbook, the production guarantees both laughter and tears and is sure to evoke nostalgia in long-time fans while entertaining newcomers too.

This is a funny movie . The Bob & Eddie Show feel of it could lead to a sequel but  the writing doesn't have the sharp edges needed for something that lasting. Despite this, the movie is full of amusing sight gags and musical numbers that have made it enjoyable. The outlandish storylines are one of a kind, like when Bob finds an alien as his travel companion or Eddie developing a costume store while searching for Bob and meeting peculiar people while at it.The misadventures and hilarious run-ins with cops, bad guys and extraterrestrial critters create loads of surprises in this delightfully slapstick film.

Another popular screening for a British picture at Coalville 's Century Theatre . A well crafted , solid drama with  depth , visuals that breath reality as never seen before on this quaint theater’s screens. The action plays out during one summer day in the fictional town of Castlewood and follows a 12 year old protagonist on the day that she and her mother become aware of the fact that their struggling café is set for imminent foreclosure. Along the journey we discover themes of struggling, regret, poverty and addiction through family struggle.

I hope, from his seat on Heaven's comedic throne, Spike Milligan can see and can enjoy this film, as Terence Ryan and Ken Tuohy have taken a book that the author himself said writing it "nearly turned me mad" into a joy to watch.The film tells the story of the Irish town of Puckoon and the problems befallen upon it when the partition between Northern Ireland and the Republic is drawn up, cutting its way through the centre of the village and, more worringly, through the middle of the churchyard.

Some days ago, in Rome, a young Romanian man with criminal precedents assaulted and tortured to death a middle-age lady coming back home after an afternoon of shopping. A Romanian girl, who had seen everything, reported what happened.Therefore, it started a debate about the too much intense flow of immigrants from Romania, generalizing them as criminals, everyone, indiscriminately.I'm only 15, but I thought: what idea of affluence does Italy give to these poor people? How ever do they regard us as the Land of Plenty? Yesterday evening I finally saw NUOVOMONDO, and my question had an answer.

At first I did n't think I would like this movie , but as it progressed it became better and  better . The plot twists began to reveal itself more as the movie went on and soon it became clear this was much more than I ever expected it to be. My initial impression of the movie quickly faded away as I realized the director's original intent. I found myself enthralled in the world the filmmakers had created and caring deeply for the characters I was so desperately trying to learn more about. Overall the movie surpassed all my expectations.

In the first transformation scene, what is the music? I've heard it was "The Greeks Don't Get No Freeks". Is that right? I really liked that sound. I also liked the "Hyde's Got Nothing to Hide" in the final scenes. Truly a doper movie, but with many laughs and puns, sight gags, and slapstick. Madam Woo-Woo's place was reminiscent of some places I have visited myself. Ivy Venus has appeared in some other stuff that is truly amazing. She looks much different in the movie we're talking about, but her maturity didn't hurt her a bit.

I wonder why I haven't heard of this movie before. It's truly a magnificent comedy (I'd say farce, but it's too well acted and I'd hate to denigrate it's quality). A comedic character study about the travails of mid-life crises, the inequity for gays who can't have their long-time unions recognized, and the general differences of people who can't fit nicely into society, that pairs Kathy Bates and Rupert Everett to a wonderful effect. Forget Julia Roberts and Rupert; Kathy Bates and Rupert should do another movie together.

Pity the Monkees . People always accused them of being manufactured ( which they were ) or being nothing more  than an advertising ploy ( which they weren't )

Pity the Monkees who, over the years, were constantly denied the credit they deserved. Most musicians in the Sixties who moved out of traditional vocal pop with strong R&B, rock and even progressive rock sounds moved with critical respect; not the Monkees. Because they did appear as a “made-for-tv” pop band and existed more as a part of television, popular culture treated the Monkees very different from other innovating rock bands.

I was so happy to learn that Hari Om will finally be theatrically released in 2007 . I saw this  film at the 2008 Cannes Film Festival and I was immediately captivated by its beautiful storyline and creative visual approach. I felt very grateful for the fact that people around the world will get to watch the film. In a world dominated by Hollywood big productions and celebrity scandals, it was wonderful to witness a work of art celebrating human existence through characters exploring its deepest depths. I have already seen the film three times, each time discovering nuances and meanings I was not able to capture in previous watches.

I saw this movie on PBS the first time . Then I bought the video and watched it countless times . The story became my go-to comfort after a bad day. Watching it always brought an unexpected feeling of serenity, made me hopeful, and remind me to look at life in a positive way. The core values and principals shown in the movie is something I bring with me to each and every day, consciously or subconsciously. Even after years have passed, and I watch the movie yet again, I never fail to get something new and rewarding out of it.

This show really is the Broadway American Idol . It has singing , the British Guy , A guy who  works in tech, and a comic book lover

This show is quickly becoming the go to place to check out the latest, up and coming Broadway stars! Everyone on the show has the potential to take Broadway by storm. After each performance, audience members are amazed and captivated. From the traditional singing styles of the British Guy to the Comic Book lover delivering an edgy routine - this show really gives Broadway an interesting mix of performers!

Mark Blankfield ( from the old late night TV show `` Fridays '' ) plays Dr. Daniel Jekyll , a  genius scientist who accidentally unleashes a dangerous, monstrous alter-ego while experimenting with a special formula. Fearing he has unleashed a menace upon society, Daniel goes into hiding and enlists the help of old friend to try to find an antidote before his other identity wreaks havoc in the streets. Along the way, Daniel must struggle with his inner conscience as to whether he is a villain or victim to the circumstance that he has set in motion.

Some days ago , in Rome , a young Romanian man with criminal precedents assaulted and tortured to death a  19 year old Italian girl. The Italian Police have worked quickly and meticulously to investigate the case. Witnesses reported to the police about a young man, with a Romanian accent. An inquiry was started by the detectives and with further interrogation the suspect eventually confessed to the assault.The community around Rome has reacted to this terrible incident in various ways, demanding justice. The Prime Minister has met with both Roman and Italian officials to find an efficient solution for an extradition request for the suspect.

An interesting look at the immigrant experience, told as a fable with some very weird imagery.I got drawn to this movie because it tells of immigrants from Sicily who traveled to America. I imagine much the same as my Grandfather did at that time. Travelling in steerage to provide ballast for the ships, I cannot imagine it was very comfortable, as shown in this film.Laws restricting immigrants existed. I would guess that these laws were more strict on those who came from the Mediterranean and Africa. Immigrants had to be free from contagious diseases or hereditary infirmities.

Damien O'Donnell has a good track record and in this film he handles a very delicate topic with sensitivity but  also gives an engaging experience. He depicts the dilemma that adolescents must face, managing complex relationships with family, while longing for their personal freedoms and place in the world. The cinematography draws the audience in and adds to the heightened emotion the story generates. By the end of the film, a broader scope is taken to show the lives that teenagers everywhere share and what an integral part of life these unique relationships can be.

This movie gives us some WWII history along with some touching romance , a little fantasy and meaningful emotion - 

This is the story of a family of Parisians during WWII, faced with unprecedented loss and perseverance. We follow the journey of Elsbeth and Raimund, a young couple struggling with choices, hardships and heartaches but ultimately sharing a triumphant journey. With exquisite attention to the look, setting and music of wartime Paris, we see the horrors of Nazi occupation, and the beginnings of bravery, resilience and courage from a Parisian populace not afraid to hope and resist.

I saw Borderline several years ago on AMC . I 've been looking for it ever since . It was  so captivating and inspirational. At the time, I found comfort in the tale of a hopeless soul striving to make it on the stage against a series of struggles. I found great parallels in my own life story and the ups and downs that most face while traveling through their personal and professional journey. Now, so many years later, I’d love to revisit that movie and perhaps show it to some young adults for a renewed source of inspiration and to encourage those just starting their road to the promised land.

(Some spoilers included:)Although, many commentators have called this film surreal, the term fits poorly here. To quote from Encyclopedia Britannica's, surreal means:"Fantastic or incongruous imagery": One needn't explain to the unimaginative how many ways a plucky ten-year-old boy at large and seeking his fortune in the driver's seat of a red Mustang could be fantastic: those curious might read James Kincaid; but if you asked said lad how he were incongruous behind the wheel of a sports car, he'd surely protest, "NO way!"

This is sweet. The actress who played the nurse with the gonzongas is the same actress who plays Elvira mistress of the dark. Another little tidbit is the actress who played the nurse who would give her wedding ring was the landlord lady of Roy Munsin in King Pin. This is most glorious story ever to be told. It should sell more copies than the bible. My parents played a part in suggesting the release of this movie to a local movie theater. The movie ran for a week and we were one of 4 families to see it.

Like a few people I know , I came in late on 'Stingers ' ; not until 2000 . Three  years later I could easily tell that my family had already been missing out

on so much when I caught the show during a late night on television. I was instantly hooked by the arresting plots, driven by unique characters. My Sundays went from movie night to becoming Sunday night viewing night. Each episode grabbed me into an ever unraveling web of maffia, graft, deception and overall heart racing 'guess who's after who'.

In an early scene , Luca ( David Pasquesi ) and James ( Jeff Garlin ) are walking down a  busy city street. Luca and James converse as they take in the city sights and sounds. As they do so, they encounter a group of passionate street musicians who entice them to stay and watch their show. Despite the bustling atmosphere of the street, they forget the time, lingering and admiring the musicians. With joy on their faces, they throw money into the musicians’ hats and move on, experiencing the vitality of the city and sharing some memorable time together.

Hey all you jive hustlers , you stone foxes , you mean dudes . Watch out cause Slaughter is back  . He brings with him an attitude and a strength none of you expected. He won't take your nonsense no more, he is ready to take charge of the hood and stand for what's right. He ain't in for trouble but for justice, you gotta respect that. In a place full of desolation, mayhem, and darkness, a leader shines, his glimmer enough to show you the right way forward.

Easily Lucio Fulci 's most respected film , `` Do n't Torture a Duckling '' is highly renowned for it 's level of depth and societal critique that went largely unmatched in genre films of its time . One of the reasons for this level of depth in the film was the performance of Florinda Bolkan as Claudia Gerini; who brings complexity and a psychological richness to her character in spite of the film's short run time. She instils a real poignancy and humanity to Claudia, making her more than just a target of terror.

William H. Macy always gives a good performance. He never looks lazy and never seems like he'd rather be somewhere else. In short, he's what more actors should be like. "A Slight Case of Murder" is directed by Steven Schachter, who went on to do two more great films with Macy (Door to Door, The Wool Cap).Television movies have long been a dump of overdone acting, poor cinematography, and sub-par scripting. That's why it's so refreshing to see a TV movie that does exactly what it's sort of film was created for.

Blind Spot's images are great. The action draws you in completely, even though the movie is a bit long. By the end credits all that you can think about are the film's positive high-points. The lead actors have the most incredible screen presence. The story is heart-wrenching. The film score is nicely understated . Completely moving in its own powerful way. Not your standard melodramatic cuing. Trance-like moments add poetic resonance to the engrossing narration and terrific visual compositions. Hope you get a chance to see this film. It delves into some dark territory but you come out of the tunnel seeing nothing but white light.

Films belonging to the "film noir" genre usually contain similar elements: a "deus ex machina" plot twist that drives the main character headlong into bedlam, a pretty but psychotic girl, a handsome but psychotic thug, lots of money, lots of brutality, and usually a denouement in the desert. Think "High Sierra" or "White Heat. "There is plenty of hard-boiled bad film noir out there. But when film noir is good, you can't take your eyes off the train wreck of human lives.It is this latter tradition that "Blind Spot" belongs to.

This is another film where the cinematography is the best thing to recommend it . That would be fine if  the overall execution and the script are to blame for how the film unravels,

but then again, a great deal of time and resources was put into capturing gorgeous images which had its consequences to the production design, costumes and ultimately performance and cinematography is definitely the most noteworthy element of this otherwise dreary-filled movie. As visuals sometimes give greater life to an existing set up and drab casting, this movie stands as an ode to visual artists who knew that above all their work needed to shine through any dense landscape of shortcomings.

This film, winning Im Kwon-Taek the Best Director at Cannes in 2002 (tied with P.T. Anderson for Punch-Drunk Love), is about a 19th century Korean painter with a commoner's roots and significant impact on Korean painting. One of the strengths?of the film is that Im tries to help us see with the eye of a painter, so we see multiple scenes and objects which help our drunken painter friend, Jang Seung-up (Choi Min-shik),?receive inspiration.The costumes and the art direction are all impressive and the acting is even along being good.

As with so many modern US films, there has to be a supernatural element to the plot, but if you just let that go, this is a tale with heaps of charm and a kindly heart cased in a crab shell.We are presented with a scene of a town in an economically depressed area struggling to find anything to be happy about. Beau Bridges' character is really up against it with a family on the increase, a nil bank balance and a brother-in-law who's sold out to a big business chain which he secretly hates, but in which he is willing to rub Beau's nose.

I've commented once on this Chucky great, but I had to do it again to say some things about the film, when I first saw it in a great balcony in a great theater. The film was a lot of fun in the theater and my first Chucky film ever in a theater, and that was a special moment for me, because I cherish Chucky. The other horror villains are referenced with GREAT COOLNESS!!! And the gore was shockingly great! The scene where the gay kid gets nailed by the truck was amazingly cheerful!

I never heard of architect, Louis Kahn, until this documentary. In this almost two hour documentary which goes very quickly, his son, Nathaniel Kahn, explores his father's life from Estonia to the slums of North Philadelphia to the University of Pennsylvania in West Philadelphia where he studied and taught. He travels to Bangladesh, Israel, Connecticut, Trenton, and La Jolla, California as well as New York City to explore his father's creative genius. Personally, Louis Kahn had three families including his wife, Esther, who refused to give him a divorce and their daughter Sue Ann.

Chucky ( the murderous doll from `` Child 's Play '' and 2 crappy sequels ) is dead . But  his 

legacy lives on. For years he has been a cornerstone of horror movie buff and pop culture alike, with phrases such as "Hi, I'm Chucky" being well known quotes from his movies. Recently, we have seen various books, art, figurines and new collectible items paying tribute to him being released. Though dead and buried, Chucky is clearly still having an effect and resonating with audiences to this day. All hail to the Lord of the Mischief!

In Tweety's S.O.S, Sylvester goes from picking garbage cans to being a stowaway on a cruise ship that happens to carry a certain canary bird-and Granny, his owner. Uh-Oh! Once again, Tweety and Granny provide many obstacles to the cat's attempts to get the bird. Sylvester also gets seasick quite a few times, too. And the second time the red-nosed feline goes to the place on the ship that has something that cures his ailments, Tweety replaces it with nitroglycerin. So now Sylvester can blow fire! I'll stop here and say this is another excellent cartoon directed by Friz Freling starring the popular cat-and-bird duo.

Louis Khan was one of the most influential architects of our time, and this film speaks volumes about how little everyone really knew. His son's desire to find out who, and more importantly what he was is moving, and emotional.This film captures the spirit of what architecture is really about, what good design is, and the emotional price that is paid for it. Equally haunting is the sound track. If you see the film, and then listen to the sound track you can revisit the film simply by listening.

"Showtime" falls somewhere north of what some critics have been saying, and a little south of what I expected months ago when I first heard about Eddie Murphy and Robert Di Niro teaming up for a comedy. Overall, it was pretty good! As "real life" crime or cops go-- and plot, for that matter-- it is pretty illogical, but DUH--- this is a comedy. Also, while the special effects, chases, aerial shots, and skyscrapers blowing up were present but lower key than a Schwartzenegger movie, I found it a bit tiresome and overdone.

If we could have `` Separate Tables , '' why not `` Separate Lies . `` This becomes somewhat involved  because the complexity of our situation determines what outcome we are seeking. Truth in any form, has never been simpler; between lying and deceiving oneself there can be multiple shades of grey. Knowing and determining when we should own up and embrace honesty can be quite perplexing at times. It also means our individual definitions of honesty often fall short as there can be repercussions that depend upon our cultures and societies we come from.

As the mom of a 3 year old and a 2 year old , I adore AristoCats . It is  the perfect family movie for my family of four. I often wonder if a better moral could be told. Even though it centers on cats, the teachings go way beyond the pet world. Marie teaches kids a valuable lesson: Family always stands together and solves any crisis together with unity and collective wisdom. She educates children not to give up hope and try different approaches in order to overcome struggles in their lives.

What a great film ! I never knew much about Buddy Holly , but was familiar with his lively and  popular songs. It was incredibly insightful learning his struggles as a teenager to becoming a big music superstar, before suddenly facing the unfortunate ending of his short life. Watching all of his interactions with family, fellow musicians and groupies, with actor-play performances to keep all entertained - I could have stayed in the movie theater all night! Knowing Buddy Holly had passed at such an early age was a tragic experience for his loved ones, yet even so his music carries through time until this day.

SHOWTIME is a mess, but it's an entertaining mess. The plot is forgettable, the satire is lightweight and the action sequences, though well-staged, aren't that exciting. But I laughed. A lot. Credit goes to the inspired pairing of De Niro and Murphy. They have great chemistry. Murphy delivers the one-liners, De Niro cracks us up with a look or grimace. This movie will get a RUSH HOUR-like reception from the critics. Don't listen to them. If you're a fan of De Niro or Murphy, you're going to enjoy this movie.

I just saw this film and I recommend it . It has a very good plot , it holds your  attention all the way to the end . The characters are interesting and complex. Every decision and choice they make influences the story. Even minor roles play an important role in bringing the plot forward. Every scene has something to say, helping in building suspense and suspense keeps you hooked. I also enjoyed how this film tackled deep themes like fate and faith and opened a thoughtful discussion afterwards. The way it incorporated humour was something that made it more entertaining and created more characters for viewers to attach to.

We saw La Spettatrice at the Syracuse International Film & Video Festival & liked it.This film delved into the fear we all have. Fear of rejection, fear of intimacy and most importantly fear of our own inadequacies.The three lead actors, Barbora Bobulova as Valeria, Brigitte Catillon as Flavia, Andrea Renzi as Massimo are match well to their roles and are excellent. It was a joy to witness the dynamic between the three of them as it seemed real.I believe Barbora Bobulova is a stand out. I hope we see much more of her in the coming years.This film doesn't take the easy way out.

You know , people who make comedies so often forget it 's really ok to be outrageous . Well ,  it's something I stand behind ! You can have a meaningful , emotional , even nostalgic moment in the show , and then out of the blue you can turn it into something funny . For me that makes a huge difference to the humour. Not only do you get those surprisingly hilarious one-liners that evoke tears of laughter, you also get thoughtful jabs of satire and edginess, leading to the absurdity that keeps us hooked onto the shows we enjoy the most.

I've read a lot of reviews about Showtime on IMDb and many seem to miss the mark. I've noticed a lot of reviewers calling this the typical "buddy" film. De Niro is in no way Murphy's buddy throughout most of this movie. In fact, part of the comedy of this film is De Niro's reluctance to be friends with anybody.Murphy really shines in this one. He is back at doing what he does best, acting like a complete ham. He is a cop who wants so much to be an actor and enjoys being in the reality show.

This is a remake of the anime classic from the 80 's , and this one is even better . The remake maintains a faithful representation of the story while bringing it up to date with the modern graphics and more advanced special effects. A well known cast of seasoned voice actors help the story flow in their well-loved accents and expressions. Critics have said that this remake proves that remakes can be even better than their original iterations, introducing the story to a new generation of fans. It stands out amongst other remakes of classic anime stories because it appeals to all kinds of anime fans, no matter the age.

I wish there were more films about middle aged people. The intellectual journey and the twists and turns of life's moral highway make interesting viewing. There seems to be a different standard of judgement on women who have extra marital affairs than on men. Amy Watson's hurtful and humiliating behaviour towards her husband seems to pass without comment. Reverse the roles and one could expect a torrent of condemnation towards the man. If she found her husband boring and judgmental she could could have told him so, left and waited for a no doubt large financial settlement upon divorce.

I recently saw Blind Spot in Coyoacan, where it drew a huge crowd and some pretty intense discussion. I really admired the story and visual approach. The action is frightening and the mood of loneliness that the film projects is amazing. There is much beauty in the melancholy that surrounds these three misfit heroes. Not just in the desert but in the city too. My best scene was after the boy discovers his friends in the apartment and then rides his skateboard through all the remarkable lights of the city. You really feel for this guy.

By convincing the Prime Minister to back the totally unsuitable Ali G as a candidate for Staines in the local elections, nasty chancellor David Carlton (Charles Dance) hopes to discredit his party's current leader, thus enabling him to seize power. To his surprise, however, the plan backfires, Ali is embraced by the nation, and Carlton is forced to find other ways to try and guarantee his political future.Puerile, crude, misogynistic, and always outrageous: Ali G Indahouse, the big-screen debut outing for Sascha Baron Cohen's middle-class Berkshire gangsta, is all of these things and much moremeaning it's my kind of film!

Do you liked "Dead Man don't wear Plaid"? What about "Top Secret" and "A Chorus Line"? Well Müllers Büro is a fantastic Melange of all three of them, as unlikely it may seem. Very Funny "tongue in Cheek" Movie Noir hommage with stunning Songs and great Dancing. You have to have a little odd humor for this movie, but it is very well worth seeing it. I've voted it a nine, If the end would be a bit more logic it would have gotten a ten. Thats how Good that Movie is.

There 's no point in comparing this with the original series . Though different in look and content , both  series still managed to remain a 

popular favorite for its own set of reasons . Whereas the new series showcases thrilling twists and darker narrative style, the original emphasized the touching stories with good humour . In addition, the incorporation of technology with 3D animation proved to be captivating for the new fans. Also, its wider accessibility with TV shows and books and YouTube captivated children's imagination and enhanced the series's overall charm. Ultimately , no matter which version ,the adorable characters kept both series on top of everyone's minds.

I would say 'Bride of Chucky' is a "return to greatness" but the series was never really great. Very good #1 was, #2-3 were throwaways, and I think this 4th installment is equal to or even better than the first movie. And it contains the best subtitle/tagline: "Chucky Gets Lucky." So he does, in the role of Jennifer Tilly, who thoroughly rejuvenated this series as Jeri Ryan did for 'Star Trek: Voyager.' Tilly didn't just create a presence; she added much needed humor, back-story, drama, tension and a great little sidekick/play-thing for Chucky.

What 's the point of this messages if not to discuss and share thoughts about the next season ... Here ’s a way to approach the conversation. By encouraging our community to focus on solutions and actively engage in lively discussions, we can offer our perspective, put forth solutions, learn from each other’s ideas, and discuss what might happen with the upcoming season. By utilizing the features of different messaging forums or comment sections, we can review key ideas, opinion pieces, and logical debates so everyone’s thoughts and solutions have their place and respect.

probably the best horror movie in 5 years .. there 's been lame remakes , attempts to make you scared . Although horror movies have certainly gone through their ups and downs over the past 5 years, we've all found something to enjoy in them, be it laughs at some campy dialogue or covering our eyes and screaming during the gruesome scenes. No doubt that new and innovative story telling within horror movie genres will lead to a new golden age, much to our collective delight! Many young creators have their own unique take on what the horror movie could be.

The revelation here is Lana Turner's dancing ability. Though she was known privately to be an excellent nightclub and ballroom dancer, Miss Turner rarely got the opportunity to demonstrate this ability on film.So, viewers take notice! Here, MGM were clearly still trying to determine in what direction they would develop the still young starlet, and were, therefore, consigning her to everything from Andy Hardy to Doctor Kildaire.In "Two Girls on Broadway," however, she is given an excellent opportunity to display her native rhythm and ability to shift tempo in the lavish production number, "My Wonderful One, Let's Dance."

it's a good watch if u have time - deals with three friends who get into a needless bar fight, and get into serious trouble. they find themselves fighting some shadowy people, and can't deal with. very, very disturbing portrayal of japan, the arbitrariness of modern life... some intense scenes, but a bit of a potboilerthe spoiler was that the plot is not too clear based on English sub titles. obviously, i don't know Japanese.the only other Japanese movies i've seen were kurosawa, who is a different and far loftier than this modern genre.
