I was watching an NFL game and started surfing during a break and found this on one of the HBO  talk shows. I was astounded by the experience shared by this person and the way they managed to tackle such an important topic with grace. I never realized before then, just how real this issue can be. This sparked my interest in understanding the scope of this problem and what I can do as a small individual to have a collective positive impact. Although this show was entertainment at face value, the discussions it initiated challenged the viewer to delve deep into a hard truth - mental health.

SPOILERS BELOW`A Dog's Life' was most noteworthy for its excellent comic timing. In Charlie Chaplin's other movie from 1918, `Shoulder Arms', the silent film genius focuses on an entirely different brand of humor. His war comedy specializes in surreal, exaggerated set pieces in which Chaplin demonstrates unprecedented creativity and mastery of composition. When the soldier's bunker gets flooded, the water level reaches just the right height so that Chaplin can execute his gags most successfully. In a later scene, the soldier dresses up as a tree, a disguise that belies Chaplin's much increased ingenuity and goofiness.

Valeria, an elegant and pretty young lady lives in a world surrounded by the walls of her shyness and depression. Although she may have a one-night lover or if someone lives with her, it makes no difference of being completely alone. Valeria is also a passionate woman who can take actions to approach that special man, Massimo, and at the same time the fear that allows her to answer his questions only with a "yes", "no" or "I don't know". The way to accent the loneliness of the character is magnificent.

I 'm not a huge fan of Lucio Fulci 's films . Most of his 80s gore films had their  time and I believe the appeal of it has kind of gone past its glory. However, I think some of his work stands up nicely over time and the cinematic prowess has never been overshadowed. His mysterious Italian horror, Démoni 2, starring Simonetti and narrations by Cruz remain cult classics for many horror fans. AIP’s New York Ripper as well, albeit having various flaws and slip-ups is also highly regarded among die-hard fans of 80s slasher.

After a somewhat slow start I thought this movie about the Italian occupation of a Greek island during World War  II was turning out quite good. As I watched, I noticed it seemed to lack a bit in acting ability and lack some suspense that I've seen in some of the same time period. The battle sequences were mostly cliched and visually lacking any attention to detail. Nevertheless, as the movie continued, I began to see the struggle and tragedy unfolding as the years dragged on, culminating in a strong ending that emphasizes the tremendous human toll on all sides.

Oh my gosh ! ! I love this movie sooooooooooooooooooooo much ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! I can hardly believe my luck! I've watched it four times so far and it's already one of my favorites. The cast, the characters, the visuals, the soundtrack - all of it is brilliant! The movie made me cry, made me smile, and also made me think. I love it, I could watch it over and over again. All in all, it was a unique, once in a lifetime kind of experience!

Another great Tom Wilkinson performance punctuates "Separate Lies," a 2005 film also starring Emily Watson, Linda Bassett and Rupert Everett. Directed by Julian Fellowes, it's the story of a married couple, James and Ann Manning where the husband (Wilkinson) believes he and his wife (Watson) are happy together. An accident near their house on the night they have a party brings the police around. It is a hit and run that killed their maid Maggie's Bassett) husband. James becomes suspicious of a neighbor, Bill Bule (Everett) when he sees some damage on his car.

Not a stunner, but a good movie to see once or twice. Bill Macy shows he can do more than just act; his writing was pretty darn good. Great supporting cast, especially Jamie Cromwell as the extortionist private eye.The movie's greatest strength is the work of Macy, who reminds us of his Jerry Lundergaard role from Fargo. He has numerous scenes where he is extremely funny as a slimy, manipulating and deceitful character. It's enjoyable to watch him be a weasel, and for a while I was happy that things were turning out well for him.

I saw the trailer and read some reviews , and I had low expectations for this movie . I was  surprised when the movie began

I was immersed in the beautiful storyline and intrigued by the thought provoking themes it presented. I started rooting for the main character even when they encountered obstacles along the way. The cinematography was magnificent and the cast selection was inspired, but my favourite aspect was how engaging the story was. I could feel the characters emotions through their performances and the meaningful symbolism enriched each scene. This movie has captured the attention of millions for a reason, and as it unfolded before me I completely understood why.

The Child's Play series isn't a favourite of mine, but Bride Of Chucky is actually an okay movie. This time we have two dolls Chucky and his former girlfriend (when he was human) Tiffany. Together they go on a journey to find an object. There are a few interesting scenes through the movie like the guy getting hit by the truck and literally exploding, the sex scene between Chucky and Tiffany and the ending which allows for another sequel to take place. Wasn't really a straight forward horror, it mixed a lot of comedy and was a sort of spoof of the horror genre.

I wonder why I have n't heard of this movie before . It 's truly a magnificent comedy ( I  wish it would come out on dvd ) 

I went on to do a bit more research, watching different interviews, music videos, and discovering the history of the characters. This helped paint a picture of why I should give it a chance. I took a leap of faith and gave it a try. Little did I know it was one of the funniest movies I had seen in a long time! It's unexpected gems like these that really brighten my day.

I watch the show every day and it is very entertaining . It provides updates of tech news , video  tutorials and entertainment. It offers unique discussions from celebrities and experts from all around the world, such as movie stars, social influencers, entrepreneurs, CEOs and a variety of other figures. Each person has their own viewpoint and shares insight on their knowledge about the industry, contributing valuable tips and knowledge that I can apply in my own life. The show also has additional coverage like live event interviews and exclusive announcements about future trends in technology.

Accepted is a 2006 teen flick that stars the guy from the mac and PC ads. The movie is about Bartelby .B. Gaines a guy who has rejected from all the colleges he has applied for so decides to make his own college and invites all the other people who did not make it, problem is hundreds of people sign up to his school. The movie is hilarious and I was lucky enough to buy it for $5.00 at a sale and I have always watched it since. Overall this movie is a must watch for fans of all comedy as it is funny, witty and just a good movie all up.

Right this may be the wine talking but this could be the best movie I've seen in a very long time. Granted I spent much of the first half an hour wondering what the hell was going on but once I had accepted that I would never understand everything from the subtitles I was able to enjoy the film.Can you really hate a film where a staff turns into a flock of birds that defecate over the enemy? What does character development matter when faced with a lesbian alien princess whose people built the pyramids? Why does Buddha wear seriously blinging diamond earrings?

"Hari om" is an Indian greeting and the compelling title character of the film bearing this same name(played by the wedding planner from Monsoon Wedding) greets you and takes you on a journey through the heart of southern India. There's no "Bend it like Beckham" backdrops and stereotypes, and only slight salutes to the music and dancing of Bollywood (however, the soundtrack is well worth procuring), but rather, the feel that you are seeing the real India permeates the film through the use of dozens of local residents in each scene to augment the performance of the five professional actors.

This is one of those movies where I just want to move my feet and dance around the house . So as soon as the credits finish rolling I start swaying, gyrating and sometimes even shouting to my favorite lines or most exciting parts! Moving with the flow of the music that was used in the film always makes me so energized, almost like I'm at a live concert myself. There's a certain aura that helps me feel liberated, motivated and happy. Its simply pure joy at its most uncomplicated, laid-back form, living each moment of the music and never looking back!

What a shame this movie was never released. (It is now playing on cable.) I tuned in based on my high regard for the stars and was rewarded by seeing a movie far better than the ones I've been paying to see in theatres recently. I like to be surprised. So often movies are marketed as "offbeat," but are in fact more of the same old recycled drivel. This movie is genuinely different, with the bonus of a heartwarming message. Jonathan Pryce sings like an angel.

Considering all of the comedies with a military situation that have been done in history , someone had to be  first . The 1950 classic "Tears from Stalins' Statue" may very well be one of the first modern comedies to set it's scene against a backdrop of military scenery. Though comedy about military occupation and politics was never rare, this farce introduced themes that would not usually appear in such an environment. However, with bold gags about enlisted military workers and resourcefulness among dire conditions, the film paved the way for modern interpretations of an emotionally saturated realm of hardships.

I thought it was brilliant ! It was great watching the presenter tracking each one of them down . Dwight  

The end of the show finally arrived with Dwight walking up on the stage, complete with microphone and hugs to each participant that had followed his journey on-screen. For an unexpected story to develop, he had seamlessly maintained his goals over his physical limitations and flourished under intense conditions. The remarkable series was only proven as an inspirational example of taking that necessary journey of personal self-growth to better our society and leave no obstacles untackled.

"Back in the Day" is an interesting, but flawed effort. Ja Rule stars as Reggie Cooper, a honest but sad man trying to cope with the death of his father. He meets his old friend J-Bone (Ving Rhames) who tries to force Reggie into a life of crime. Reggie also falls in love with Alica (Tatyana Ali) who is the preacher's daughter. Now he has to choose: Love Or Crime.Ja Rule does a competent job as Reggie. At least he's trying to act. Ving Rhames is perfect as J-Bone.

The very few reviews I could find online of Barnens ö really do not do it justice . I read  almost everything my aunt had given me from her book collection and found it very entertaining . Out of curiosity, I asked around to see if my other friends had heard of it and even I was surprised when all of them unanimously voted Barnens ö as the best Swedish fiction novel. After making a few inquires, I found out that even its first international launch at the Stockholm Writers’ Festival was extremely successful and a popular choice among the international audience.

This movie, based on a true story of Gerrit Wolfaardt, is one of the best films I've seen on race relations in South Africa; a very good history lesson of the turmoil of 80's South Africa. I put it in on the scale of American History X as far as it's depiction of how a young man can get seduced by the Aryan doctrine and how the "certain" segments of the Christian church taught a false doctrine regarding race to justify an injustice.It's strong message of forgiveness and redemption, is one of rarity in films today.

I viewed the original Outer Limits in real time, when first broadcast and have since viewed the entire original series again and again in re-runs and complete on DVD. I find the New Outer Limits WELL MORE than just a remake of old retread episodes, as some of the more adolescent commentators have suggested.With seven (7) years of programs versus just the two (2) years of the original series, the producers and writers have certainly added considerable new original stories and philosophical lines to a much longer running and very well produced (cable) TV series.

I thought this was movie was great , Richard Greico and Yasmine Bleeth have great chemistry in this movie . Their acting really complements each other, Greico is playing a rebellious maverick and Bleeth, a rule-following thinker. He constantly fights against society, while she attempts to settle her differences within it. One scene even shows Bleeth exposing an alter-ego in Greico to make him fit society's mold, much to Greico's dislike. It is an epic battle between her intellectual rigidity and his wild mentality that really drove the story and entertained the viewer.

I've seen the 1973 movie Lost Horizons and read many of the reviews for this movie. I agree the move had many opportunities for improvement but unlike all those who are looking for the perfect movie with the perfect songs and the best acting, I was looking for something a bit different and this movie gave it to me. I watched this movie not as a critic but as a person looking for a little hope, a little cheer, a bit of a release from my everyday life, and this is what I got.

The Monkees , surprisingly , are a big favorite of mine . Yes , they might have been the original 

manufactured band, but there's a certain energy to their music that transcends any creative manipulation. From my youthful 'Head' to some more recent output I was unfamiliar with, it was inspiring to hear the style change, along with personal chemistry that really fed into their recorded works. The whole essence is still alive even in current versions and versions to come of the 'pre-fab four' - because without a doubt there's much more music yet to be written about.

Duchess and her three kittens are enjoying the high life with their devoted human mistress until the wicked butler Edgar, with his eyes on a big inheritance, decides to dope them and get them out of the picture. How can these fragile creatures cope in the unfamiliar countryside and the meaner streets of Paris? Only by meeting the irrepressible alley cat O'Malley, a rough diamond with romance in his heart. After they get a taste of the wide dangerous world, he guides them home, and Edgar gets his just desserts at the wrong end of a horse.

This movie is truly a classic 80s movie! A must have in any '80s' movie collection! Guns, Bad Guys, CREEPS, Gangs, CHARLES BRONSON and more CREEPS!!!! In my opinion, this is the best Death Wish movie. Tons of non-stop action! And keeping with the classic 80's "bad guy vs good guy" movie - this movie is about anything but the norm and all about guns and CREEPS! We see Bronson mowing down thugs and CREEPS with a 30 caliber Korean War heavy machine gun! A HEAVY MACHINE GUN FOR CRYING OUT LOUD!

Before I forget , let me say the artwork in here is outstanding . From garbage cans to the huge  tapestry of Che Guevera on the ceiling of the entry hallway , it makes the atmosphere just about as cool as a room like this can be. The graffiti spread throughout the establishment make it unique, offering messages from environmental concerns, controversial takes on today's media to indigenous artist coming together from cultures from all around the globe. The grand fireplace built in a heritage-like architecture showcases historic pieces. On the dancefloor a pop up lightshow stage flanked by balloon figures drive the patrons away.

Gary Busey did a splendid job playing the rock-n-roll legend Buddy Holly(1936-59). He does have a spitting image to the man. Being a garage band in the 50's is sure different from today's. Having a group of three is usually simple back in those days. I bet that Buddy Holly(Busey) was a much better musician than most of what I heard. Since he lived in Lubbock, Texas, it was only a quiet country town back then. His parents were Christians, though his mother was a strong supporter of her son's work.

I always liked listening to Buddy Holly and felt a real loss when he was killed at a young age in an airplane crash. He wasn't in the old rock 'n roll class of , let's say, Chuck Berry or Jerry Lee Lewis, but he wasn't far behind. Who knows how big his legacy would have been had he sang for decades. Almost every single he put out was a hit.So, I was very pleasantly surprised how good a job Gary Busey did at playing him and at imitating his singing voice.

We saw La Spettatrice at the Syracuse International Film & Video Festival & liked it.This film delved into the fear  and doubt of Lucia, the lead character, as she and her friends lived under the oppressive regime of their culture. We felt both sorrow and joy through the expression in her eyes, as the unfolding story moved us through emotion. The way the story ended in the embrace of acceptance for different customs is so strong to watch. La Spettatrice has a strong moral message that emphasizes respect and acceptance in all communities. Everyone can relate to feeling scared and wanting to belong, no matter what your situation is.

As many of today's movies are guilty of, the plot isn't exactly stellar, the movie doesn't move anyone, and certainly this won't warrant any award (outside of Blockbusters' perhaps)...but then again, who really cares.Eddie Murphy and Robert De Niro team up to produce a very funny, at times hilarious, movie that I really enjoyed. Russo and Shatner played their small parts well as well. Man, I hope in the future my wife ages as well as Miss Renee has.Moving along, this "buddy" cop-flick produces high laughs in a reasonable amount of time.

by TyNesha Mells. In this drama, Ja Rule, who stars as Reggie, struggles with the loss of his father. His old friend J-Bone, who is a cold-blooded thug recently released from prison, helps Reggie find who murdered his father. A week after his dad died, a preacher, Reverend Packer, came up dead. Reggie was suppose to be the one to kill him, but did he? Did Reggie kill Reverend Packer or was it some type of a setup? Back in the Day also has a couple of romantic scenes.

Cult-director Lucio Fulci is probably most famous for his gory Zombie flicks from the 1980s that earned him his rightful reputation as the "Godfather Of Gore". Fulci's absolute greatest film, however, dates back to 1972 and, while it is definitely gritty and violent, it is not nearly as gory as many of his other films. "Non Si Sevizia Un Paperino" aka. "Don't Torture A Duckling" of 1972 is not only by far Fulci's greatest film, this tantalizing and utterly brilliant Giallo is one of the absolute highlights of the genre.

I went to the pre-screening of `` Rory O'Shea Was Here . '' I like this movie better than I  thought. The actors performances were quite convincing, and there was no mistaking the feelings in the air of sadness and frustration which radiated throughout the movie. The plot was simple yet heart-warming, showing the kind and fragile nature of friendship which many of us aspire to. The humor of the film had me laughing despite the overwhelmingly poignant atmosphere. Overall, this movie is definitely a must-watch if you're after a little emotional trip!

No real plot, no character development, no Scorcese-level direction, but seriously, were you really expecting any of this? The only thing that matters is that this flick is absolutely hilarious, nearly on the same level as Borat. Sure, the ending drags a bit, but if Borat's cameo didn't crack you up, you must be the worst batty boy in the history of batty boys. Sacha Baron Cohen is possibly the greatest comedian ALIVE, and here he gets more laughs than Jude Law on a nude beach.

This musical has a deep meaning which is appreciated by only a few. The wise can see the wisdom contained in what most call folly.This music may well regain popularity as world consciousness rises. It is about a land "far away from it all" where "living things have room to grow." Its people are "living and growing together" mentally and spiritually faster than in biological age.The lyrics help us recognize the relativity of this "world that is spinning around" and to "look inside yourself; that is where the Truth always lies."

I saw this movie when it first came out in 1973 and loved it. Since then I've searched for a video but never found it until now, 33 years later, when I ordered it from Moviehunter. Sorry to say it doesn't hold up. This glamourized version just can't rise up to the 1937 production level. I love Burt Bacharach's musical score, that is if listend to by itself, and I even bought a CD of it, but for my taste it doesn't lend itself well to this mysterious and compelling story. Just doesn't fit.

The Aristorcats is a hilarious film that not many people have seen. Clearly not that many because it only got a 6.8. There is nothing wrong with it at all. It's my favorite of the Disney classics, which have tons of fantastic films already made. Like Beauty and the Beast, Snow White, and Peter Pan. The reason why The Aristorcats is so high on my list is because of how funny the film is. I hate to say this, but I don't blame Edgar for what he does. I probably would've had them taken care of too.

We saw La Spettatrice last night @ the Chicago International Film Festival & we were both immensely moved by it . The powerful and relatable film focused on the story of family loss, but within its confines addressed timely issues such as oppression and freedom. In contrast to the sad narrative, there were glimpses of hope in certain scenes throughout the movie, hinting at healing, newfound bonds, and faith in people. These moments gave us both an appreciation for the range of human emotions. We would definitely recommend this film to everyone interested in an emotionally driven film that can’t help but draw out different reactions within its audience.

My friends and went through a period of time when we would rent movies that none of us had ever heard of. The only good that came from it was this movie, "Take it to Limit" Right as the movie started, we could tell we were in for a true classic. The music is probably done by rural white boys from Colorado, but it sounds just like early 90's rap. The star of the show, actor Leo Fitzpatrick, plays the bad-boy so well, especially sporting a big zit the entire movie.

Great show! About time a reality TV show comes along that closes generation gaps. Contestants range in ages, some seem old enough to have watched the movie when it first came out. And others, looked so young that perhaps parents or teachers handed down the movie hoping it would touch their lives the way it once touch them. Grease has truly become an American icon. Grease is a fun and entertaining movie in which the young and old can relate to. "You're The One That We Want" is sure to gain even more Grease followers.

I'm not a massive Disney fan, but my 7 year old son is starting to get into them, so we've built up quite a collection, and this is one of my favourites. We first saw this a couple of weeks ago and we must have see it half a dozen times since! OK, as others have pointed out, not the most complex or inventive of plots, but there's more to a film than that.Great characters, Phil Harris stealing the show as Thomas O'Malley, but Edgar the butler not far behind.

In Nordestina , a village in the middle of nowhere in Pernambuco , Antônio ( Gustavo Falcão ) is the  perfect representative of its population

Antônio loves living a quiet life away from the big cities, with family, friends and the closest connections. His opinion is respected and although he is proud of his birthplace, he's still in love with tradition and local beliefs. To Antônio, Nordestina is his oasis. There he can laugh, fish and simply savor his good days. He loves his neighborhood, and nothing would change that. Life seems so effortless, like floating in the sunshine.

This film as it is now is far shorter than it was when released in 1918. In fact, it is now more available with two other medium sized silent Chaplin features (A DOG'S LIFE, and THE PILGRIM) that Chaplin re-released in the 1950s. In it's day SHOULDER ARMS was a big hit because of it's humor in uniform approach. It still is very funny (Chaplin in disguise as a tree, spying on the Germans, is so ridiculous it's hysterical), but it suffers from being set in it's own age.

This was one of the worst Columbo episodes that I have seen , However , I am only in the  fourth episode so 

Despite this episode being so awful, I'm excited to see where the next episodes take me. Perhaps, the following will redeem the show in my opinion. I look forward to the clever, unassuming detective emerging on my TV. I can only imagine how Columbo's engaging persona and infamous "Ahhh..." will gradually persuade the viewer as he relentlessly drives toward uncovering the criminal. I imagine with growing enthusiasm how captivating the dialogue and plot will become.

When I saw this movie i expected it to be a cheesy American movie done on the cheap with appalling actors. I was really surprised to find that i was totally wrong. The movie centres around Bartely or B who has been rejected from all of his colleges- the actor who play B is very natural and makes his character seem real- and decides to create a pretend school so his parents stop harassing him. However loads of people see his fake website and join. Feeling their sorrows B can't turn them away much to the chagrin of his best mate.

If you like who-dun-its , you will like this film , considered the best Italian detective story ( giallo )  ever made. Directed by the brilliant and enigmatic Dario Argento , Suspiria stars young actress Suzy Banion as she is drawn into a web of nightmarish evil centered around the decadent Markos Dance Academy in Freiburg , Germany. Despite its underlying horror, Suspiria features stunning visual displays of color and lights, woven together with impeccable shot composition and devilish camerawork. Unlike many of the cliché giallos of the time, this film set the standard with respect to art direction and musical score.

I saw this today with little background on what to expect of the storyline. I go to the movies as an escape, to leave everything behind and enjoy a "story". I found this to be a good movie, not great, but good. It was worth my money and my tears :)Diane Lane was wonderful as always, Richard Gere isn't an over-actor. He held his own and has a certain presence that we always come to expect. He brings his own style to the movie.I think it was the kind of love story that doesn't always get told.

Always enjoyed "DOA",1950,which starred Edmond O'Brien and was very curious about this film. Dennis Quaid,(Dexter Cornell), was a professor who loved his wife and finally found out she was having an affair with one of his students. Dexter gets involved with Meg Ryan(Sydney Fuller), who was a student in his college class and at the same time had a big crush on him and wound up having a one night stand and in some ways loved him deeply. Dexter learns that he received a drink which had bad contents and would cause him a great deal of health problems!

As the mom of a 3 year old and a 2 year old, I adore AristoCats. It is a movie that contains no double-entendres, no almost-swear words like heck or darn, no parents who are functional idiots, and no crotch-smashing or flatulence jokes that are so prevalent in even the "best" kids movies these days. The story line is sweet and interesting. The music is great. The love story is quite romantic. The kittens are adorable, and the various other characters are unique and attention-capturing. The action is simple and not overwhelming or confusing.

Based on a William Faulkner short story , Two Soldiers is a top notch short film , a movie that  incorporates the hallmarks of a deep and classic text. The film preserves the original story’s eloquent word choice, hard hitting conflicts, and much of the inherent emotions present in the novella. More than that, the characters are given real weight by tremendous performances from Nathan Corwin and Stewart Abbotts as the titular soldiers, Calap and Pete. This masterpiece adaptation dutifully conveys the loneliness, brutality, and unavoidable cost of the war and does the Faulkner tale justice.

I never thought I 'd say this about a biopic , but there is a near over-abundance of characterization ( amid a flimsy plot ) that sometimes can overpower this piece. Although there are periods where things stagnate , the combination of swift cutting and fly-on-the-wall style helps keep everything flowing . All of the diverse subplots fold in together well in order to properly sustain the vibrancy of the presentation . At times , some sections dip in order to prove a point that needn’t have been in play to begin with. On the whole, however , this is an exceptionally refined narrative despite its diversified structuring .

This show really is the Broadway American Idol. It has singing, the British Guy, A guy who's sometimes nice, and a super-nice woman.Of course it is different because there is a sing-off, and there's dancing and some acting (we just don't see some of the acting). I gave this show a 7 because there are a couple tweaks that I know a lot of people (including me)would make if they were working for the show. The first thing that really needs to be changed is the judges deciding who goes home.

Do you liked `` Dead Man do n't wear Plaid '' ? What about `` Top Secret '' and ``  Real Genius''? Yes, I really enjoyed both "Dead Man don't Wear Plaid" and "Top Secret". While both movies had plenty of comedic moments, "Real Genius" was far more outrageous than both and I found it highly entertaining. Another one of my favorites is the original version of "Mr. Mom", which follows Jack Donner as a father, who after losing his job, takes on the challenge of running the household, with hilarious results.

( Synopsis ) Graduating high school senior Bartleby `` B '' Gaines ( Justin Long ) finds himself without a  job or prospect. But that soon changes when he gets recruited by promising but life-torn  tennis player Laramee Fields ( Rob Corddry ) to create a 3-person tennis team and compete for a chance to join the biggest university-level tournament of the year. With their skill and wit, Bartleby and his newfound teammates Miles Daly ( Josh Hutcherson ) and Jun Esakoi ( Kristina Cohen ) set off for college in Las Vegas for their chance of glory.

Years ago when I first read John Irving 's The World According to Garp , I was astounded that most  of it read like a fable. Reading on I felt swept into the magical realism woven by his powerful use of the storyteller's techniques. Whether or not Garp would prevail I was to discover further in and was amused to find myself oddly and surprisingly invested in this complex character, very unlike anyone I have met in reality. The writing alone captures a panorama of darkness and light that take on human life even within fiction.

For all those people who believe the dialog is worth something, and who appreciate a farce that is clever enough for you to take it seriously, this movie will surprise you. It is not a 'whodunit' for people who can't aren't able to follow the verbal exchange of our hero, Professor Dexter Cornell (Dennis Quaid).Cornell teaches in Southern California, near the tar pits. He has not published a novel in four years, his wife is divorcing him, he drinks a bit much, and is blessed or cursed with caustic wit, which he freely dispenses to his students.

William Faulkner was one of the American writers to win the Nobel Prize in literature . Faulkner mostly wrote about  Southern USA with stories depicting suffering people, broken promises and falling dreams. He focused much on the demise of Southern morality which changed the landscapes of that part of the US. His works included short stories, dramas and even poetry that created a highly honest account of a divided nation post civil war. The sensitivity, vividness, depth and range of Faulkner’s works stirred his audience towards exploring pressing social and historical issues that evoked spiritual beauty and defined courage.

I do n't care what some of the reviews said , this movie was funny . The thing with this  genre is you really don't have to think about the content of it and this movie hits just that for sure ! I have not seen such fresh and amusing gags for quite a long time, especially coming from this type of comedy. The actors are all skilled in their respective crafts and have done an impeccable job with making the gags play out funny. What is so commendable is that even if this movie is funny throughout the runtime, it never loses its comedic flair even if it approaches end game.

When the new Outer Limits first started , the episodes were quite optimistic and challenging . As the series began  to dig deeper into alien worlds and speculation, 

It quickly transformed into a cult favorite. One of the unique elements that made The Outer Limits stand out from other science fiction shows is its blend of optimistic and adventurous storytelling and harsh introspection. The plots often included subjects such as poverty, climate change and apocalyptic possibilities, forcing viewers to come to terms with some very tough realities. As the series progressed, it pushed more into existential and philosophical questioning.

This searing drama based on a true incident concerns several ambitious African nationals who decide to temporarily leave their families by stowing away on an outbound ship. They think that if they successfully make the voyage they can better their lives by making enough money in New York to send for their families. Unfortunately for them, the ship that they select is a rundown Russian freighter which has already been heavily fined at a previous port for harboring stowaways. The captain and the first mate are determined not to let this happen again as their jobs are on the line.

NIGHTS IN RODANTHE brings back to the screen two talented actors in Diane Lane and Richard Gere in a simply beautiful story of a man and a woman hungry for something more in their lives than they have at present. The chemistry between Lane and Gere is magical from the first scene in the film to their last embrace. The locations, beauty of their attraction for one another when it unfolds when they first meet, and the story that follows, and as they begin to know each other with the attraction they feel towards each other is real, is romance that is projected to an audience with tender care.

NIGHTS IN RODANTHE brings back to the screen two talented actors in Diane Lane and Richard Gere in a simply  romantic drama that many viewers could watch again and again. Set on the coastline of North Carolina, Diane and Richard experience a unique connection. During a very passionate time, when away from their daily life troubles and commitments, a sweet attraction grows between them and they explore their complex relationship while they develop into something unforgettable. Ultimately, with Gere's pleasing charm and Lane's grace, their togetherness is everlasting even though they live in separate worlds, hundreds of miles apart.

What I enjoyed most in this film was the scenery of Corfu , being Greek I adore my country and  watching

Seeing my beautiful island of Corfu through the film lens gave me a deep sense of connection and peace. Although the film made some modern interventions to the legendary tale, I still had the feel that I was rediscovering part of our Greek heritage. Everything had its magical spot, and even though it might be because I'm a Greek, there were moments that I held back tears. Corfu may be home for some and for me is truly like traveling into the gates of heaven.

To experience Head you really need to understand where the Monkees were when they filmed it.This was as their series was coming to a close and the group was near break up. Their inventive and comedic series (sort of an American Idol of their day) took four unknown actors and formed a manufactured supergroup around them.This is their take on their "manufactured image" and status as the 2nd tier Beatles. They always felt they were in a box, trapped, and unable to find credibility despite their talents.It is also a hell of a musical-trippy, inventive (I have the soundtrack) and full of surprises.See it with an open mind.

I've heard a lot of different opinions about this film and then to find out that Paris Hilton was in it as well didn't give Me the best impression of the film .... then to be dragged to the cinema by a group of my friends and sit there expecting a pile of pants i was shocked to find that i was scared stiff all the way through the film ... it was predictable yes but the build up of the deaths and the whole atmosphere of the film made it REALLY scary for me ... i was watching through my fingers the whole way through.

"Nuovomondo" was a great experience. Many filmmakers tell their stories to a big extent via dialogue. Emanuele Crialese directs his film very visually driven. For everything he wants to tell, he finds powerful images that are able to stand for themselves. Thus, he understands film as a medium that primarily tells its stories over the pictures on screen. Particularly European cinema is often very dialogue-driven (and many of the young US-American directors are strongly influenced by that). Crialese's opposite attitude was really the point, that made this film special for me.

`` A Slight Case of Murder '' is an excellent TV movie , which is defiantly worth the price of  rental. It has amazing acting by Eddie Bracken as well as fantastic direction by Lloyd Bacon, combined with great editing. The film stands on its own today due to its elements and comedic tone, something one will not often find in old movies. Eddie Bracken stars as Tom Brian, a hustler on the edge of alcoholism and public indecency. The comedy allows him to emerge with comedy while delivering his tale of degradation and underhanded manipulation, much to the enjoyment of the viewer.

In an early scene, Luca (David Pasquesi) and James (Jeff Garlin) are walking down a neighborhood street in Chicago, admiring the bucolic architecture, when a woman, angrily arguing in French on a cell phone, passes by them, prompting James to remark, "There's nothing hotter than an angry French woman." A few blocks later, they pass an old Filipino woman, also angry, also arguing on a cell phone, and Luca remarks, for referential effect, "There's nothing hotter than an angry, elderly Filipino woman.

inspite of many movies dealing with great artists or a genius , chihaweseon pointed out the real dilemma in which  artists , highly misunderstood

Chihaweseon not only gives the audience an insight into a different culture through its representation of Seon Ho’s works, but its wider point speaks to something anyone living with a certain type of social or creative pressure can relate to: even if they express themselves deeply and unguardedly through their creations, they cannot communicate their feelings in return to the world. While their works become classics, their spirits slowly sink, mired in endless problems arising from misunderstandings of their personalities.

Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character, unable to speak, living in a world incompatible with modern life. He trusts to his homemade weaponry - helmet, sleeves, and spear - made out of hubcaps, seat cushions, and discarded office furniture. Just as Don Quixote rode Rocicante, "The Man" rides his contraption (literally) transcending the lost lives caught up the harsh and demeaning modern world - soaring above the earth, away from the plight of modern man. Both characters ride in search of adventure in an effort to right the wrongs of the world.

i love this film!! maybe it is my generation but i can really connect with what he is talking about and means to do. it kept me laughing for the duration. duration of the film, the next day, and beyond. i think this film is not one to watch if you mainly care about the plot and character development. this film is pretty much only for the generation that will understand it. there are lots of things you just know being brought up in that generation that you wouldn't if you were say 40. i think Sacha barren Cohen was Very and i do mean Very good.

Oh my word!! I have never seen a film so lacking in any kind of moral judgement or consideration for anything other than the death of the scum! Michael Winner here makes a valid observation of human desires in displaying a gung-ho troth world of deep and damaged execution. Not only does he spoon feed us with utter hell on earth seen through the face of the moustached Bronson, but he also shows us the spoon he's feeding us with and says "look at what your watching now look at your self and ask the question: Are you enjoying this?"

When the trailer for Accepted first came up, many people began to get excited about seeing it... really excited. Who could blame them, it looked like fun. But that's exactly the thing. People went into Accepted looking for a good movie, but if you think about it, Accepted isn't the type of film destined to be a good movie. It's meant to be a film that pleases its crowd without too much effort being given. That being said, for those of you who expected a great film, you need to think about what could be made of a comedy like this one.

While I agree that this movie lacks any real substance and should not be taken seriously, its primarily directed to fans of the series who are looking for a quick fix. Bronson (Paul Kersey)once again takes to the streets (given a license to kill by the chief police no less) and moves into his friends apartment (who you guessed it) was killed by a street gang that has taken control of the neighborhood (which looks like Beruit). It's funny that people who associate with Bronson have a habit of getting killed.

This movie is true action at its finest, It doesn't get any better then this. This is one of those movies that you can just kick back and watch some real good non stop shooting and killing plus there are some excellent lines to go along with all of this. My favorite is there is a one bad guy who is breaking into this old couples home and he is stealing a TV or something and he goes right up to them and yells "I will come in here anytime i like!!!" and right before he jumps out the window he yells "Anytime!!!"

The cinema of the 60s was as much as time of revolution as the politics and the music. Filmmakers were daring to make avant-garde films discussing taboo subjects only permitted before in exploitation films. Starting with both "Breathless" and underground American cinema (such as Kenneth Anger), films became more and more experimental. All of this accumulated when Hollywood realized they had mass commercial appeal with "Easy Rider". One of the best (and most surprising) outputs of this era was also one of the least successful initially.

Emily Watson and Tom Wilkinson together - what a treat! With Rupert Everett and Linda Bassett rounding off the supporting roles to the foursome of lies and intrigue. Yet at the heart of it all, each character maintains a streak of decency - moral conscience held up in spite of obvious contradictions. "Contradictions are the source of all movement and of all life." How true these words are. Watson's Anne Manning is at the core of this intrigue - she's the central conscience that the other three latched on. She is the decency undeterred.

I remember this film of old . It 's a great , chilling , atmospheric horror picture about a man  and a mysterious woman . It was said that she haunted his life. People believe she was a witch, who had put a deadly spell on him. To this day I am still mystified about who she was and why the man in the movie was haunted. There have been various explanations offered, ranging from divine judgment to a hoax. Some claim that the mystery woman was really a spirit from the afterlife that came to punish the man for past transgressions.

I saw this movie on it 's opening night , and enjoyed it . I probably would have enjoyed it  even more had I not known how the story ended beforehand

Regardless, I still really liked the film and I was really impressed with the director's technique of jumping around in time to add suspense. It was fascinating to watch and I could tell the audience was just as on the edge of their seat as I was, due to the gasps, sighs and some cheers as scenes hit familiar landmarks throughout the movie. It made the experience quite fun and memorable.

The Buddy Holly Story opens on a shot of a yellow neon moon on the roof of a roller rink  in Lubbock, Texas. At the center of the rink stands a nineteen-year-old Buddy Holly playing his famous six-string electric guitar. The evening erupts into song as kids, drawn in by Holly's amazing showmanship and wonderful music, fall into a sweeping fever-pitched chorus of all of his popular songs. The emotion, energy and electric musical appeal enthralled a young and yet unknowing crowd into the highest praise they could possibly give the artist.

I saw this film at the Seattle International Film Festival in a full house of avid movie buffs and Indian  expats. The feeling in the audience was contagious and the energy radiating off them heightened with every shot of the screen. Everyone erupted in joy at all the different musicals and started crying at all the deep human moments presented. Everyone laughed and cheered at the complex metaphors present throughout. People couldn’t help themselves as the deep content and visuals presented weaved a cohesive message that moved us all. It truly made us feel connected to this story, something even I didn’t expect.

It reaches the minds and feelings of everyone driving them deep in the black desert. A brutal but beautiful world that is explored through memories and edgy layers of sound and score. The landscape develops its own persona, paralleling the inner geography of all three characters as their stories unfold. The stark void of lost love, the fear of the unknown, and then transcendence of emptiness through the very openness of this desolation. Three misguided souls fighting to find something absolute and positive in all that negative space. The drama is compelling. James Franco and his co-stars deliver deft performances.

Accepted is one of the best teenage comedies I have seen in a long time. It has an original script, talented cast and it delivers an hour and a half of pure unadulterated fun.It tells the story of a high school graduate Bartleby "B" Gains (Justin Long) who is not accepted in any of the collages he applied to, so to avoid his parents' disappointment he creates a fictional collage. In the attempt to fool his parents completely he creates a fake website and turns an old psychiatric hospital into a school.

Very touching film , a great surprise to come up from Brazil , a country that usually exports features about  happy lifestyle and festivals

This time they delivered a strong story with deep emotional vibrations, turning from comedy to melodrama through comedy . Despite the difference in emotional register , what continues is the country’s contagious and empowering spirit as conveyed through characters ’ embrace of moments, defiance in hard times, but most importantly showing us a positive attitude regardless of the conditions we find ourselves. Even when poverty is hard to bear , hope makes a difference and such idea is skillfully captured and linked together in this bittersweet story.

The Ali G show was really something amazing - he was so stupid wannabe rapper , but no one he  interacted with realized

The brilliance of the show lay in how Ali G played so effortlessly on other people's misconceptions and how some of the most powerful, self important individuals on the planet couldn't bring themselves to show his foolishness. Ali G succeeded at outsmarting some of the top authorities in various fields by spinning sophisticated concepts with comedic intonation. Although people knew the show was just satire, most became convinced in that moment that Ali G was truly remarkable and astoundingly ignorant simultaneously.

Dr. Paul Flanner (Richard Gere), a successful surgeon, has his wife leave him, his son (an uncredited James Franco) not respect him and looses a patient he's operating on. Adrienne Willis (Diane Lane) has two children and discovers her husband has cheated on her. They both need to get away. She watches over a beautiful oceanside inn in Rodanthe at the same time he books a room. They're all alone together. You can pretty much figure out the rest.This is what's known as a weepie or a woman's film.

I taped The Morrison Murders on Lifetime Movie network and I watched The Morrison Murders on Lifetime , Lifetime Movie  network. The movie captivated me and made me addicted to solving real life murders. Since then, I've watched a variety of true crime documentaries and have always thought I had the answer that the cops couldn't figure out. But I'd often reach the conclusion of each episode without a solid answer or solution. While this can be incredibly frustrating, the puzzle of solving real-life cases has always drawn me in.

Ross Hunter's musical remake of the 1937 fantasy, based on James Hilton's enduring bestseller, was written off by critics and audiences almost immediately in 1973, sounding off a backlash against musicals in general that gave the genre a bad reputation in Hollywood for years. Group of disparate British and American individuals end up on an emergency flight out of a war-torn Asian country, but their plane is hijacked and crashes in a snowy mountain terrain; a rescue party arrives and leads the group to an isolated community called Shangri-La, where the sun is always shining and most of the residents are youthful and blissfully content.

No , I have not seen the original series and I wo n't compare the two if I had . I believe that sequels often find it hard to match up to the originals and they often receive criticisms because of this. Nevertheless, they offer different perspective and are made in their own right to give viewers a sense of a familiar but different product. Thus, although I have not seen the original series, I won't necessarily compare the two, because I want to remain unbiased and assess it as its own independent entity. After all, to each their own in terms of taste.

My favorite show of all time! Yeah, I thought this was so cool, and Larisa Oleynik was the first crush I ever had (AAAAWWWWWW). It was well written, funny-except when it it wanted to be serious, and just a great show overall. But since we couldn't afford to keep Nick, I couldn't see any episodes after Feb. 1996, and maybe that makes me think more of the show than I should. To me it's more the epidemy (now that doesn't look spelled right!)

This was the greatest movie I have ever seen in my life, the action was great, and i was so scared, there was a lot of gore WHICH MADE It GREAT, i would see it 1,000 more times, and Paris Hilton, D*MN she fine in that movie. But anyway, i would recommend it to anybody, even kids(like me) Adults like it to. You would probably have nightmares at night though, but beside that, IT IS AWESOMe, I CANT STOP BRAGGING ABOUT IT.

I think it definitely is. The writing is of such a quality that beginner students of the English language should model their conversations after its dialogue. For example, the exchange between Paul Kersey(Bronson) and Ms. Kathryn Davis(Deborah Raffin) (more about this character later) is extremely clear and to the point: Ms. Davis says, "I hope you like chicken. It's the only thing I know how to make," to which Kersey deftly responds, "Chicken's good. I like chicken."

The movie has taken a little flack for playing fast and loose with the facts. But it will put you close to being in a time and place that no longer exist by getting to the *feeling*.As Keith Richards remarks in Paul McCartney's movie about Holly, there's some Buddy Holly in almost all rock made since his day. The tragedy that took him is dealt with gently, and the rest of the movie recreates the joy of a great music career and a joyful body of music.Gary Busey does a remarkable, energetic portrayal of Holly, and his performances hint that he really gets into the music.

If you get a chance to get a hold of this lost (for many years) gem, I doubt you will be disappointed. PS has an odd blend of social satire and ultra-cool blaxploitation-- even hints of slapstick, but it's so odd that it was not only ahead of it's time, nothing has been seen like it since.I strongly disagree with people who say that the film is dated, especially with Spike Lee's "Bamboozaled" (SP?) a few years back which was a misfire of trying to capture the same message. (Good filmmaking, disjointed script.

The A-team is still repeating every day on Dutch television ( RTL7 , around 1800hrs ) and I still watch  the episodes regularly. The show focuses on a highly decorated Special Forces operator, Hannibal, along with a multinational group of expert tacticians including Murdock and Face, who create clever plans and crack difficult problems to make a little wrong, right. The episodes still hold me in awe with the unlikely ingenuity, tough reality and mostly resolution that revolves around friendship. Though I must confess, my personal favourites always been Murdock and his intelloligence.

The movie has taken a little flack for playing fast and loose with the facts . But it will put  people back in the classrooms so that real history will be known by them 

That’s exactly the message behind the movie and its subject, our current day generation - that we should learn from the lessons of history to ensure our collective future. Without learning these hard earned lessons, and potentially ignoring key parts of our past, it will only be to our detriment. To ensure these are remembered and seen clearly, filmmakers have endeavoured to interpret a snapshot of what can otherwise be viewed as complex topics and time periods.

I just can't understand why people are surprised this movie makes no sense. It was never supposed to make sense. (Duh! The writers were completely wasted on Frodis at the time.) It was just supposed to entertain and mock, and it does both wonderfully.The Monkees are good actors. They wouldn't have been hired if they weren't good actors. Mike has a thing for deadpan and darkness, Micky is the best at sheer psychotic comedy, Davy is a Broadway veteran, and Peter actually had people believing he was that dumb in real life.

Surprisingly effective British drama about two very different people who find common ground, and in particular the "flowering" of one of them. An embittered, "Spike"-type youth (McAvoy) with Deuchennes MD is placed in a home for the disabled and quickly makes friends with a youth (Robertson) with cerebral palsy. Robertson has never known anything outside of the home, but McAvoy has and he is bound and determined to get back into the real world. Together, they manage to do just that in this funny and heartwarming and often heartbreaking tale of inner strength overcoming physical shortcomings.

by TyNesha Mells . In this drama , Ja Rule , who stars as Reggie , struggles with the loss  of his child's mother. He battles inner demons such as revenge and animosity as his quest for vengeance pushes him away from his only daughter. His actions ultimately results in a heartbreaking spiral that reverberates throughout the streets. In a surprise move , Reggie realizes he must find the strength to do something he never has before, the very thing his former foe achieved and never received - forgive. In the most devastating moment, Reggie makes the ultimate act of sacrifice and we are forever moved.

Just as in `` Columbo '' we see the fatality occur right at the beginning . What follows is an  even better narrative of why. It starts with detective Lieutenant Columbo collecting all the tiny pieces of evidence that never made sense together in the investigation of a seemingly-perfect murder case. One of Columbo's quirks is his interrogation and admiration of suspects, which makes his 'show-down moment' that much more intriguing. This culminates with an unforgettable criminal confession. For every Columbo fan, it's the scene that gives us that delightful and rewarding "ah ha!" moment every single time.

It reaches the minds and feelings of everyone driving them deep in the black desert . A brutal but beautiful  display

Every minute detail like the sparkling of stars, is taken in as part of a symphony playing with your mind and soul. You see every constellation shining as one when it all comes together. In spite of the sombre aura that can linger throughout the black desert, one can still appreciate the ethereal beauty. A love-hate kind of romance arises. You still ache in love and worry about the coldness of it all at the same time.

I thought that the storyline came into place very well. I liked this movie a lot. If you're going to rag on a Bridget Fonda movie, you can just rot. I thought that ragging on movie stars was a bad idea. Apparently somebody doesn't think so. I rather enjoyed the movie. I'm even thinking of buying it. I want it to be my very first DVD for my room. That's how much I like it. I rather would not start an online argument with someone I don't know & have it be over a movie.

This movie is a love story set in the backdrop of war. Everything about the movie was perfect. I just saw the movie yesterday and I want to get my own DVD asap and watch it many times over. The story ends as it started I was very happy that he came back and I was proud of her for becoming a doctor and fulfilling her father's dream. She honored her father, boyfriend-husband, and her lover. The character had many shades. Christian Bale is also an phenomenal actor. Some stories do have happy endings.

I admit to being in awe of the Sea and have spent a number of years in the Navy ,  a bond had formed

Having the fortune to spend my time in the Naval life I had gained an in-depth perspective of the immeasurable sea life and power, such an unrelenting form of tranquility and elegance despite its erratic presence had an intoxicating feel. Its inviting appeal truly rejuvenated my faith and moved me to stop and stare during most moments. There were even a few memorable days in the spring when rain just halted and the sea silently blossomed.

Gary Busey 's best performance in a nicely-flowing biography . Since had a musical background , he was able to  convince audience when starred as Sonny Crocket , in films, such as Point Break and Life Cycles. Apart from acting, Busey had the interest for motorsports, eventually taking part in 2003 Bullrun Rally across United States, and 2003 Paris-Beijing rally. Other endeavors include restaurant ventures and painting which he started since 2013 and exhibited since 2016 respectively. One notable achievement includes receiving the last Platinum Schimdt Memorial Award in 2008 for significant achievement and extraordinary life with Humanitarianistic ideals.

OK , so this film may not have won any Oscars , but it is not a bad film . It has a great script and well developed characters that keeps the audience hooked from start to finish. The editing is tight and precise. Although some have complained about the soundtrack, the actors’ performances manage to carry the film well, showing their intense emotion and bringing the viewer in for a roller coaster ride. The climax and resolution make this a great story-telling journey. All-in-all, this is an underrated but amazing film that manages to stand tall amongst bigger-budgeted and mainstream projects.

I just saw this film and I recommend it. It has a very good plot, it holds your complete attention, the acting is superb, Tom Wilkinson was fantastic and Emily Watson was also very good. A very good film indeed, about great and unconditional love. Tom Wilkinson's character is a man who is not prepared for the ordeal that is about to begin, but he takes the matter in hand as the story progresses, and this great actor gives a performance that makes you feel the character's anguish and suffering.

`` Hari om '' is an Indian greeting and the compelling title character of the film bearing this same name . Hari Om is the inspirational journey of a blind young man fighting poverty and prevailing over adversity with an ironclad faith in his guru and undying determination. During the film, the young man undergoes harsh trials and makes difficult sacrifices, until ultimately being rewarded with good fortune and lasting inner peace. Every step in his quest becomes a great life lesson to learn, and offers heartfelt inspiration to viewers who watch with reverence and admiration.

This film , winning Im Kwon-Taek the Best Director at Cannes in 2002 ( tied with P.T . Anderson for  Punch-Drunk Love). This earned the highly acclaimed director an immediate well-deserved distinction and established Im's claim to "Lee Sangsoo-isms" - shots of windows, cellars and ghosts recurring in almost all his films- while expanding their narrative structures to accommodate films using motion and diverse composition that demand active rather than passive viewers. With time, it became a new epic to frame this and others of his films – subtitled versions including "Two Mariners and Magic Sea".

`` Nuovomondo '' was a great experience . Many filmmakers tell their stories to a big extent via dialogue . But this film had an effective approach with very minimal dialogue, telling its story mainly through camera angle, silence and powerful sound design. It depicted Italy of 1906 in beautiful frames while many socio-economic and ethical issues of the time period were nicely used. Through powerful visual storytelling techniques and structure, "Nuovomondo" created something deeply engaging. There are also a few poignant humanist moments present here and there throughout the film which appeal to the universal moral fibre.

Wow, What a wonderful film-making! Mr. Im has done it, again!His last work, ChunHayang (2000) was a great film, but this one is even greater. Selected as an official feature film in the Canne Festival for the second time in a two-year row, this 66 years old director is getting better and better at what he is making of with a Korean culture.Simply, Chihwaseon is about a great Korean painter, '(Ohwon) JANG, Seung-Up' who was considered as a prodigy in the late Nineteenth century.

The young John Garfield turned in a fine performance in the 1939 "They Made Me a Criminal." Celebrating a ring victory in a jammed locker room, boxer Johnnie Bradfield emotes about his love of mom, rejection of booze and clean living style to fans, including cops, who eat it up. Later in the evening he's plowed and tussling with his bimbo gal while his manager, in on the con, shares the evening. And the whiskey.A problem develops when another couple arrives. The guy is a newspaper reporter and he says he'll expose Bradfield's phony life on the front page.

I watch the show every day and it is very entertaining. It provides updates of tech news, video games pretty much everything geek. They are also the official broadcasters of E3 and Comiccon. If you are a geek, gamers or anything really, you will enjoy this show. They have definitely upped their game since the guy below me's review (2006). It's the only place that I get my tech info. Kevin Pereira and Olivia Munn work beautifully with each other and the show always has segments referring to things in the game, movie, comic... Universe.

I do not think that this movie deserves the low rating that most will give it . It 's one  of those special kinds of movies that give you time to think after watching it. Despite the slightly underdeveloped plot, the underlying messages and idea have merit, making this movie valuable. As with any great film, each individual viewer interprets and digests their own message. I think that this movie can remind each of us, not only of our daily human weaknesses, but also the capacity to not just withstand difficulties and realities, but also ultimately a deeper appreciation of love.

Fantastic Chaplin movie with many memorable moments as Charlie joins the army to fight in WW 1.At first he goes  off to enlist confidently but realizes war is not all as fun and glamorous as he expected when his friends begin to die.He quickly goes from pride to terror and is terrified by the reality of battle, even accidentally killing an officer in fear.His comedic battle with a plane mid-flight still makes audience erupt in laughter despite the darkness surrounding him.His attitude is shaken to his core when an aerial explosion drives him over the brink and Charlie only starts to face up to the power of terror unleashed.

Always enjoyed `` DOA '' ,1950 , which starred Edmond O'Brien and was very curious about this film . Dennis  O'Keefe did some directing and was uncredited . After a little digging, I learned that Ida Lupino and Barry Sullivan also star in this film. I was shocked by their participation. As far as I could find, the plot follows a deadly secret discovered by two young Canadian pilots whose small airplane crashes on the way back to their bases. However, I found out that Edmond O'Brien plays an undercover agent who uncovers international conspiracy! It has all the ingredients to make a very exciting film.

Who could have thought a non-disabled actor could act so realistically and immensely powerfully as a disabled person in a  single show? It was thought provoking to watch and gave so much insight into what its like living with a disability and living with diversity. Even those without disabilities, could take the message of appreciation for diversity that the show gives. Furthermore, this show shed light on various factors like patience, endurance, acceptance, encouragement and above all strong perseverance. All these can empower and make it easier for one to live harmoniously with a disability.

Chaplin enters the trenches of WWI in this spirited comedy that never belittles the horrors of war. The rain, the mud, the explosions - all these things are present but Chaplin seems strangely oblivious to them all. He's in France for one thing: to fight the Germans, something he does with unbelievable success.It almost seems like an extended ego trip for Chaplin - a very funny one, at that - until the final minute when it rises to a new level of poignancy and everything makes sense.Perhaps it's what all soldiers dream of before the go to war.

A Formula For Murder isn't a well known Giallo, but that isn't to say it's not a very good one! The film is directed by Alberto De Martino, the man behind cult classics such as The Antichrist and Blazing Magnums. The film was released late on in the Giallo cycle, but more than stands up to many of the films released around the 'golden' period in the early seventies. Despite a lack of logic in some areas, the film works mainly due to the competent way it mixes Argento style death scenes with some genuinely surprising plot twists, and a host of well defined characters.

Right this may be the wine talking but this could be the best movie I 've seen in a very  long time

I could go on and on, raving about this movie to anyone who will listen. My friends were blown away by how impactful the story was and the way it was executed. Although I am biased since I'm a huge fan of this director's work, I must say that he outdid himself with this one. Everything just meshed together and even small details, such as the captivating musical score, complimented the powerful visuals perfectly.

First of all, around the time I wrote this comment, I had already read what kittiwake-1 had written about this game and was confused. This is a video game and not an actual movie. I mean, I myself would choose a good Deniro movie or playing a video game any day. But, dude, what are you talking about? Now that I have that out of the way, let's move on, shall we? The video game adaption of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is, as you may have guessed, based on the movie of the same name.

The show start out with the boat . Desmond was i it . Then they went to try to save  everyone in the dock

They sailed their boat to the docks, but time was running out. The pressure of the situation made things tense. When they finally arrived they started their rescue mission, hurrying against the clock to save everyone in the dock. It wasn't easy and no one could know what could happen. Then just as the clock hit zero the crew manage to safe the last life, although barely on time, the tension ran high.

It 's Showtime ! Showtime is simply a bump in Eddie Murphy and Robert DeNiro 's careers . It 's  an entertaining movie filled with many gags, comedies, one liners and silly moments. The action scenes in Showtime were definitely interesting, as both Murphy and DeNiro acted out high-octane car chases and battle scenes. What I liked most, however, were the zany lines uttered between both actors and even the outrageous behavior they displayed while executing scenes. This collaboration was successful with two of the biggest stars in the movie industry performing their usual trade-mark antics on the screen, guaranteed to have the viewers laughing away.

James Franco is totally cool in this movie . Not just handsome and charismatic but genuinely open and vulnerable in  his performance as a wanna be Hollywood Director . Franco takes the audiences on a ride, through every highs and lows in this unpredictable career. Despite having a roller coaster ride of his own , his upbeat presence works to reinforce an optimistic message at the heart of the movie that while our work may never receive any big, resounding wins and riches in response - our spirits should never break nor the fact that ‘A STAR IS BORN’.

My impression, having seen this documentary, is that Nathaniel Kahn ended up with more questions than he had before he made the film. He took five years to make it, a labour of love and longing. I can only imagine the turmoil of the editing process, what to leave in, what to take out. His father, the renowned architect Louis Kahn,comes across as a man too selfish and self-absorbed to be emotionally available to even one wife not alone three. But like many men of his character, he attracted women who were spellbound by the remoteness and entranced by the creativity.

After seeing The Aristocats: Special Edition in a two pack with The Fox in the Hound, I decided to buy it since both of these films were childhood favourites.The Aristocats is a classic, definitely. It might not be a five-star classic, but it is a fun film and makes a good evening's entertainment. It is somewhat a light refreshment from the darker, more serious Disney classics. The Aristocats tries to be a light-hearted musical comedy, and I think it just about succeeds.The storyline doesn't really make much sense and I don't think the plot is particularly strong, but it is certainly not weak.

This is one of the best of the early "Star Trek" episodes, with Kirk and his crew venturing into the unknown to do battle with an enemy known only by name. Imagine their surprise when they find out that the dreaded Romulans are racial offshoots of the Vulcans! Young Mr. Stiles, well-played by Paul Comi, is one of the few truly unlikable characters in the "Star Trek" universe. His barely disguised hatred of Mr. Spock is eerily similar to the post-9/11 hatred and suspicion many Americans have of people of Arab or Middle Eastern origin.

I love this movie , though I do n't like how they picture Egyptians , being an Egyptian citizen myself 

Though I love this movie, as an Egyptian citizen, I'm disappointed in how they portrayed our culture and values. They brushed past the many detailed nuances and historical events that have impacted modern day Egyptian history and culture. What makes a movie powerful is the respect to which they dig deeper into the social issues of the region. When people experience something they wouldn't otherwise have seen without the movie, that leaves an impressionable mark, inspiring us to look past just the surface details.

Duchess and her three kittens are enjoying the high life with their devoted human mistress until the wicked butler Edgar  showed up one day

At first Edgar showed no animosity to Duchess or her kittens, often smiling when the adorable little family settled in together. As the months went on, though, Edgar became increasingly impatient, making harsh comments to Duchess's human mistress and often barking orders to keep Duchess and the kittens out of his way. Unwilling to tolerate this bullying any longer, the mistress moved to another house and made sure her loving pet family had everything they needed to remain safe and happy in their new environment.

Before I talk about the ending of this film I will talk about the plot . Some dude named Gerald  wanted to start fresh and move away. So he leaves his family and moves across the country, although he really feels lonely as soon as he lands in his new home. Soon enough, though, he finds solace in one of the friends he makes on a journey that eventually leads him into a web of crime and insanity. The struggles that Gerald experiences puts his idea of starting fresh on a challenging turn and Gerald becomes tangled in events far greater than he imagined.

Captain Corelli's Mandolin is one of Nicolas Cage's better films. He turns a fine performance as the title character. This is a romance set against the backdrop of a worn torn island. John Hurt's character gives his daughter, played beautifully by Penelope Cruz, some honest advice about love. This movie doesn't have the fault of being completely predictable. This movie also allows Cruz to turn in a performance as a strong woman who knows her own mind and heart. Once the film warms up beyond the opening sequence this film keep you focused on it.

Jack , Sawyer and Sayid swim to the boat and find a completely wasted Desmond . His traumatic past experience  forced him to burn down his shelter and there were hardly any survivals 

Sayid identifies that Desmond isn’t just some drifter on a solo boat but that he holds significant importance to the rest of their lives. Before long, the four men realize they all have a significant bond: they’re the sole survivors of Flight 815 crash on a desolate island, running away from their destinies.Desmond explains his travels around the world have given him key knowledge that may aid their understanding and help with getting off the island.

I did not know what to expect when I decided to watch this documentary. I knew it was about an ex-Viet Nam POW in Laos who escaped, but I didn't know much else. In reality, I wasn't expecting too much. Oh what a surprise! The story of this man's life is very interesting in itself, but what sets this film apart from other biography-type docs is that Dieter himself tells most of the story himself. Dieter is very comfortable in front of the camera. His personality really shines. He tells his story about his life growing up in Germany during WWII and the hardships.

this is a teen movie and while u watch it expect some nonsensical stuff added here and there but overall  the film doesn't miss its mark. Although some of the plot may seem irrational, the characters take you through an exciting and comical journey. With catchy music and amusing lines, this teen movie keeps you hooked as the film progress. There is also an important message in the film as it allows one to reflect and think on certain things. Ultimately, while it has its unrealistic moments, it tells an interesting story that anyone who watches can relate to.

What a shame this movie was never released . ( It is now playing on cable . ) I tuned  into a station the other day and the trailer was airing ! I quickly ordered the movie On Demand, just so I can watch it as soon as possible. Even though the trailer seemed too good to be true, it still is pretty close to what was being presented. With some heart-racing moments and several dark scenes, it manages to surprise me again and again. Overall, it looks like this movie has gone down in cult cinema for those that enjoyed the crazy storyline and badass action scenes.

I thought this movie was pretty good!OK, so maybe it had a few scenes that could make people think of other horror movies, but i have seen a lot more pathetic movies that got much higher ratings than this! Many movies nowadays are remade to a more modern version and there's nothing wrong with that, it keeps the story alive. i don't think this movie was pathetic at all and i'm not just saying that because i'm a major Chad Michael Murray fan, but because i enjoyed it.

Try to look for another movie that is such a trip without having a story or plot and you'll be hard-pressed. HEAD is a masterpiece of non-linear non-structure, surrealism and experimentaion. In less than 90 minutes, it manages to be not only a time-capsule of an era, but also a full-length experimental feature that defies time,space and convention in a way that only underground films of the sixties could.HEAD is a reflection of those films. No matter how one feels about the Monkees, this is a film every filmmaker should see because it cracks wide open the endless possibilities of film as an art medium.

Ah the Outer Limits. I love that show. It was surpremely creepy, or down-right mysterious. I loved all the genres of the show, from horror, to thriller to mystery, whatever the genre, it was good. I guess I must have started watching way after it got canceled, when Sci-fi showed it as re-runs, or played marathons of it. It was a really good show, I don't know all about the seasons and everything but I do remember that every time I saw the screen freak out and the voice on the TV say: "There is nothing wrong with your television.

I am a guy, so i was very hesitant to watch the movie because i know that Richard Gear likes to be in tear jerker movies. I would rather watch action/adventure/sci fi. I was right, the movie is definitely a tear jerker. Diane tended to over act a few times, as did richard, but they brought it around and made it work. The daughter was a suppressed teen with huge attitude, so you started out hating her. The movie is way too predictable, but for entertainment purposes, it was a masterpiece.

Being a middle aged mom myself, I very much appreciated seeing a romance between grown-up people that weaves in the many issues that effect us. Diane Lane beautifully portrays Adrienne and the sacrifice and conflict that a mother goes through, wanting to do what is right for her children, but still have a happy life herself. I am not a big Richard Gere fan, but he always does a good job with the guy who is sort of jerk, but learns something about himself.Criticism of their romance as unrealistic is hardly justified when compared to most other romantic movies.
