Well , I guess I was in the mood for a movie that really grabbed me from the beginning . So I ended up choosing something in the action/adventure genre that promised plenty of thrills and drama. When it came time to turn off the lights and press play, I was pretty pumped up with excitement. Even before I was 10 minutes in, the rollercoaster of excitement had been triggered and my full attention had been devoted to the story. The combination of storyline, directing, actors and effects had created an emotionally engaging spectacle.

To experience Head you really need to understand where the Monkees were when they filmed it.This was as their series  ended, but that didn't mean the end for their stardom. Despite many failures and mistakes along the way, the Monkees earned a fan base and admirers of their classic hit records that endures to this day. A number of websites dedicate to the history of their creation, or simply applaud the skill they mastered over their two and a half years on television. Nowadays, the three-album long opus HEAD offers an homage to their influence and knack of imbuing four young rockers’ DNA in great comedy.

Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade . She smokes and drinks . She does n't have a lot  of close friends . Jade is often judged by others who don't understand her unique identity. She seems isolated but enjoys nights out and trying out new places, although she'd never admit to it. Jenny Lewis plays Jade with charm and complexity. While at times her carefree attitude can be seen as an obstacle in life, she refuses to give into societal pressure, further inspiring the audiences watching. We see Jenny bring an underappreciated emotion of unapologetic self-love that only she can deliver.

This is a brilliant film. The story starts off in Romania,where Billy Crystal stars as an agent who can talk anybody into doing anything. There is a really funny scene here, where Crystal is a child, and talks his father, who is a rabbi into eating pork (you filmophiles may know that this is a parody of Crystal's religion). He is mainly a talent scout, and he's trying to find a suitable villain for his latest movie. After finding out that the whole film has a terrible crew, he accidently falls into a small river.

I just had the opportunity to see 'Nuovomondo' (hitherto known in the U.S. as 'The Golden Door'), and was very impressed by both it's dreamy & occasionally surreal tale of a family that immigrates from Sicially to the U.S. in the early days of the 20th century. It also worked as a (proverbial)middle finger jammed into the eyeball of Homeland Security (preferably all the way up to the 3rd knuckle),in it's depiction of the ill treatment of foreigners who just want a better life than they were getting from their original mother land.

The movie is incredible, it has a sound track which sets the tone for the movie. THe lines in the movie are great, such as "Nothings to good for out friends" and "Its collection time Charlie collection time." I can watch this movie over and over again and still laugh because the lines and action are one of a kind. I feel that when i watch this movie I want to go out and shoot down bad guys, If there is a movie that you don't want to miss its this one.

This is a good film for die-hard Chucky fans . Okay I 'm sure it 's not as good as 

the older versions, but it's still very entertaining for me. What I liked about the movie is that it introduces a bunch of new characters that breathe new life into the classic horror genre. The visual effects were excellent, the dialogue was enjoyable, and the performances from the actors were amazing. It doesn't follow a traditional horror film style, it takes some new and fresh ideas from different films to give it a unique feel. All in all I enjoyed it a lot.

I don't care what some of the reviews said, this movie was funny. The thing with this film is that you can't expect anything else except to be entertained. This is not some intellectual comedy, this is a clever popcorn movie. The three main cast members are great and work very well with each other. Shatner is a standout in the supporting cast as himself, a former TV cop, brought in by Russo's character to coach the cops on how to be "TV cops." Those are by far the funniest scenes.

Undoubtedly one of the best episodes ever, Balance of Terror is 45 minutes of well executed suspense, with intelligent real-world parallels (the title refers to a situation very similar to what was going on between the US and the Soviet Union during the Cold War), spot-on characterizations and the introduction of Star Trek's second most important hostile alien race after the Klingons: the Romulans. After receiving a distress call from a Federation outpost, the Enterprise is dangerously close to the Neutral Zone which, if crossed, would lead to open conflict with the Romulans, although no one has ever actually seen them in the flesh.

It took me a while to find this movie since they do n't have it yet on DVD ( and  it wasn't easy considering it had won 4 academy awards). Searching high and low in movie stores across my city I eventually found it in a local theatre’s antique archive. It was only available in VHS but the person who provided the copy had done a remarkable job transferring it over the years. Unfortunately, I couldn’t keep it since it was already on loan from a well established film museum but being able to see the movie itself after such a long search was nothing short of miraculous.

I was so happy to learn that Hari Om will finally be theatrically released in 2007. I saw this film three years ago at the Vancouver International film Festival and have been waiting for it's release ever since so I could send everyone I know to see it. It's like taking a trip to India....colorful, magical, thought provoking. Aside from one rather strange Hollywood style auto rickshaw chase scene this movie is very realistic. This is not a Bollywood style song and dance movie but it does have drama and romance and humor.

When I first saw this movie , I also expected `` our boys '' to be cute , and more  on a magical side ,

I was taken aback a bit as it turned out to be nothing like that. There were magical elements in it, sure, but they were fewer than expected, with mostly involving an almost anti-hero like protagonist, strong presence of archetypes and problem solving with puzzles and mechanics. Despite this not being quite the type of movie I expected, I must admit it made a unique statement and had surprisingly memorable visuals.

Buddy Holly was a pioneer and victim of the early days of rock 'n ' roll . The young singer/songwriter  composed his own original songs that captured the innocence of early rock music and showed a promise of greater things to come. Sadly, he was killed at only 22 in a plane crash on the day that would become known as 'The day the music died' He had a real influence over generations to come, most prominently as a songwriter rather than a performer. The unique songs written in this era that later earned Holly a prestigious award remain inspirational, creative and musical discoveries still in existence today.

Nominated for best documentary feature at 2004's Academy Awards, My Architect follows filmmaker Nathaniel Kahn in his quest to find out about his father, the legendary architect Louis I Kahn. Lou Kahn died in 1974, when Nate was 11 years old, leaving behind an incredible but limited body of work, unpaid debts and three separate families all living within a few kilometres of each other. My Architect follows Kahn's life through chronologically examining his buildings, and interspersing their beauty with the story of a charismatic, but selfish and emotionally immature genius.

"Pearl Harbor, buddy." This movie is brilliant! Sure it doesn't exactly flow like an multi-million dollar comedy does, but the jokes that are constantly thrown in are unbelievable. I'm one that goes for silliness, much like "Dumb and Dumber", "Airplane" and "Wet Hot American Summer" and I have to say this easily ranks up there. Movies just aren't written with this kind of sporadic comedy anymore. Too many jokes in this are such a surprise to the viewer that it's honestly amazing that more don't know about and praise this slapstick masterpiece!

Despite of all the negative criticism I really enjoyed this movie. I am not saying this lightly. I love movies and am fairly picky about them (my home DVD collection is over 9,000 movies - some are great, others are OK, a few I do not like at all). And, to all those with criticisms: this is a comedy. I simply love this movie. It is light, funny, and very restful. I am aware of all (or most) of the deficiencies but I love it.

I 've commented once on this Chucky great , but I had to do it again to say some things  that I had previously omitted . He is by far the funniest doll out there, with a true aptitude for comedy that gives rise to side-splitting situations. He constantly cracks his inimitable and yet simple one liners, inviting the onlookers to chorus and become enamored with his spirit. Besides his compelling on screen performances, his gestures can keep viewers hooked throughout the movie. Truly, he brings sheer and solid laughter along with thrills and mystifying plotlines making the plot, memorable, capturing and to engage fans with continued adoration.

`` Showtime '' falls somewhere north of what some critics have been saying , and a little south of what  might become required listening to stay in vogue. It is likely to satisfy fans looking for something specific in their listening. Its sonic playgrounds veer further and further away from radio's bland alternatives, enabling curious musical selections that remain near enough to traditional convention to evoke exciting emotion and explore personal sensations, each using melody and memory differently, revealing startling nuance in craft, precision and instrumental development that transport an audience well beyond those previous edges.

"D.O.A" is an involving and entertaining little picture from start to finish. Dennis Quaid is at his caustic best; and Quaid is sadly one of the most underused talents in Hollywood. His then beau Meg Ryan also appears with him, but as is usually the case, doesn't really make much of an impact. The film is stylishly directed throughout, drawing on a number of influences to capture its 'seamy' feel. Would you credit that it's actually directed by two people? The answer is no. The whole thing is superbly slick, from its innovative camerawork to its unabashed use of black and white photography.

This is Christmas time ! A nativity in terms of rebirth , or at least this is what can be  gained in reflection . It is this reminder of life, a literal embrace, and metaphor for all humankind - a treasured reflection that makes it hard to think about Christmas being celebrated apart from each other this year. After all, Christmas is about so much more than spending, it's a holiday dedicated to forgiveness, humility, and hope for a better tomorrow. No matter where in the world, the warmth of the Christmas spirit seems to span the miles in little squares and goblet in homes around the world.

This is one of the finest TV movies you could ever see. The acting, writing and production values are top-notch. The performances are passionate with Beverly D'Angelo superb as the older woman with a teenage daughter and Rob Estes simply perfect as the young stud boyfriend. However, the best part of this film was how it showed the consequences of sexual abuse instead of going for the usual happy ending. It showed that abuse can happen in good families; involve good people; and wreck lives. It is thought provoking and entertaining. Congratulations to all concerned with this exceptional movie.

Chucky is back but this time he is not scary ( a lot ) - but he is funny ! He has some pretty wild comedic jokes and will have you laughing in no time . This time round, Chucky shows a completely new and different side. He isn't out to harm or bring fear - it's quite the opposite! He joins in on some of the group activities and becomes almost part of the gang, bringing laughs and plenty of silly antics. Even though his jokes may be a bit corny, Chucky puts on a performance sure to lift your spirits!

In this early Fulci work the director shows his most mainstream side as well as a talent for compelling storytelling and more than reasonable elucidation for the genre. Personally I think he has been unfairly maligned throughout his career as an aesthete of gore. It's a pretty capable procedural and surprised me with its subtextually rich narrative that shows his distrust for small minded small-town mentality and the inefficiency of the police, as well as the twisted ideals of the Catholic church, the last of which seemed to have cut this film at its knees when it was first released and could have possibly given the director another direction so early on.

I absolutely love this film and have seen it many times. I taped it in about 1987 when it was shown on Channel Four but my tape is severely worn now and I would love a new copy of it.I have e-mailed Film Four to ask them to show it again as it has never been available on video and as far as I know hasn't been repeated since the 80's. I have had no reply and it still hasn't been repeated. The performances are superb. The film has everything. Its funny,sad,disturbing,exciting and totally takes you back to school days.

It was a terrific movie! I like to watch it again and again. The actors were awesome. The movie kept me on the edge of my seat. I would recommend this movie to anyone. I wish Lifetime would put this movie on DVD. I would most definitely purchase a copy. This movie just proves that you should be very careful about who you get hooked up with. You may think you know someone, but you never know. My daughter watched the movie with me. She thought it was great. All I know is, I will watch this movie every time Lifetime airs it.

Unconditional Love is one of the best movies I've seen in a while. It's an emotional roller-coaster. One of my favorite scenes is the pub scene. When Dirk tells Grace that he didn't want to go to the pub because the villagers don't like him, you expect the worst. When the old woman holds her glass up and says 'To the Memory of Victor Fox and the whole pub follows suit, I wanted to cry. The funeral scene is hysterical! Julie does it in her typical Julie Andrews style. Johnathan Pryce is excellent as Victor.

Wow , What a wonderful film-making ! Mr. Im has done it , again ! His last work , ChunHayang ManJeon , impressed me in many aspects :

Mr. Im once again amazes with this new film-making. The combination of symbolism and photography gives the audience a beautiful insight into human suffering and longing. The slow pacing of the film adds a special level of emotion. Characters of all ages, creeds, and lifestyles collide in powerful interactions throughout the film, shining a light on issues such as life and death, survival, justice and morality. Every scene feels absolutely real and alive.

Film auteur Stephan Woloszczuk explores the depths of love, passion, and brotherhood and the devastating results of loss in his latest film BLINDSPOT.BLINDSPOT'S diegetic world is exploding with suspense and takes the audience on a twisting  journey to the core of the human soul. As a director, he manages to draw the human spirit from the performances of his actors. With superb editing, especially in the flashback scenes and beautiful cinematography, BLINDSPOT is a thought provoking suspense from beginning to end. A thriller which leaves much to the minds' eye.What an  astounding accomplishment for Stephan Woloszczuk. Cheers Stephan!

where do we go from here ? that is the overriding question of this film . And make no mistake  it's a complex issue. What does the answer mean for us and for our future? To make it simple, is to do what we have always done- coming up with solutions that push our society to advance forward together and leave nobody behind. This includes acknowledging our mistakes in the past, accepting our responsibility and commitment towards the betterment of our fellow human beings, the environment and other creatures living on this planet.

He did one at Christmas to try and bring back a number one song , and now the terrific Justin  has a spot in the Hall Of Fame 

The effect of his music did not go unnoticed -he left fans in tears and also achieved two number one albums during his successful music career. From that moment on Justin was respected by the media, fellow music industry artists and obviously a tremendous fan base from the success of all of his future hits. But it was in recognition of Justin’s substantial achievements in the industry he finally found himself nominated for induction into the famous and celebrated Hall Of Fame.

I remember seeing this film when I was fairly young & being quite disturbed by it. I found the storyline very distressing and can still remember the various bullying techniques used. One in particular was when the other school children spat in his soup before he could even taste a spoonful. They also bound him and shaved his private parts. This was all because he was unpopular. Why was he unpopular? Because he was bad at games. I have a feeling though that even if he was good at games he would have been bullied because it's hard to decide what makes someone popular.

Fantastic Chaplin movie with many memorable moments as Charlie joins the army to fight in WW 1.At first he goes to boot camp, where he has to learn how to handle his rifle and how to walk in line. That's a really funny scene as the tramp is not used to keeping his feet straight!Next thing you know he's in France in a trench. Hilarious scenes here include a starving Charlie eating the cheese of a mousetrap and reading a letter from home over someone's shoulder.When Charlie goes to sleep he finds his bunker all flooded and his roommate snoring.

When his elderly mother Emily ( Jeanne Bates ) is attacked by her lodger Nestor Duvalier ( Brion James )  Charlie races home. He is relieved to find that she's still alive and quickly goes about dispatching Nestor. He engages him in a knockdown, drag-out fight with him eventually coming out on top and binding Nestor up with a heavy, strong chain. The police arrive at Charlie's place of residence only to find Nestor looking worse for wear. In one of his first use of parental control Charlie forces Nestor to pay reparation money as punishment and a form of redress.

where do we go from here? that is the overriding question of this film. And make no mistake, 'mainly ETC. ', the 2003 effort from director john jansen, asks far more questions than it answers, but none so poignantly or so powerfully as this one.much of the the film plays like a running conversation between you and your college drinking buddies, and I'm sure many of the questions raised by the main characters you'll recognize from your own evenings of drunken debauchery. however, one of the many beauties of this film is that we are rarely given an answer.

I 've seen the 1973 movie Lost Horizons and read many of the reviews for this movie . I agree  that this is an interesting and interesting story that will provide viewers with some entertainment as they learn about the power of trust, determination, and personal exploration. The performances in Lost Horizons have received praise and prove the caliber of the story and its setting. For example, viewers will enjoy the courage of protagonist Dr. Joseph Buchan and the heartfelt encounters between Richard Carlson and Betsy Drake. As the characters embark on their adventures, the personal growth that is showcased will both captivate and evoke emotions from its viewers.

This is sweet . The actress who played the nurse with the gonzongas is the same actress who plays Elvira  in the same series. The talented actress, besides Elvira and the Nurse with the Gonzongas, has a number of roles in other television shows and films. She has showcased her versatility, mastering comedic, and even some tragic, performances that have left the audiences mesmerized. As if to test her true mettle, the star plays a spy in an upcoming film which requires intensive choreographed fights. The demand is sure to put her physical, and more notably emotional, prowess to test.

When the new Outer Limits first started, the episodes were quite optimistic and challenging. As the series began to wind down, most of the episodes became just plain ugly and devoid of any entertainment value. The six episodes here reflect the very best, and worst, of the series.Since The Outer Limits always preaches a moral. I would like to offer my own. Starting with the most entertaining to the flops.1. Afterlife: As an institution, The U.S.A. military-industrial complex is both evil and paranoid, not to mention plain stupid.

My college theater just had a special screening last night of this film . I have got to say that  it was one of the best experiences that I ever had. The movie was heart-warming and soul-stirring at the same time and each scene was more interesting than the last. There were even parts where you were on the edge of your seat because the film moved at such a captivating pace. Even during the middle and end of the film, where everyone knew the main characters had all been on a rough journey, the audience held back their tears.

OK , so I loved Rachael Ray before , but now , I ADORE her ! How innovative . I  saw this recipe where she used watermelon instead of traditional tomatoes in a BLT ! The recipe was unique but tasty , adding in fresh flavors that I hadn't thought of before. Plus , she showed ways to give a basic dish a flair. Rachael Ray uses both commonplace ingredients that most of us already have , but with uncommon cooking ideas. This always inspires me in the kitchen , to make something that might surprise my family and be scrumptious too.

I first saw The Buddy Holly Story when I was about seven years old . I had no idea who  he was and had never heard his music. The movie sparked something in me, however. Every scene where music was involved I just couldn't look away, and I just had this burning sensation within me that said "this is amazing!" I asked my parents who the guy was in the movie, and from then on, I had become a fan of Buddy Holly's music. Growing up, I sought out anything Buddy Holly-related and even managed to pick up guitar to recreate some of his beloved songs.

This movie , based on a true story of Gerrit Wolfaardt , is one of the best films I 've  seen so far. Gerrit's struggle for self acceptance and understanding for who he truly is truly captivated me. The tension built between his religious background and his quest for individuality takes many unexpected turns. You won't see the ending coming. But despite all his doubts, the knowledge that in the end, one has the choice of whether to bow down to conventions or stand strong, determined to face all the barriers thrown your way was rewarding. There is something special in this movie.

I always liked this movie, I have seen it so many times but I always enjoyed it :) the story is interesting and special. But the only thing I have to disagree with is that I don't think Max lived in a Romanian monastery or what was that :P They don't look that way in Romania.. Anyway, back to the story, Ghita Muresan played pretty well but as someone said before me, his English needs to improve. And there were some funny moments and some tragical/sad parts too. It worths being seen, I thought it was sweet that the giant wanted to find his love.

The very few reviews I could find online of Barnens ö really do not do it justice. I read them all before ordering the DVD, but for some reason I ordered it anyway. I regretted it almost immediately, but the order had already gone through so I couldn't cancel it. I'm very glad now that I couldn't. It's an extraordinary movie.I won't give a synopsis of the plot, because other reviewers have already done that. But I will say that I don't understand comments that it's bleak, shocking, weird, clinical, depressing or pornographic.

When I started watching 3 of the episodes of this series on the Action Channel , I have to say 

I was instantly hooked. With it's dynamic cast, exotic settings and twists, turns and suspense this show was unlike anything I had seen before. Each episode unfolds its story in unexpected directions. Every episode keeps me captivated, on the edge of my seat, eager to find out what will happen next. From intimate character exploration to thrilling sequences and the adventure never ends, the stakes become ever more thrilling and make the episodes gripping.

Enhanced by the expressive cinematography of Agnes Godard ( Beau Travail ) , Golden Door is a visually striking tone -poem, emphasizing both its overall fantastical appeal and deeper emotive aspects. As such, subtle conversations and philosophical questions are part of the canvas - manifested through Gianna's plea for her son's escape from poverty. Failing her families income to surpass the rate of imposts. The medieval geography provides not just poetic landscape imagery, but communicates man's strugglje in its permanent circumstances, chaste undercurrent and fuctional diplomacy a pivotal focus ofthe golden door experience.

After spotting the boat at the end of the previous episode ("Three Minutes"), the survivors are shocked to find out who the occupant is. With the use of the boat, Jack and Sayid come up with a plan to confront "The Others". However, when Jack, Sawyer, Kate and Hurley follow Michael to "The Others", Jack is forced to reveal Michael's deadly secret whilst they are in the middle of nowhere.Meanwhile, Locke decides that the time has come to find out the time has come to find out what will happen if "the button" is not pressed.

What's the point of this messages if not to discuss and share thoughts about the next season... Here is my forecast: 1. The hatch was indeed blown, but somehow everybody inside survived. Buts lets see about that. 2. The episode at the end with the tent is an observation team monitoring the tracking device installed on Desmonds boat by Penny. Now that the magnetic shield around the island was lifted, the signal was picked up by the observation station and they are going to send a rescue mission. 3.

This is a stunning movie . Raw and sublimely moving . It felt like a very gripping , intelligent stage  adaptation

This movie left me shaken. There were multiple dramatic scenes where emotions were absolutely palpable. The subtle direction helped move the story along. It captures small moments like no other. I was in awe throughout the entire show, deeply invested in the characters’ relationships and arcs. As I was so wrapped in the gripping tale that slowly reveals itself, I couldn’t help feeling both gratified and impacted by it.

Lucio Fulci 's `` Do n't Torture a Duckling '' paints an exceptionally unflattering portrait of small-town Sicily plagued by  ingrained poverty and ancient superstitions

Lucio Fulci's film tells a disheartening tale of a family crippled by abject poverty and hampered by primitive, oppressive attitudes. In his devastating vision of rural Italy, hostility pervades and prejudice runs rampant, epitomizing Fulci's conviction that secluded poverty instills generations of sickness. The turbulent emotional environment presented serves as an unlikely platform for newfound courage, when a lowly gaggle of brave kids attempts to reveal a treacherous secret.

This movie is beautiful in all ways . It is visually stunning , and this is a good thing since  it tells a powerful story . The story is beautifully intertwined with suspenseful musical arrangements to capture the heart and attention of any movie lover. Each scene and setting are accurately depicted in great detail with the aid of top of the line visual effects that are unparalleled in quality. It gives the audience a true window into what it was like in the times the film was made. Actors who star in this movie give genuinely captivating performances and powerful dialogues that fill in many emotional depths throughout the film.

I think I was recommended this film by the lady in the shop I was hiring it from! For once she was bang on! What a superb film! First of all I was convinced James McAvoy & Romola Garai were Irish so convincing were their accents; and by half way through the film I was utterly convinced Steven Robertson was a disabled actor and pretty sure James McAvoy was also! When I watched the special features on the DVD and saw both actors in their 'normal' guise, to say I was blown away would be an understatement!!!

I do n't usually like this sort of movie but was working at home and wanted something to halfway watch  in the background

As a result, I ended up with this particular movie, having seen all of the major trailers and expecting something mildly amusing. To my surprise, I was highly entertained and pleased by the ending. It was original and clever, and made the story come alive. My previous indifference toward the movie transformed into genuine appreciation for the fresh concepts it was promoting. Now, this movie tops my list of the best genre flicks, despite the clichés in it.

The last film by underrated director Alberto De Martino ( `` The Antichrist '' , `` The Killer is on  the Phone '' ) received little fanfare. Unfortunately, it was a much lesser film compared to De Martino's earlier ones. Despite a riveting soundtrack, the dialogue and character development were painfully unconvincing and overused. Many felt the movie was full of potential and what it lacked was someone behind the camera that could fill in those glaring gaps. Fans eagerly awaited to see if Alberto De Martino had it in him to make another amazing movie; one with tight storytelling, pacing, and characters that audience could connect to.

This is one of the best sequels around and a very good movie too even there were some mistakes but still I enjoyed it. This time, Charles is not just fighting one or two muggers but a whole army of them. Death Wish 3 has a lot great action scenes and I enjoyed it every single second of it. Director Michael Winner knows how to direct a good action movie like this and Jimmy Page providing the music, with producers Golan and Globus still doing there thing and Charles Bronson is still acting good for Paul Kersey.

At one time ` Buddy Cop ' movies ruled the box office . It seemed that every summer flocks of  people rushed to theatres to experience the adrenaline-inducing action-packed plots that filled their nights. It was common knowledge that Hollywood had hit on a good formula and was sure to capitalize on its success. Eventually the excitement subsided and these movies disappeared from theatres just as fast as they had become the hottest thing on the block. But nostalgia from those glory days remains in the memories of those movie fans lucky enough to have lived it, if only for a summer.

I wasn't expecting a great deal from this film, so I was pleasantly surprised when I watched it and found it to be most noteworthy. It's noteworthiness is mainly due to the talent and appeal of it's star, John Garfield.Garfield plays Jack, a boxing star who is framed for murder. He must go on the run, and ends up out in the sticks with Gloria Dickson and the Dead End Kids. Here is offered a chance for redemption, yet will the past catch up with him yet? Garfield was an actor ahead of his peers.

( Some spoilers included : ) Although , many commentators have called this film surreal , the term fits poorly  . This movie is much better defined by other words like awe-inspiring, wondrous, and life-changing. The protagonists walk a careful tightrope, doing good and striving for something bigger and better for themselves as well as for their respective communities. Much like their situations, each character is subject to extremes of courage and tragedy; tremendous moments of levity and unfathomable darkness. Although ultimately satisfying, this movie is a narrative balancing act in more ways than one and isn't the kind of work that people easily forget.

The writers of lost have outdone themselves. Season two's finale is even more heartbreaking and intense than the finale for season one. Locke's lack of faith has not only resulted in spiritual consequences for himself, but in tragic physical consequences for the lives of the other castaways. Michael's betrayal resulted in a success for him but can he possibly escape the island? He will have to if he wants to stay alive. I don't doubt that one or more of his former friends would be willing to kill him in revenge.

I love this movie, though I don't like how they picture Egyptians, being an Egyptian citizen myself! that's why it earns an eight out of 10.The relationship between Augustin and the leopard is awkward, and of course because of loneliness and living in that cave for quite so long, he develops a kind of insanity and passion to that leopard.A very touching scene when the leopard dies, watch Augustin's reaction.. All in all I find it enjoyable, and I'm looking forward to reading the short story by Balzac.

I saw this movie on it's opening night, and enjoyed it. I probably would have enjoyed it more if I hadn't been sitting by my father. My father saw the original (unfortunately, I have not seen it yet) and kept talking through the whole thing. He kept saying that the movie sucked, and that it was stupid. The thing is, he didn't understand that the creators were slightly making fun of the horror genre with the film. In every horror movie, there is always a certain character depicted.

Just about every commentator has mentioned the way that some of the interview footage is superposed over the concert footage in places. This is true, and is the biggest flaw of this film. However, it isn't so often, or so bad, that one shouldn't see this video. If you are a Black Sabbath fan, you have to see this. Aside from having seen Black Sabbath in the Sevnties and early Eighties, I saw them in 2005 or 2006 when they also headlined OZZfest just like in this video.

The big names in film tried to do their part for the war effort , and Charlie Chaplin was no  exception

He released the critically acclaimed "The Great Dictator" in 1940, which became an overnight sensation in the United States and overseas. Charlie Chaplin openly showed his disapproval of Adolf Hitler, with this epic propaganda film that showcased the challenges of anti-semitism and terrorism. Following this, the US Office of War Information asked Chaplin to use his cinematic voice and support US Bonds by speaking during war drives throughout the country. This was one of Chaplin’s proudest and most enduring acts for America during wartime.

I have to admit I had never heard of this movie . I caught it last night on TMC . It immediately caught my attention. The main character was interesting, the music was perfect, and the dialogues flowed wonderfully. I thought the director had done a superb job with making the scenes very vivid and the drama was heartfelt and emotionally complex. I especially loved how the love story progressed, it wasn’t rushed but taken its own sweet time to take a realistic and bittersweet shape. The photography, pacing, lighting and music fit so perfectly, and combined it told a magical story.

This film, like much of their music, is either underrated or unnoticed by the casual observer. It is terrific and, in many ways, ahead of its time.The images are funny, disturbing, and at the very least, engaging. The music is amazing. This is not the "candy pop" sound they are unfortunately associated with. This is the sound of a band in exploration and revolt.HEAD, alone, should put The Monkees into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Can anyone tell me why these guys are not in there?

This film was one of three that were later combined by Chapin into a compilation that was released to theaters  later that year. The trilogy was largely met with enthusiasm, gaining respect for Chapin's experimental film-making. While the three shorts alone made barely enough profit to cover production costs, the compilation secured long-lasting attention in critical circles, earning Chapin prestigious awards. Having caught the attention of famed filmmakers such as François Truffaut and Andrei Tarkovsky, this short served as a demonstration of Chapin’s versatile direction and budding filmmaking techniques. Its relative success furthered Chapin’s drive to venture into newer and bigger films.

The movie starts with a board meeting at a major advertising agency. Putney Swope is on the board for no other reason than the fact that he is black, and the agency needs a "token" on the board. Swope is ignoring the meeting, reading Jet magazine at the big table, and everybody is ignoring Swope... Suddenly, the CEO croaks on the spot. No time is wasted. A janitor is called to haul off the corpse, and the board immediately and unceremoniously tackles the business of electing a new CEO.

'Captain Corelli 's Mandolin ' is a fantastic film in itself . It is nothing like the book , which  it is based upon. It has moments of magic and levity as we journey through Greece under Italian control, but with World War Two just round the corner. Though it carries its own spin on Louis De Bernieres' epic book, the movie proves itself just as emotionally touching as the original tale. Much of the magic of the movie comes from Nicolas Cage's spectacular acting - delivering a believable performance that reminds us of both the peril and comradery in those troubling days.

This is a 100 % improvement over the dross of a third movie and it 's one hell of a  final instalment. It proved that the franchise was meant to reach a remarkable peak and remain just as captivating to audiences long after its end. Of course, with all its action, emotion, drama and wonderful new characters, the grand finale made the world that once started off so promising, incredible once more. By sticking to its strengths, the movie managed to wrap up its adventure with finesse and panache while delivering powerful messages of companionship, morality and motivation.

Let me clarify that . This is not a `` good movie '' , but I am so glad it  is one of the choices on offer. The other two films on offer do not appeal to me so this one was the obvious pick for tonight's movie night. It does not require much attention as its genre can sometimes make movies tedious. Although it is not the ideal movie for our movie night, I'm quite sure that all of us will enjoy watching it to some degree. Despite this, we still plan on having a fun evening filled with popcorn, conversations and laughter.

TV churns out dozens of true-crime movies every year. You can see 3 or 4 every Saturday on Lifetime, and Court TV can be relied on for a few every weekend. So I started watching The Morrison Murders thinking I knew very well what to expect: a more or less competent retelling of a real-life family murder. What I got was a subtle, beautifully acted drama that engrossed me from start to finish.Both the brothers were totally convincing, and Jonathan Scarfe was perfect in the challenging role of Luke. The look and feel of Georgia was in almost every frame.

As with so many modern US films , there has to be a supernatural element to the plot , but  the writers don’t rely too heavily on this aspect and ensure that it does not take away from the human drama in the narrative. Instead it serves to highlight the underlying themes, bringing a kind of foreboding mood that tenses the audience up until the climactic resolution. The storyline has plenty of unexpected turns, as characters behave contrary to what you would normally expect, while important questions remain unanswered and invite multiple interpretations.

Damien O'Donnell has a good track record and in this film he handles a very delicate topic with sensitivity but manages not to let the film turn into schmalz.This is a fantastic film, its funny with sad bits and it makes you look at things differently. Tell everyone you know to go see it now- FANTASTIC!The acting is excellent, and Dublin plays a starring role. This film will change the way you view people with disabilities and also give you a very entertaining night out in the cinema. I can't wait til it comes out on DVD.

The "old dark house" sub-genre that dominated the early talkies rarely fails to disappoint when we re-view the oldies to-day. Here is one that provides so very many suspicious characters you have to wonder how they will be able to tie up all the loose ends in the 6 reel running time.The Crooked Circle is a gang of counterfeiters and thieves who have decided to take revenge on Col. Walters (Berton Churchill) who has sent one of their ranks to prison. They decide he must die that very night. Meanwhile the Colonel's own group, The Sphinx Club, is determined to protect him at all costs.

This is a good film , no doubt , but with some odd aspects . Without spoiling anything it takes  a twist in the middle , with one character (Kaya ) becoming someone who nobody saw coming. Kaya ends up leading her newfound life to success, pushing back any doubts that surround her character. Her courage and ambition shown give her character the motivation to keep on moving forward no matter the opposition. In the end it creates a moral which adds even more to the twist and unexpected aspects which gave the film its excitement.

What an incredible story and what a beautiful film! Hat's off to Ben Daniels, Lavinia Currier and the great Honore de Balzac. This captivating film conveys the passion experienced by the characters so effortlessly and yet so powerfully. I watched it mesmerized, almost holding my breath as the story developed towards its inexorable end. This film's execution was almost flawless: simple and pure, it plays with our hearts, guiding us in understanding the strange platonic, absolute thus possessive bond between two creatures not meant to be part of each other's world.

This movie is an awesome remake of the original by the same title. The movie was cool,despite the fact, I hate new ones! All of the cast was awesome . It has great cast and an awesome plot!! The main plot is a man is poisoned and he has to solve his own murder , neat eh? !Dennis Quaid is the man who is "D.O.A"(in other words Dead On Arrival).He finds help with his friends, but everyone is now a suspect! !Dennis's character has several hours to find out who poisoned him.

The cover of the VHS says it all: "Without doubt, the most powerful movie of its kind since the Texas Chainsaw Massacre". I'm a huge fan of 70's and 80's slashers and I have to say, I agree 100 %. The characters are believable, the actors have an excellent charm (especially George Kennedy as the forest-ranger). There's the twisted atmosphere, that only TCM has, an astounding soundtrack to reflect the emotions and the filming locations that are the most beautiful in the history of horror.

I was surprised and touched by this emotional movie which moved me very strange . I was confused , sad  and i could hardly think straight. It has been days and I am still trying to find words that could justify my feelings. The scene which depicts the closeness of a father and daughter during the funeral stirred all sorts of emotion in my mind. I felt heartbroken and could almost feel the characters' pain in my own body. This film truly showcased how one should value and treasure their relations before it's too late.

SPOILERSI love the Simpsons, and I have seen every single episode that had ever come out. I must admit, season one is by far the most underrated season, and this is the most underrated episode in season one.The episode begins with the family playing a game of Scrabble to get Bart ready for an intelligence test he needs to take at school. He says the game is stupid and he doesn't want to play it, but he needs to. He spells out a word that angers Homer and he chases Bart around the house.

Oh my word ! ! I have never seen a film so lacking in any kind of moral judgement or  ethical standards. The acting was horrid, and the plot didn't really take off until halfway through. There was too much over-the-top romance and violence that should have been left out of a movie in the first place. Moreover, the scenes weren't linked well and at times, I found it difficult to understand why characters behaved in certain ways. The film did have its fair share of merits though. But overall, this wasn't the kind of experience I had expected from the promotional materials I saw.

The best thing from the American Pie `` bakery . '' I found the humor and the plot to be  well done, with enough twists and turns that kept me guessing and entertained. It's not just the writing and acting that draw me in; the character arcs were unique, allowing me to feel what the characters were feeling as they progressed through their stories. And who can forget the memorable soundtrack and Alanis Morrisette's single? I left the cinema humming the "Goodbye, Little Lame duck, Goodbye" as I strolled out the door.

I would say 'Bride of Chucky ' is a `` return to greatness '' but the series was never really  known as that to begin with. The franchise is really built on the idea of laughs, blood and nastiness. Bride of Chucky isn't trying to scare anyone like the original did. Instead, the creators shifted focus to clever, off-color jokes with an almost loving emphasis on clever dialogue and physical gags. That could turn some people off, as Bride of Chucky focuses heavily on that style of filmmaking that was born from popular horror flicks of the 90s and 00s.

I agree that this is ONE of the very best episodes of the entire series -- my only detraction would  be

I don't think any other episode got quite so far down in the minutiae and characters the same way. While this depth gave viewers a profound glimpse at our show's iconic universe, some long-time fans felt disconnected because of the sporadic lack of main characters, some fans worrying this could signal the demise of the show. Overall however, most of the responses to this episode were extremely positive and proved it would only boost the show's presence going into the next season.

A nice and pleasant movie full of meditteranean sceneries (Cephallonia is a very beautiful greek island) that keeps many of the novel's characteristics. I think that greek sceneries add something special and magical to a movie. One thing i didn't like at all though, is that the main characters, like 'Mandras' and Pelagia's father weren't greek actors but foreigners. I mean the actors tried to express the greek way of living, but to me they didn't succeed and it was quite clear. Even their pronunciation when they were trying to use greek words was terrible and that was bad for the film's plot.

1969 was the year. New York City was the place. Putney Swoope was the second Robert Downey film to achieve some recognition. The first was Chaffed Elbows (1966). Putney Swoope achieved a much wider release. Pound (1970) and Greasers Palace (1972) were even more profane and obnoxious. Those 2 films were mean spirited to the point that they actually stalled the Prince's feature film career for several years.The subject at hand is Putney Swoope. And it is a mad farce/satire that has to be seen to be believed. I'm not going to go through the plot here.

I am a long time fan of Luc Besson's work, and for about as long as I've known his name, I've also looked for this movie. I tried looking for this movie all over California for over four years. this past summer i took a trip to Europe, one of my missions on this trip was to at least see this movie. long story short, I bought it and watched it in France! I was blown away, it completely made my trip and i finally feel content that i have seen Luc Besson's first work.

Loved today 's show ! ! ! It was a variety and not solely cooking ( which would have been  great). I loved seeing all the talented people involved. It was nice to get a break from cooking to be reminded that variety can have great show appeal too. Everything was perfect- the acts, the guests and the energy of the studio. I thoroughly enjoyed myself. Best of all, I could connect and interact with people around the world who shared my enthusiasm for the show. It's safe to say this was truly a successful show and I'm sure there will be much more to come.

I was pleasantly surprised by the depth of story and character development . Fulci was a master at creating horrific  suspense which was a hallmark of his later movies

In terms of violence and gore he spares no one in 'Zombie', with its confrontational shock cuts, avant-garde angles and hallucinogenic graphics. Zombie marked a significant shift in the content and graphic displays used in horror cinema and prefigured the modern popularization of slasher movies that emerged a few years later. Its depiction of inescapable fate and ultimately unbearable levels of despair are emblematic of his unique brand of storytelling.

Another enjoyable Warner flick. I really liked John Garfield in this, though I'm wondering why Cagney wasn't in the role. Perhaps it was too similar to ANGELS WITH DIRTY FACES? I mean, it's another Dead End Kids story of sorts too, but I really appreciated them here and this film had a lot of nice comical touches along with some good serious drama. The boys work great with Garfield. A nice sequence was the whole "swimming" scene which starts out with no cares but winds up coming too close to disaster.One negative comment: Claude Rains was grossly miscast.

Cult-director Lucio Fulci is probably most famous for his gory Zombie flicks from the 1980s that earned him his rightful  status as 'maestro of the macabre'. Since the beginning of his career Fulci went against traditional, cinematic conventions. While Zombie Flesh Eaters became an undisputed cult-classic of it’s era, some of Fulci’s more absurd works have more recently become recognized as cult masterpieces. From oddball comedies like Now They Call Him Sacramento and Frankenstein '80 to horror-filled supernatural titles such as The Psychic and A Cat In The Brain.

I saw this film at a small screening . Even though it had a low budget , the creative direction  , photography and musical score was stunning

The actors managed to showcase excellent performances despite the conditions they were put through. The emotional rawness that portrayed by the director at its heart, cut right into my own emotional vulnerability. Themes of identity, prejudice, culture and inner growth stood at the core of the story and completely engulfed me throughout the entire viewing experience. It's safe to say I left feeling quite breathless, all inspired to be better than who I was before.

I remember years ago BBC1 used to show this movie in a very cut form. I tracked it down on video a couple of years ago and viewed it again. The film although slow and slightly odd (the mountain men look very strange) the atmosphere was eerily effective. It's one of my favorite slasher films and I have no idea where an uncut version can be found. Currently deleted everywhere (except the USA where it was accidentally put on a horror compilation!). It's a shame you cannot get this movie as it was meant to be seen.

Is this a good movie ? It 's hard to say -- but in 1953 , for many people ,  this movie was ground-breaking. This classic comedy broke traditional conceptions of both comedy and societal values and left viewers with a classic but timeless message.It inspired some classic films today that draw heavily on the iconic tropes used in the movie. Moreover, a box-office success it pushed the boundaries of the way people view comedy films in that era and has even made an impact up until the modern era.In conclusion, while opinions on this film may vary, its history has left a cultural impact beyond what anyone in 1953 would have predicted.

It was Libby talking to Desmond in the flashback, and if anyone is confused about her past (like how did she end up in the same hospital Hurley was in) then you should know that despited Libby dying in season 2, the character will be explored more in season 3 and we will get answers to questions surrounding her.BTW, great episode. It had a really great cliffhanger and some interesting questions...like what happened to Eko and Lock and what about the four toe statue?I cannot wait till season 3, Lost just rules!!!

Barbora Bobulova's portrayal of Valeria in this story was entirely captivating and heart wrenching at the same time. It has been a long time since I have seen so much hidden passion and mystique presented by any actor simply by utilizing her facial features and the use of her eyes and mouth the way Barbora does with this character. She was entirely believable as Valeria and I was swept away with her characterisation of this role. All at once the film was real life and fantasy, the clever use of what was limited dialogue left me spellbound.

I ca n't say how many times that one line has made me laugh or how often I 've described  the show to other people. Friends has definitely found a special place in my heart. The writers were genius when creating jokes and relatable situations, which always lead to hilarious scenes. The timing between the actors were superb and it made every line of dialogue even funnier. Whenever I watch the show, I always pick up something new I didn't notice before, adding an extra layer to the already brilliantly constructed show.

NOBODY ( 1999 ) is a fantastic piece of Japanese noir . It 's about three salarymen who get in  a crazy triangle with a cold female contract killer

NOBODY is a neo-noir thriller which portrays these three characters facing ethical dilemmas as they become entwined in an intensely personal journey filled with violence and guilt. Along the way, these anti-heroes battle inner turmoil, revenge, manipulation and addiction. The central theme of the film is each man's personal pursuit of salvation through exploring the ideas of existential justice and redemption in a world with few values.

This early film from future goremeister Lucio Fulci is a very good addition to the giallo sub-genre . Set in  Paris and with many comedic elements, it works as both a police procedural and murder mystery. Fulci uses elements such as wide shots of the streets and opera interspersed to create a surreal yet riveting experience that starts of somewhat quietly and slowly builds up to the point of pure hysteria. Certain trademark effects like gliding shots of body and blood splashes, striking several different techniques present in the master's work, give The psychic an intriguing stamp to set it apart from the standard whodunit thriller.

Spike Milligan 's books and plays have defeated film makers over the years , and 2002 's 'Puckoon ' is  a testament to the success of his most humorous works. Puckoon is widely considered to be a cult classic, thanks to its subversive comedic touches and brazen attacks on cultural norms. Additionally, his own improvisations became deeply etched into popular culture with catchphrases such as ‘Oah howanylikeemgeeve'” immortalized in English vocabulary and on TV series dedicated to him and other humorous performances. Milligan's satirical messages and lampooning has secured his works an undeniable presence in popular entertainment, continuing to live on long after his death in 2002.

The Buddy Holly Story opens on a shot of a yellow neon moon on the roof of a roller rink in 1956 Lubbock, Texas. As the credits start, the camera moves down from the moon to the parking lot, into the roller rink, past the concessions and across the rink to a small bandstand where a small band is doing their sound check. It's a tracking shot Welles and Scorcese would both appreciate. It cuts to Buddy Holly's bespectacled face peering down in rapt concentration as he grips the headphones and talks to a man putting this band on the radio.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji , a Japanese poet and writer who was active in  the Meiji and Taisho eras

The biopic brings together experts on Miyazawa’s works and recollections from the people of Hanamaki city (Miyazawa’s hometown). While speaking on Miyazawa, people recollected events and personal stories; painting a deeper portrait of this complicated artist and unveiling his themes on environment, art, society and religion. As per a senior lecturer of the Miyazawa Institute at Iwate University of Health and Welfare - 'Everything has in the form of Spirituality in his works and any translation effort could ruin that meaning.

Documentaries in which sons and daughters seek to understand a parent and, by the process, their own lives are not that uncommon. Also not uncommon are results that reflect lack of talent, a failure of introspection, an abundance of narcissism and, perhaps, an unsubtle quest for publicly-splashed revenge for countless past hurts, real and fantasized. What is unusual is a brilliant, fair and engrossing portrait of a fascinating parent and "My Architect: A Son's Journey" is that rare achievement.Louis Kahn emigrated to this country as a child, his face irreparably and brutally scarred by an accident.

Little Gus is a ten year old delinquent. He runs away from his parents and decides to go on a road-trip. Reaching the petal is somewhat tough for him, so he creates a device to help him. His goal is to win a gimmicky lottery type card game called Motorama. He has to find all eight letters in order to spell M-O-T-O-R-A-M-A. Dark laughter follows as it turns into the road-trip from hell. He runs into some deranged Lynch like characters. Most memorable is the gas station attendant, who puts his picture on a kite in hopes that God will see it.

This movie was great. It had everything a true action fan could want. Plenty of people getting shot and/or maimed, minimal romance involving sex, a hero that can be identified with, violence at many intervals instead of pointless plot storing up just one scene at the end, and villains that are just asking for it. Bronson appears to be at his lowest level of tolerancy in this film and it shows. Ed Lauter makes a great cop and was seamlessly worked into Bronson's plot without stealing his spotlight. The movie doesn't involve a plot so boring or over-consuming that you watch this film once and never again.

Hey look, you don't watch this movie to change your life! But if you are female especially and have always had a little thing for Richard Gere; this movie is right up your street. Diane Lane and Richard Gere have on screen chemistry going way back. 'Nights in Rodanthe' is not a Oscar winner movie and it will probably be forgotten sooner rather than later but if you want an atmospheric, beautifully shot love story between MIDDLE AGED good looking people (they don't make your stomach turn and even when Gere is 'on top' he does not look too jowly) then this is the movie for you.

Ali G earned his fame on the small screen - though the big screen has not lost him any kudos . The appeal of Ali G extended across to movie roles too. He had cameos in Mike Meyers' 'Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me', and featured as the lead in 'Ali G Indahouse'. He also featured as himself alongside comedians Mark Wahlberg and Will Ferrell in 'The Playboy of Beverly Hills' in 2004. From presenting the red carpet show of the 81st Academy Awards to contributing voices to successful movie franchises like the Madagascar series, Ali G has left his stamp on movie making too.

This series has a lot going for it with beautiful footage of the some of the most impressive underwater environments on this planet. Being a staggering five years in the making, one would be hard-pressed to expect any less. I did get the impression that some scenes from the first episode where repeated in the latter ones, which is naturally only a minor gripe.David Attenborough is great as a narrator and comments are informative, leaving enough room for one's imagination, and well spaced out, so that viewers get plenty of time to reflect upon the breathtaking imagery.

If you've never experienced the thing that is Zasu Pitts, here is a Zasu zinger! In 1933 Mae Questel caricatured Pitt's voice for the character Olive Oyl for the Fleischer Studios animated cartoon version of the comic strip Popeye. Zasu (pronounced Zay-Sue) does her best "Olive Oyl" impersonation walking around whining and ringing her hands or attaching herself to the policeman's laynard. I kept waiting for her to say "ohhh myyyy", but instead it's "something always happens to somebody." The first time I saw this film I loved Zasu and found her character really funny.

As an English teacher , I appreciate films that do more than tell a story . Good films , like  good literature , can transport us to another place and allow us to explore other perspectives . They challenge us to rethink our opinions, opinions and stimulate lively debates among friends . What's more, the use of audio and visuals help to truly bring a movie alive and make learning much easier . Consequently, using movies in the language classroom is a valuable asset which helps make learning an enjoyable and meaningful experience for all.

This is NOT the masterpiece that is Snow White , Cinderella , or Bambi , but it IS a very  respectable story in its own right

In spite of being no classic like Snow White, Cinderella, or Bambi, this story offers an entertaining and heartfelt experience in its own right. With mesmerizing visuals and heart warming story, the movie quickly rises to an unexpectedly positive level. The story puts children and adults alike on an imaginative and heartful roller coaster ride with gentle storylines, friendly characters and interesting settings that draw viewers in to a whole different universe.

While I agree that this movie lacks any real substance and should not be taken seriously , its primarily directed  at 

I think it is beneficial for the younger generations who still have some attachments with our more traditional media as this movie paints a broader picture and brings more understanding about our differences. Its unique spin also celebrates all forms of traditional culture, heritage and celebration, especially in times when such diverse social issues might seem hidden away. What is more, it should also remind adults to pay tribute to a growing complexity of our rich society while young people are given an open look at the history and belief.

When I was 10 (currently 14), I vowed to never see a movie that I knew would not have a happy ending. And until a few weeks ago I had done pretty well, except for Shakespere for English class...etc...I was still only watching things that ended happy. But then I saw Ramola Garai in Havanah Nights, which was cute, not good but entertaining enough to watch. After seeing this a few times over the two or so years since I first saw it, I grew to like it, especially the music.

This is possibly one of my favorite films. It tells the tale of a girl named Gerda (Chelsea Hobbs) who lost her mother at a very young age, so has been bought up by her father. She falls in love with the bell boy named Kai. However, on her birthday the snow queen (Bridget Fonda) comes the the hotel which her father owns and kidnaps Kai. Gurda then goes after Kai, and follows him through the four seasons in an attempt to rescue him.I thought that this was an excellent adaption of the story with great performances from all the cast.

Ah the Outer Limits . I love that show . It was surpremely creepy , or down-right mysterious . I  know it gave me and countless others a plethora of nightmare scenarios. The plot twists, the shadowy beings, and most of all the soundtrack and famous tagline "There is nothing wrong with your television set, do not attempt to adjust the picture" had me gripped and paranoid with fear that someone or something was going to come through my TV and swallow me into oblivion. I guess that is what happens when we stay up late watching eerie supernatural stories.

Even after nearly 20 years apart , the original members of Black Sabbath have not lost a thing . In  recent interviews, all the members express a joy and excitement that extends far beyond just music. With the full line-up reunited, their live shows quickly gained new, and unexpected fans. With their simple but powerful performances, their legacy of unruly fans was continuing on with renewed energy, who not only loved their older songs, but would accept the new musical experiments with genuine excitement. With each album or show, their stature increased, culminating with their eventual induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

I never thought I'd say this about a biopic, but there is a near over-abundance of characterization (especially concerning Kenji Miyazawa's emotions) and too little on the literal occurrences in his life--by the end, I'm not sure if he dies (he's supposed to), or if his sister finally dies (she's supposed to), or if the director spent a little too much time on the Galactic Railroad (that's an inside joke, in case you missed it--Miyazawa wrote a children's book called Night on the Galactic Railroad).

A film about the relationship between a man and leopard that's very reminiscent of "The English Patient," even down to a scene similar to when Ralph Fiennes' character carries the body of his lover across a desert-rock cliff. In "A Passion in the Desert," the main character carries the body of the leopard across a desert-rock cliff but in the opposite direction (calculated decision or unconscious contrast?). Historically expanded from a very short Balzac story, the film is not perfect but a treat no less. Final shot will haunt me for weeks.

I Loved this movie . Mark Blankfield was perfect for this role . More Classic sci/fie/Horror films should be remade . Although remakes of classic films can evoke mixed feelings, it's important that classic films be refreshed to be appreciated by newer generations. Of course, there will always be debates on the creative ways they are re-envisioned. Mark Blankfield was particularly ideal in this role - giving depth and clarity to his character, whilst providing some fun performances at the same time. For classic sci/fi and horror films, hopefully more directors would put more thought and care into this craft so more excellent films could emerge.

What a cast of actors and actresses in this Columbo episode , beside Peter Falk , you have Julie Newmar  , Karl Maiden , Linde Alfhelt

Every other character acted amazingly too; Barbara Baldavin plays Marilyn Mason and together with her sister they conspire to kill her brother played by Liam Dunn. Caroline Ellis is Emmy their Grandma and yet a fine art historian and Arch Bain as Edgar Murray as a traditional businessman trying to hide an evil motive. Last but not least Cally Steele as Cynthia Kane is sweet, efficient, reliable and also supports in other leads attempts of stopping the crime being uncovered.

WTF!! Do any of his books/movies end in a happy ending?? The Notebook was good...but sheesh, enough with the depressing endings already. I'm told that he writes about realistic situations that people deal with in real life. Understandable...but sometimes it's nice to see people who have sacrificed their whole lives to only get to a mediocre unhappy time in their lives - to finally find the true meaning of happiness and are able to live it out for the rest of their days. Don't we already know what really happens in real life?

I thought I might be disappointed viewing this film again after so many years. On the contrary, I was more impressed now than in my callow youth with its honesty and brave humour. In 1969, the transition among African-American groups from a predominant policy of conciliation and integration to one of confrontation and self-determination was still quite new, and more than a little controversial. It took courage and finesse to portray both the Establishment and the Anti-establishment as the caricatures they often closely approximated in real life. Special mention should be made of Arnold Johnson's performance: he successfully avoided having his character lapse into either sociopathy or buffoonery.

What can I say about the series dubbed the NEW OUTER LIMITS ... Hmm .... Only that this was one  of the creepiest and most wonderful shows that was created by imaginative and creative individuals. It surely elevated the horror anthology show to greater heights. The cast and writers added great elements that made it much better than the other genre programs out there. Through special effects and technology the show was able to craft episodes that grabbed the audiences’ attention in ways previously unimaginable. Even decades after it first aired, people still discuss the mysteries, conundrums and universes that the show has presented to viewers.

When I first saw this movie,I also expected "our boys" to be cute,and more like an extended version of the TV show. I didn't "get it" back then. But,years later,at a party YEARS later,at a 70s' type PAR-TAY,where certain substances had been smoked,inhaled,and with plenty of tequila,"HEAD" was on late at night.We watched it,and finally realized what "HEAD" was all about. It spoofed their own show,as shown in one song that called themselves,"a manufactured image".

This movie may be the best ever if you like watching movies and laughing and then subjecting your friends to watch those movies too. If you're anything like me, and you probably are, you'll be laughing for years to come at the jokes in this movie. One of the funniest parts is when Gus sharks some money off a guy with kids and then the guy takes those kids into the forest like Hansel and Gretel then he and his wife go home with them. The soup scene kitchen is rife with comic genius of buffoonery: "Inspection officer -- Here!"

A very weird , psychedelic , esoteric , ( and did I say weird ? : ) experience.But on at  least one level, it was curiously thought provoking,

Bringing with it a sense of hope; a resolve, a seed of opportunity, lingering and visible through the strange tones and visuals. I was able to make sense of what I felt, as opposed to sitting back in wonderment, to distill this all encompassing stream into a language that worked for me. Despite all its outward chaos, the essence of my trip still proved accessible, inspiring a sort of growing freedom to tackle life in a fresh, clearer perspective.

This movie is an awesome remake of the original by the same title . The movie was cool , despite  its weak start

The first act felt like a high school drama with clichés and predictability, however the suspense of the story developed with surprising action sequences and stunning effects. Each actor brought charm and ferocity to their performances and the actors’ dynamics played to the unpredictability of their adventure. The narrative held tight tension and continual moments of high stakes, supported by powerful and contemporary musical selections. At the heart of it, the movie held a beautiful statement on living courageously.

This film was made right in the area where I grew up and now live . I know personally most  of the people that are in it and even saw many of them while they were filming it

Watching the film I could connect more to the people that are actually here instead of some Hollywood movie that portrays reality wrong. Most people featured have direct connections to this city's rich culture and years of history. Watching it was very heartwarming to me, especially when you feel that the persons you see are the same people you were able to share important moments of your life.

This is one of Chaplin 's First National films from the period between his glorious Mutual shorts and the more  emotionally expansive feature films. This was an influential and renowned film at the time of its release and many filmgoers proclaimed Chaplin as one of the funniest comedians and lauded his dramatic skills too. With this feature, Chaplin gave further support to the culture of strong storytelling, sensational soundtrack and equally important iconic characters to facilitate emotional catharsis. He worked hard to bridge the art of technical and emotional significance; consequently gaining plaudits from contemporaries and remaining a culturally valid watch to this very day.

i did not read the book. nor do i care to. the movie was a beautiful romance, and i think women will enjoy it. no, it was not a "10" film, but it was enjoyable. women, if your man is bored as mine was, then watch it yourself. hurt is wonderful as the philosophic doctor who delivers a thoughtful monologue on "in love" and "loving. "also, if you like nick cage, he was terrific and funny. i enjoyed watching the developing romance. also, if you like Christian bale -- do see him in equilibrium.

I do not think that this movie deserves the low rating that most will give it. It's one of the best "teenager" horror films I've ever seen; and that's saying a lot. Nothing is left without an explanation to back it up, the characters and plot break countless horror movie stereotypes, and it has got nothing to do with some other horrible pieces we've been submitted to lately. (A clear example is the mindless "Saint Ange".) The first 30-40 minutes might be downright boring with the exception of the beginning, although some minor light mistakes can be easily spotted.

There are a select few cartoon films where animals or something "not human" is portraying human beings and I think that this film is one of them. Apart from a few points of the plot and the characters - this film could be changed with all people rather than mainly animals. Although - it's good someone did not - I feel the cats are jolly good in this film portraying humans! :-)This film also focuses on quite a lot of adult issues - which is rather odd for a Disney film.

I admit to being in awe of the Sea and have spent a number of years in the Navy, so I am somewhat biased on this one. I missed this documentary when it first came out but nagged various people to buy me it on DVD this Christmas (2002) and I got it! Some of the film is amazing and I have a lot of respect for those who make these kinds of documentaries, to see 200 ton Blue Whales 'cruising' through the Sea is an incredible sight, they looked like submarines.

When I saw this film at a festival years ago I was very impressed and I started to looking for  a way to get the film made

Eventually, I decided to invest in the project, bringing together several financiers, finding a director and constructing the screenplay. After five months of hard work, production started. I soon discovered that this journey was both interesting and hard. Dealing with multiple companies and hiring of talents put a tremendous amount of pressure on my shoulders. I needed to deliver something great as every film I supported became part of my reputation.

Is this a good movie? It's hard to say -- but in 1953, for many people, it was a remarkably effective movie, suspenseful, scary and then, amazingly, actually touching when "the old gentleman" meets his unhappy death at the end of the movie.Yes, what lurks in the Maze turns out to be something of a surprise and, for a lot of people, a hilarious one. But the basic idea (ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny) was a very real one at the time the book was written, and does have some basis in fact.

Just about every commentator has mentioned the way that some of the interview footage is superposed over the concert footage . Many believe this move provides insight into how fans feel as they experience the music. Not only is there great appreciation for the joy of being at a live performance, but we are also presented with fans contemplating and reflecting upon the raw emotion and intimacy within each track. We witness what it is like to express music, live on stage and how it makes the audience feels – powerful, thought provoking and the slightest hint of inspiration and discovery.

This movie felt so real. I actually felt all of the emotions portrayed here during my life at various times - that of both Rory and Michael. I have Duchene's Muscular Dystrophy like Rory so what you see here is exactly what I've actually felt myself. Some won't believe there ARE disabled people like Rory, full of anger and rebellion. I know they exist because I'm one of them.The story is great. For a drama, character-driven movie, the story moves fast. I was never bored, maybe partly because I was seeing stuff that is close to my heart.

It amazes me that production companies will sue because of reproductions they will not supply . I 've been looking  for this hard to find DVD from my favourite classic film but none of the shops I look in stock it. The idea that these companies will choose not to rerelease their films frustrates me as the consumers in these cases are not those looking for financial benefit, just an enjoyable film night. Recently the rare and highly sort after gem of classic films seems more of a war-chest kept hidden away rather than material to benefit a greater audience.

Great show ! About time a reality TV show comes along that closes generation gaps . Contestants range in ages  of anywhere from late teens to senior citizens - it's a great combination of learning , loving, teaching and making memories. The interactions between the young and older generations have truly made the show stand out. Together they work through age-appropriate challenges while getting to know one another, showing the viewers that there really is nothing like connecting over similar interests despite our generational gap. Seeing that there are lessons to be learnt from both young and old has enabled viewers of all ages to connect.

Blind Spot 's images are great . The action draws you in completely , even though the movie is a  bit dated now . The cinematography also stands out as impressive, from wide shots of locations that are vivid and arresting, to extreme closeups that capture tiny nuances of the character's emotions. While the plot itself takes a few confusing turns along the way, this only adds to the story's compelling narrative. Each character's motivations become all the more thrilling when obscured by the complexity of the overarching plot, forcing viewers to take their own imaginative leap.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The film captures and interprets his artistic method ('sketching' poems), his inspiration (the spirit of nature and its fantastic beauty) and his struggles to accept a harsh reality in the face of his idealist imagination.The film integrated excerpts of Miyazawa's poems into the plot beautifully. His relationships with his students was powerful, especially in one scene where he offers everything he has to a student who has just been caught stealing materials from the classroom.

The Simpsons of course started off with Christmas special `` Simpson 's Roasting On An Open Fire '' which had  first aired in 1989

The show got enormous critical praise and gained millions of loyal viewers around the world and launched an empire that's continued for more than two decades and four hundred episodes. The Simpson's hit us right in the nostalgic heartstrings.
