In fact I even sang it in a talent show with my sister and friend since I loved it that much. All three kittens are so cute and their mother is one of the prettiest cartoon cats I ever saw.

Mark Blankfield played Jekyll and Hyde.Michael McGuire was the dad.Tim Thomerson was the plastic surgeon.Did you even see this movie? I doubt it!Blankfield was fairly popular at this time for playing the pill-popping doctor on Fridays. Thomerson has been funny in anything he does, from movies to series to stand-up comedy. If I ever find this movie on DVD I will definitely buy it. I recorded this movie off of HBO back in '82 and have pretty much worn out the tape. One of the funniest takes on the Jekyll & Hyde theme ever.Of course.

If we could have "Separate Tables," why not "Separate Lies. "This becomes somewhat involved. A housekeeper's husband is killed when he is hit by a car while on a bicycle. The culprit turns out to be the woman she cleans for. The latter was having an affair with a friend and was driving the car with the lover in it when the accident occurred. To complicate matters further, the housekeeper once worked for the guy's parents and he had her jailed for stealing. Therefore, people will hesitate to believe that it was his car that caused the accident.

Exclusively for Coop 's lovers , though Clint Eastwood very strong though unobtrusive presence is a great asset of this  remake , we sadly discovered 

that many key pieces of character development and intertextuality with Westerns and old myths were cut out for pacing, making for a hollow action experience. There are still moments of decent humanist vibes in the process, especially at its concluding reveal, yet too many unfortunate occlusions subside what could’ve been an event much more self-aware. While it holds weight on the large scenes involving superheroes, smaller events and heartbeats don't seem to follow along throughout and arguably shortchange it.

Obviously the previous reviewers here are not fans of this genre, but I think this one is done quite well.It's twistedly cute clever & dark. This story brought back memories of the types of girls I was in love with as a child.Also, it makes me want to check out some of Nadia's other movies, many youtube comments about how hot she is in this video. Sure there is some Burton influence here, but I wouldn't say this Brad is trying to rip him off.He is just jumping in & adding his talents to a genre that I can appreciate.

Let 's be fair : there are no RULES for scriptwriting , so I wo n't say the movie SHOULD  have been written in a certain way. Rather, let’s look at it from a storyteller’s point of view; although the movie can be looked upon from a critic’s lens and criticism shared for future improvements, ultimately it was an entertaining experience with both tears and laughter to enjoy. As an avid reader and lover of cinema, there were a couple of creative moments that came off as unpredictable and genuinely awe-inspiring that makes the film worth watching and provides perspective on life's struggles.

At one time `Buddy Cop' movies ruled the box office. It seemed that every summer flocks of Beverly Hills Cop wannabes descended on our nation's theaters. Not any more. Lately the gusher has dried to barely a trickle. The drought has eased a bit recently with the release of Showtime, a movie that is a genuinely funny and consistently entertaining example of the genre.Mitch Preston is a dedicated cop. He's not a Dirty Harry type by any means. He's just incredibly focused professional who's completely intolerant of anything that gets in the way of the performance of his dutieslike, say, a T.V.

If you are looking for a phony Hollywood action movie , this wo n't be one for you . If  you’re wanting an emotion evoking thought piece - this is right up your alley! This story starts out simple enough and though at first sight you won't see your ordinary A-list hollywood thriller, your emotional thriller awaits with characters jumping off the page and lively moments both expected and unexpected alike. Beyond the slow build and mounting intensity lies an intertwined storyline with multidimensional characters aiming for love and redemption. Prepare for scenes that might seem crazy, and venture beyond expectations, because sometimes the more unconventional tales get rewarded.

I love this movie a lot . I must get this on DVD . I have 2 VHS copies ,  but i know

DVD's are much better and that will definitely give me better clarity when watching it. This movie was made such a long time ago , but the power of its message is still true even to this day. So far , I've shown it to my family and some of my friends and they loved it. But I would love to watch it again with the new found clarity a DVD could give me .

This is a remake of the anime classic from the 80's, and this one is even better. Sylia, Nene, Linna, and Priss are all back as the Knight Sabers in their hard-suits battling the robotic boomers. The animation is crisp, the characters are well-developed, and the action rocks. Priss is a singer in her regular job, so the series features some wonderful songs as well. There is a fair amount of violence, but most of it is against robots, and there is some fan service, but nothing too racy.

Even after nearly 20 years apart, the original members of Black Sabbath have not lost a thing. In this concert, they perform their best songs from their heyday (1970-1978), including "N.I.B. ", "War Pigs", and "Paranoid".Also included is priceless backstage footage with interviews and retrospectives into their days as the top hard rock band on the planet. The comments of Ozzy, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Bill Ward are just as interesting and intriguing to watch as the fabulous onstage performances.A must-see for all Sabbath and Ozzy fans.

This was a riveting film , one that really drew me in . I 'm a big fan of William  Douglas ' movies, so I was thrilled to get to watch one that he 'd directed himself

I was hooked right away with the amazing visuals and talented cast of actors. Douglas created a complex and multilayered narrative that kept me wanting more. What was more, the music complemented each scene so effectively that it felt like part of the movie. I'd heard such wonderful things about William Douglas' films, and watching this one really gave me a new appreciation for his artistry.

I caught this show a few times when I was young and it was playing tilt, My parents loved it and now in syndication I feel what they feel. This show did what the original limits and twilight zone (new and old) couldn't do. This show used some old ideas and some truly original ideas.I still cannot believe Jonathan Glassner and brad wright did this. Those guys were producers on stargate sg-1. The show kept the audience entrenched in the story and set a truly scary atmosphere. This is what was not there in the new twilight zone.

This is a well directed Columbo episode , with also some good character but the story just does n't really  come together

Although there is some interesting dialogue and many great performances, this Columbo episode struggles to find a balance. Characters are flatly presented and while they seem integral to the mystery, none of them quite carry the necessary arc. Consequently, the climax lacks oomph as a sense of accomplishment and triumph is lost. With such talented actors involved in a typically great Columbo premise, the script needs a bit more TLC for it to truly resonate.

I got some free tickets via the Times to see this little know Irish movie called 'Inside I 'm Dancing '. I was so excited to get tickets to see Inside I'm Dancing and to have such an intimate experience in a theater as small as it is was icing on the cake. Once I got inside I saw why so many have heard such good things. Not only was the plot unique, but it showed its Irish roots to a tee. I could relate to the characters and the Irish-inspired set design immediately had my eyes glued to the screen.

Warning -- this film has some amazingly graphic images and should never be seen by kids.The artist who this story  comes from was praised for their shocking scenes, but the violence and gory moments presented may leave a lasting impact on viewers of all ages.This is especially true for children, who may be left with nightmares that could cause distress.Though those old enough to watch can appreciate this amazing story, it should be approached with extreme caution and ideally without children present. Even teens might not have the maturity to make the right decisions with what they are exposed to on screen.

Although this film never attained commercial notoriety, my experience has led me to conclude that many well-done pieces of artistic expression often do not gain mass appeal. The story line depicts a young boy stealing a car and embarking on a surreal, dream-like adventure with very little basis in our conceptualization of time and space. Therefore, anyone who attempts to view this film from the perspective of its conformity to reality will likely be disappointed; it is not intended to be "realistic." It is, however, intended to be metaphoric with extensive symbolism apparent to those with superb attention to detail.

I was 19 or 20, years old at the time and living in Salt Lake City, Utah and I still remember the new dome theater, called the century 21. Layback chairs that rocked and a new sound system, large screen and huge open space between the screen and the packed theater. We felt all the excitement of a new preview screening of a film. Ta da da daa da ta da dada dada... I can still hear the opening music ringing trumpet and the crash of cymbals. I loved the interplay of characters and the filmed vistas.

I'm not going to go into too much depth, but Showtime was a pretty funny movie. There wasn't any slapping-your-knee funny scenes (that I can remember), but it had it's moments. The cast is pretty good, Robert De Niro is good as usual and Eddie Murphy pulls off a pretty funny performance. Rene Russo was just fine in the film, no complaints there. There were two characters in the story that I liked that they didn't explain much at all. The first one was Trey Sellars' (Eddie Murphy's) buddy at the gym played by Ken Campbell.

The Paul Kersey of DEATH WISH 3 is very far removed from the Paul Kersey of the original film . He is more closely connected with the Wild West Gunfighter - acting without legal authority, wreaking revenge and answering to a moral law only he understands. While not in his action capacity, Paul seeks to talk the innocent people into having a good time and develop personal connections with people around him. All these aspects make him even more lonely and extraordinary, as many seem to understand the world only in its logical perspective.

The Child 's Play series is n't a favourite of mine , but Bride Of Chucky is actually an okay  movie. I found Bride of Chucky to be quite enjoyable compared to other movies in the Child's Play series. I appreciated the comedy injected into the movie which made it funny, as well as the plot twists, adding a sense of drama. Of course, as with all horror movies, there was suspense too, enough to keep the movie interesting throughout. To make the movie complete there were special effects, particularly from Chucky.

I thought Besson 's film managed to do without words what few films have been able to do with them  -

By conveying an array of emotions through imagery and music alone. He tells an affecting and memorable story. Through the non-linear plot, Besson captured in the perfect mixture of melancholic visuals and jovial tunes. Watching the film and tracing Besson's cinematography journey allows us to truly observe human values of hope and resiliency as Lou adapts to a changing society. After all, being heard is more important than having to express our stories in words.

Due to its predictable , second-rate title , ( the one it was distributed under in Italy , at least  ) Pietro Germi'sDivorce Italian Style was undeservedly written off

It was released in Italy to tepid critical response and audiences weren't terribly enthralled either. There seemed to be an understanding at the time that a movie labeled a "comedy of manners" wasn't really deserving of that 'second-rate title.' Alas, had anyone bothered to watch it and recognized the irony of that title, it is sure that they would be sufficiently rewarded.

"Live Together, Die Alone" is divided into three main story lines, and each one of them alone would have been enough for a great episode. So when you put all of them together, you have a great ^ 3 episode. It was a daring move to give the flashbacks of a season finale to a character (Desmond) who had only appeared in 3 episodes up to that point, but it worked: his backstory is absolutely fascinating to watch, both informative about the past of the island & the Swan station itself and honestly moving.

It was a terrific movie ! I like to watch it again and again . The actors were awesome . The plot was extremely gripping and I didn't even feel like blinking till the end! The visual effects were quite remarkable. The director managed to narrate a powerful story using simple visuals and background music which really enriched the story telling experience. Watching this movie also increased my enthusiasm towards cinematic experiences and everytime I sit down to watch the same film, I find myself discovering some finer details. Overall, it was an outstanding film and I would love to watch it multiple times and cherish each time for sure!

I am a long time fan of Luc Besson 's work , and for about as long as I 've  been able to recognize it , I have always loved his imagination and unique artistic sensibilities

He constantly transports us to seemingly fantastical worlds with his craft of story-telling, while reminding us to embrace different lifestyles that embrace ethics and love that exist within even the most alien landscapes. While many times have pushed boundaries, his desire to achieve pure emotion in his stories can also bring an enchanting nostalgic mood to even some of his more “family” movies.

Considering it's basically low-budget cast, this is a surprisingly good flick about the life and death of rock pioneer Buddy Holly. Gary Busey stars as Holly, who was one of the first to use an electric guitar for pretty much all his music. Backed up by his Crickets, Holly had a string of hits and became a bona fide star before his death in a plane crash along with Richie Valens and The Big Bopper. The film follows his rise to stardom, marriage to his sweetheart and eventual death. I like this film and believe that you will too.

I never realized what a fabulous dancer Lana Turner was until I saw this movie . She was only 19  in it and her beauty and grace already carried a sense of maturity 

Despite the modest storyline and script, she conveyed emotion with exquisite timing and unparalleled artistry. From beginning to end, Turner immersed herself in her character with soul-stirring charisma. Her talent was quite un-rivalled and as I watched, my appreciation and admiration for her increased. Her character really came alive in the dynamic ballroom sequences, with those long skirts spinning and flouncing; twirling in perfect balance, juxtaposed with the power in the footwork and partnering.

A great movie . The movie was even better then the commercials put on . And believe it or not  the effects and details used were really really remarkable . The actors performance was perfect. Every one from the youngest kid to the oldest veteran have worked their part amazingly. The sound track used really worked on to emphasize each emotions during every moment . Story of the movie has managed to involve a moral as well as drive home some very important social messages. In summary this was one of the greatest movies that had graced the screen for some time. I highly recommend this movie for everyone!

If you expect that this movie is full of action and grabbing you from the start then do n't watch  it

If you're looking for a thrilling, suspenseful, non-stop movie night experience then this is not the film for you. Although it has plenty of action, it's the subtle nuances that really pull at you and create an indelible effect on your memory. The visuals and storyline is brought together at a gentle pace, giving enough breathing time to really consider what’s happening, making sure all points are understandable, absorbing and believable.

Well, what's wrong with the title "Separate Lies" (accused elsewhere of not being "exciting"). It's cunning, subtle and a bit poetic. (Of course there's a Phil Collins song and a James Belushi film called "Separate Lives", which are alluded to here.) But the real point is the ethical dilemmas of telling lies at different levels that the film probes. OK, it's not an "in-your-face" hilarious title, but then it's not an in-your-face hilarious film. Please give British films like this a chance.

I still ca n't describe what to feel when I received this by the fnac site . Such a rare  occasion where I saw a painting displayed in the actual gallery setting that I only saw through a computer before. This painting quickly became very dear to me as I felt as if it completed me, showing me I belonged somewhere. Although a touch more surreal than expected it fulfilled its own destiny. That of painting my sorrows away, of freeing me to rest in it's tranquillity. Each colour shaped a place to pause and catch my breath, calming the tense exchange between my intellect and the wildly raging emotions beneath.

At first I didn't think I would like this movie, but as it progressed it became better and better. I love music and I was impressed with how well Cage could fake the movements of playing a mandolin. My son was with me and he also like the movie a lot for its music and the story and the way the story unfolded--- slowly showing how Corelli won the girls heart. The acting and the story were both well done and well directed. At first Corelli's bravado was irritating, but soon he grew on you.

Sit back and let Director Bharatbala lead us into a visual and sensual voyage of the mind and spirit of  Bhairavi. Director Bharatbala succeeds in captivating our attention, by compelling the journey through cinematography with precision. His artistry is enhanced by mind blowing animations and low key direction making it an enjoyable visual journey into this wondrous universe of fantasy. With clear attention to intricate details like hue and movements he succeeds in demonstrating to his audiences the complex philosophical narrative while leaving us room to delve deep in personal perspectives as well. Ultimately we come away moved by our spiritual escape which brings life to Bhairavi through divine possibilities.

SPOILERSI love the Simpsons , and I have seen every single episode that had ever come out . I must  say , every time an episode has a twist ending or an emotional one , I just get so hooked into the show . Recently , the series finally came out with an episode revolving around Mr.Burns. It took a full turn and presented us a very different version of the character, who had a much kinder heart than usual. I couldn’t have predicted what kind of life decisions he would make, and I was thoroughly surprised with how the episode ended.

A mix of 70's drug humor along with parody of medicine and classic story line. As I've often said about this flick - if you don't get it - you're way lame..... Classic lines such as (parapharsed) "I've got this erection and it won't go away no matter how many times I do it. You're a nurse, what can you give me for it?" Nurse replies "all I have is 5 dollars and my wedding ring..." Great sound track.The classic "Hyde's got nothing to hide".

Gary Busey did a splendid job playing the rock-n-roll legend Buddy Holly ( 1936-59 ) . He does have a  remarkable similarity in look and personality to the real person, when Busey delivered that line from a live performance and instant a thrill surged through my heart . From his believable Texas drawl and intensely animated face when playing Buddy to a solid drummer off-beat without fail; I could understand how some movie goers had difficulty in not seeing Buddy back up and entertaining at those grand 1950s gigs. Furthermore, the individual resemblance to Buddy by Gary Busey absolutely resonated to the crowd’s enthusiam.

As a film buff, I obviously had read all the excruciating reviews and funny, sarcastic comments about this film (my favourite being Woody Allen's quip "If I had my life to live over again I wouldn't change anything ... except for seeing the musical remake of Lost Horizon"). Therefore I've never been able to watch it without smirking at the choreography/set/songs etc. Just recently I came across a widescreen DVD and watched it for the first time in years, along with a friend who had never heard of the film's reputation.

Warning--this film has some amazingly graphic images and should never be seen by kids.The artist who this story is all about was indeed a fine Korean painter who rose up from the lowest depths to become their greatest painter. Unfortunately, in so many ways, this guy was also a jerk in so many ways. Some of this was the artistic temperament and what may have seemed annoying was just his demanding nature when it came to art. But, other times he was simply a drunk jerk--especially when he was on his way to becoming a great artist.

Try to look for another movie that is such a trip without having a story or plot and you 'll  probably be unable

Other examples may be horror films or music videos where there is no actual plot. Music videos such as Led Zeppelin’s Stairway To Heaven show iconic images with each successive guitar riff while horror films like Evil Dead place an audience in the middle of a crazy horror flick with almost no build up or structure. Sci-fi films that build a trippy vibe such as Repo Man can transport an audience from one fantastical environment to another or completely dystopian experiences with movies such as Brazil.

If you are looking for a phony Hollywood action movie, this won't be one for you. If the Truth is what you seek, rent or buy this. From a true story, the movie attempts to capture the heart of what was/is happening in South Africa (and many other places).For historical knowledge, this rates up there with stories such as "The Pianist," "Schindler's List" or "Nuremberg." Millions of people today have no clue what apartheid is or that it even exists. This movie may help them learn, and may even help them dig deeper.

No, I have not seen the original series and I won't compare the two if I had. This series is filmed in Canada in Vancouver and Victoria, British Columbia. The series is well-written in a different story each week. Some are little out there but most of the time it is the quality of the story telling. I loved the Afterlife episode with Clancy Brown and Barbara Gerrick and the Deprogrammers episode with the irresistible Brent Spiner as a Deprogrammer in a world where humans have become slaves to a lizard reptilian species.

Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character , unable to speak , living in a world incompatible with modern life . He stands for all dreamers who defy their fate and seek for their rightful place. A victim of constant misunderstandings and illusions, Don Quixote clings to his outmoded ideals with courage, determination and nobility. This impassive spirit reveals the power of imagination and transforms the improbable into the real. Unconditionally accepting the humble privileges offered to him by the chaotic world he desperately desires to influence, his world is delivered by conscience.

The film is n't perfect by any means but despite this it is very fun and amusing to watch . Despite its flaws, the film still packs plenty of humor, making it one of the better comedies released in recent years. You can’t help but be won over by the lightheartedness and goodwill that envelops each and every character. Viewers are made to care about even the minor characters and will find plenty to smile about in its wacky story lines. It's just a joy to watch how even the silliest of concepts can be a source of endless entertainment.

This musical has a deep meaning which is appreciated by only a few . The wise can see the wisdom  in the words and learn about things far beyond themselves. This musical shines light onto otherwise unthought-of wisdom. The musical tells of personal beliefs, hope, power and wonder which teaches valuable life lessons. In fact, it has become so renowned that some music and theatrical studies have implemented pieces of the work into their programmes to further their understanding of theatrical art. By experiencing this unique production, it may give each individual insight into becoming more wholeheartedly conscious of who we are.

This film , like much of their music , is either underrated or unnoticed by the casual observer . It  

Although not as flashy or award-winning as its more celebrated counterparts, the film tells an incredibly simple yet thought-provoking story, with the true charm of it all the immersive soundtrack by the Beach Boys. On top of that, it demonstrates the tender nature of brotherly love and has touching moments between Carl and Brian which bring home a somber lesson. As an ensemble, they created something almost too good to be real in their family dynamite and expressive lens of subtle commentary.

`` Head '' is a film that has held up well since its original release date in 1968 . The  film follows the members of a Detroit rock band on the rise and their story as they are taken advantage of by the entertainment industry. In a timely reminder of exploitation in the entertainment industry, the members of "Head" have seen their careers crash, barely scraped by on money, and bandmate Dale ditches out when his loyalty is questioned. They learn some harsh life lessons but remain resilient as they dodge wrong turns and trade labels and directors.

People comparing this movie to big blockbusters like Lord of the Rings or the Matrix will inevitably be disappointed with the way this movie turned out. Although it lacks in the big special effects department and there are no battles with hundreds of extras, there is still a masterful amalgamation of two old folk tales here. The acting talent, although not A-list, is still great and the interaction between the characters is perhaps more sincere than in a larger movie with an A-list cast. My particular favourite from this movie is Bridget Fonda, whose performance as the Snow Queen herself was quite moving, assisted enormously by a stupendous wardrobe and makeup.

I love the TV contest . Hate to see it end . There are so many talented contestants . It  has been a great opportunity for them to showcase their skill and prove their mettle

Each one has tried hard, demonstrated the various qualities required to emerge successful and highlighted their qualities of resilience and will power to succeed. It has truly been amazing to watch and experience this show where all the best qualities come together and lead to success. After being a part of this competition I'm really satisfied, knowing that such great performers can find a huge platform and be appreciated for their skill.

As far as I know I've seen most of Lucio Fulci's films, with the exception of some later ones that are popping up on DVD now, and I would have to say this was his best "pre-zombie" offering. In fact it beats out his later movies hands-down. This is a tale of superstition and suspicion in a small Italian town out in the middle of nowhere, where young boys are dying mysteriously. It's no mystery how they died, I guess, it's more who's doing it. Is it a woman that the townspeople have always considered a witch?

I 've been looking forward to seeing this film ever since I first caught the trailer , and I 'm  excited that it's finally time to see it

I went and picked up my tickets the day before, the atmosphere was abuzz with excitement. I was nearly bursting with anticipation at this point, the wait felt unbearable. Finally the doors opened, I and everyone else headed eagerly inside and I quickly picked my seat and prepared myself. The theatre lights dimmed, everyone grew silent and all that was heard was the projector as the credits started rolling.

WTF ! ! Do any of his books/movies end in a happy ending ? ? The Notebook was good ... I never seen a single Nicholas Sparks movie/book have a happy ending, his stories all have unhappy ending at some point. Despite this, fans all over the world are devoted to Sparks, I cannot deny it. I just cannot comprehend why; his romantic storylines all lack any solid footing, crumbling at the simplest misstep, typically by the man himself. His writing all blurs together, causing pain and confusion. Though everytime I watch The Notebook I forget his sad reputation.

Charles Chaplin's 'Shoulder Arms' of 1918 was his longest film to date, though, at just over 45 minutes in length, it was not quite a feature film. With World War One just drawing to a close, many popular entertainers of the time were doing their part to inspire their native troops, and Chaplin was no exception. And so the lovable Tramp went to war! The film begins with the Tramp in training, and the character is hilariously inept at even the simplest military drills, including marching and gun-slinging, much to the disgust of his drill sergeant.

This movie gives us some WWII history along with some touching romance, a little fantasy and meaningful emotion - and beautiful scenery. Nicholas Cage never fails us, and here again does a great job. And so do the other principle characters. One key charater, the physician/father played by John Hurd, delivers (to his daughter) one of the best definitions of love I've ever heard. Some of the events are a bit too coincidental to be real, but I excused that, knowing that this is partly fairy tale and fantacy. My wife and I really liked the film.

Indeed, Cynthia Watros is in this movie as Elizabeth talking to Desmond. Though I'm just wondering how she ended up as a 'rehab patient'(?) where Hurley is also in there trying to reduce his weight (as seen from the previous episodes).Anyway, this last episode is really suspended. The ending is not so understandable. I think the writer did expect the audience that there is a season 3 coming.I just hope the next season will give light to more unclear/hanging events that were happened.Just can't wait further for season 3.

I never realized what a fabulous dancer Lana Turner was until I saw this movie. She was only 19 years old and gorgeous. What a pleasure to watch her dance with George Murphy. The story line was typical for its day but the dancing was really special. I never tire of watching Fred and Ginger but Lana Turner in this movie was just as terrific. I always thought of Lana as a so-so actress who tended to over act. She should have done more dancing and less of the Maddam X and Peyton Place roles. I had a new appreciation for her after seeing this movie and her wonderful dancing.

What an incredible story and what a beautiful film ! Hat 's off to Ben Daniels , Lavinia Currier and  all the team . It's a true inspiring movie, made with great ambition and professional care. I love how Daniels captured and exemplified our connections, universal courage, heart-breaking battles with darkness, perseverance and authenticity in every emotion shown. Daniels drew on perfect performances and camera magic of his special ones to go beyond expectations and barriers and touch deeper soulful impact. Lavinia Currier knows the storytelling , even on emotionally hard layers she illuminated brilliantly the challenging search to clarity, dreams and purity within ourselves.

I saw this movie when it first came out in 1973 and loved it . Since then I 've searched  everywhere for it

Since 1973, I have seen the movie numerous times. Everytime I watch it, I experience the same delight and excitement. However, finding it has been almost impossible as it wasn't available in most of the usual places such as stores, libraries or even television. Thankfully, I have been able to watch it digitally due to its remastered versions, making it readily available in streaming sites and different platforms.

After a somewhat slow start I thought this movie about the Italian occupation of a Greek island during World War II picked up and became a quite enjoyable watch for a couple of hours, from primarily two points of view. The love triangle is an interesting one and strikes me as believable, because I know it happened in various places under occupation. Penelope Cruz played Pelagia, a young Greek girl engaged to be married to Mandras (Christian Bale). I had questions about the depth of their love from the start, but their future was torn apart when Italy invaded Greece, and Mandras went off to fight.

This film was one of three that were later combined by Chapin into a compilation that was released to theaters in the late 1950s under the title "The Chaplin Review".This was an odd film in some ways because later in life, Chaplin was anti-war and his movies stressed peace and brotherhood. This film, in contrast, is a propaganda comedy meant to bolster the US efforts in WWI. It's truly odd to see Charlie as the "super soldier" who single-handedly captures 13 Germans, casually and coolly shoots several Germans in mere seconds as a marksman and then goes behind enemy lines to try to capture the Kaiser himself!

The movie starts with a board meeting at a major advertising agency . Putney Swope is on the board for  the nomination of their next CEO. At the last minute, he slips his own name onto the ballot, is chosen unanimously and, much to the surprise of his fellow board members, reveals he has come to challenge their archaic practices. With the power of his unexpected election, Putney confronts the stodgy bureaucracy head on with no qualms about defending his position, allowing it to dictate how the office runs and also cut employee salaries and many workers begin to protest Putney.

I usually give horror films around 6/10 , but this one caught my eye . House of Wax was by  far the most daring horror film I have ever seen . From the scenery to the performances, I was both spooked and entertained . The twists and turns had my head spinning and it kept me invested from the first few moments . I was screaming and gripping my seat at every creepy twist . This truly was the horror movie to beat ! It’s honestly become a movie I find myself returning to time and time again.

Was very fortunate to see the movie Hari Om at The Bermuda International Film Festival . It was the opening  night feature film and one I knew would create an emotion stirring the audience

It did not disappoint! From the incredible cinematography and breathtaking location in Fiji to the exemplary direction and quality writing and performances, the story engaged and stayed with us beyond the opening night film experience. Even walking through the warmly lit corridors of the theater post-show the aura of film appreciation persisted.The film fostered friendships and kinship in me for the Fijian people that endured civil unrest only recently; indeed a very unexpected feeling from watching a piece of cinema!

Oh I remember watching this show at 4:00 p.m. during my junior high days . It was not a pleasant  sight, to say the least. My heart raced with anticipation as my friends and I tuned in to each episode. But it only got worse as each week ended, the characters experiencing immense peril yet remaining unresolved. Nothing felt worse then the unmet suspense building throughout the week that never came. But I guess that's how a television series has to remain. We waited until the weekend finally arrived and brought resolution to that unresolved fate.

When I was 10 ( currently 14 ) , I vowed to never see a movie that I knew would  give me nightmares again. From then on, I'm much more careful and deliberate about the types of media I consume, researching the background, rating, and plot prior to viewing them. That said, I have still watched some scary movies - I have gained some courage! - but often these were made by trusted sources. Not wanting to avoid new ideas, I’ve opted to watch shows, games, and stories outside of the horror genre.

This movie was great . It had everything a true action fan could want . Plenty of people getting shot  , plenty of action and some incredible visuals . The star performances in this movie added to its overall appeal as well. All of the main actors had terrific performances that took the film to another level. Moreover, the villain was a major attraction for the audience. The chemistry between the star and villain was great which made for an engaging experience for everyone. From dramatic close ups to sudden twist in the plot, this movie had plenty of things going for it that made it unforgettable.

I can't say how many times that one line has made me laugh or how often I've described that scene to folks not familiar with this film. I saw it the year it was released, I was 19. I don't think there were a dozen people in that East Village theater that night. For years I thought we were the only ones who saw it. Nice to see here that others found it as hysterical as I had, and see it's lasting value despite the time gone by. Rent it, buy it or steal it.... a must see.

This film was made right in the area where I grew up and now live. I know personally most of the property owners of the various locations used in the film. As a teenager, I worked in the fields surrounding the isolated road shown late in the film with Ron Perlman, Jonathon Furr, and the car. I am told that Jonathon Furr and Ben Allison are are natives of NC. I was fortunate to see it at a local showing. At that showing was one of the people who helped select locations and secure props, such as the bus (1938 Greyhound) used in the movie.

Without going into any details of a good ... if a somewhat provocative ... TV movie , there seems to  be some distinct advantages that those type of shows offer, which I'll attempt to articulate briefly. By displaying real life conflicts that are popular within society, viewers are able to understand the given struggles within their own experiences. We don't just witness a situation unfold and hope the protagonists manage to escape their seemingly turbulent lives, but see some constructive means by which they come to term and properly handle these issues.

You know, people who make comedies so often forget it's really ok to be outrageous. Well, not this time. Unconditional Love has it all. Barry Manilow and a dwarf in a movie with Cathy Bates as the romantic lead...and it works. Not only does it work, it works very very well. In fact, I think it's perfect. I laughed so hard I think I hurt myself yet the main characters were all so human, so honest, and so very real. But isn't that where great comedies come from?

Mark Blankfield played Jekyll and Hyde.Michael McGuire was the dad.Tim Thomerson was the plastic surgeon.Did you even see this movie , Jekyll and Hyde? If you haven't seen it yet then you should, because it's awesome. All of the actors did a great job portraying their characters. Jekyll's best friend Ray (Steve Levitt) was there to help him understand what's happening to him. Chris Williams was also a good character as Doc Rudy Sussman, he played the role to perfection. Ray and Jekyll's ex-girlfriend Beverly (Julie Avery) help add even more depth to the movie.

This film had about everything one could wish when viewing it originally, at the end of the 1960's decade. It was immensely entertaining, and provided a contemporary view of the many changes which had occurred during that period - and were still ongoing - in terms of the Black Power movement, Vietnam, and the volatile movement which followed the quieter, preceding postwar 1950's.All of this and one of the funniest films, then or now.Viewing it for the second time recently, I was surprised to find it as engrossing as when seen originally.

We saw La Spettatrice last night @ the Chicago International Film Festival & we were both immensely moved by it. This is a haunting tale of loneliness & missed connection in which the longing for intimacy conflicts with our fear of revealing too much about ourselves to another. The three leads (Barbora Bobulova as Valeria, Brigitte Catillon as Flavia, Andrea Renzi as Massimo) are all excellent and the dynamic between them is very surprising. After all the movies which devalue older women, it's wonderful to see Flavia (who is a law professor at a university in Rome) presented as beautiful & sensual as well as seductive & powerful.

OK, so I loved Rachael Ray before, but now, I ADORE her! How innovative. I love that she has a cooking section- I admit that occasionally I skip that part, only because it makes me WAAAY too hungry! But I also love that you can get the next day's grocery list on her website. I love that she has regular helpers and that she's made some of her viewers become her regulars. I love how personable she is and how creative she is. I also like how she does her Mystery Guests.

Another go round with the monkey king going west .... sort of.Beginning in the middle of some action the movie  quick jumps into ancient legend. After observing a skillful battle between two forces, the protagonist launches himself into an unexpected adventure! On this trip west the man brings together three familiar animal friends that unexpectedly join the group of now 4, destined for unimaginable heights. Stunning monsters and a collection of unexplored magical creatures set the background of a masterpiece now ready for filming. There's bound to be some sort of surreal surprise to further captivate the minds and imaginations of the watchers!

I 'm not going to go into too much depth , but Showtime was a pretty funny movie . There  was a lot of sarcasm 

The main characters of the movie were Scott, David and Natalia, who provided for a good source of comic relief and played off one another quite well. Scott and David, although competitive at first, became good friends and ended up fighting side-by-side. In the end, the movie taught a powerful message of loyalty and friendship and included an abundant of laughs along the way. Each scene managed to deliver clever punches to the audience which I found refreshing and comical.

I had the chance to watch Blind Spot in Barcelona and I enjoyed it tremendously. I thought it to be one of the most captivating movies that I'd seen for a long time. One of the best points of the film was to meet new fresh faces and great actors behind them in unexpectedly and brilliantly filmed great locations. The three heroes share a chemistry on screen that runs all across the film making it so thrilling. They are set on outstanding landscapes spotted by such an original eye (the DOP's work is just great) that makes you feel like you are discovering them for the first time.

The movie is incredible , it has a sound track which sets the tone for the movie . THe lines  

The movie's performances were a key factor to it's success, the actors matched perfectly to their roles, carrying the emotion and deep feeling that ran throughout the movie. I was most touched by the child performance, in which his character won over audiences by displaying kindness and integrity. The movie’s powerful music and setting fully transported me into its imaginary world. Different locations are used as diverse as deserted beach sides and awe inspiring sites with lots of foliage.

I loved this film, which I have just seen at the Philadelphia film festival. In March 2005 I went to India with 2 friends, and this movie was very real. I related to everything, and savored every moment. The characters are believable, the story poignant and the ending realistic, but not sentimental. I also enjoyed the discussion with the director after the showing. This movie shows very well the blending, but not complete mixing of 2 worlds (East and West). The supporting cast was wonderful, depicting the life a tourist encounters in India quite realistically.

Telling the story wouldn't be the point at all, would it? Barnens ö, spelled almost like "booné aww" is the title for that brilliant novel of the late seventies that shocked a lot of people, including myself.Children's Island is the title, and what an island. In the book, Raine, the main character has The Guiness World Record Book as his own Bible. And he's keen on breaking new records himself. In particular the youngest person under water for three minutes.The story is, as most Swedish films and books of the time, deep, consciously provocative and awe inspiring.

This Oscar-winning short film ( 40 minutes ) , based on a short story by William Faulkner , takes us  to Mississippi of 1940's. It starts out with Eula Varner who, driven by a turbulent past, attempts to force herself to become financially independent. Unfortunately, she faces obstacle after obstacle as no one gives her a fair chance in business, education or social activities. Eula quickly loses faith, until an old man gives her new advice. Eula and this old man learn valuable lessons, showing each other and us that difficult situations do not define our potential in life.

Little Gus is a ten year old delinquent . He runs away from his parents and decides to go on  a adventure to the country. Little Gus's adventure didn't last long however as soon he was arrested by the police. When they brought him back home his parents were shocked and completely devastated at what he had done. Nonetheless, they hugged him and explained how much they cared for him, so as to understand why he acted the way he had. They were going to get him help, as he could no longer wander the streets.

"A Slight Case of Murder" is an excellent TV movie, which is defiantly worth the price of a rental. William H. Macy is great as a movie critic who accidentally kills his mistress, and then has to try to conceal the crime. Although that may sound dark, the film is actually quite light hearted and funny, with many memorable lines ("Acting is harder than I thought- you ever see BODY HEAT? I think I owe Bill Hurt an apology" and my personal favourite "For next week answer these two questions about film noir, What do these people do during the day?

I usually give horror films around 6/10, but this one caught my eye. House of Wax was by far the best horror film I have seen... Even better than the Amityville Horror.Paris Hilton was quite good in this and I must say, has a good future ahead. Her death scene was probably the coolest. I'll just say how she dies...She gets a giant pole right between her eyes and they close-ups on and everything. Gory, eh? Brian Van Holt was very good as both the killers, Bo and Vincent (Vincent had the long hair).

If you like who-dun-its, you will like this film, considered the best Italian detective story (giallo), Fulci has done.It's not Mickey Spillane for sure. There are scenes designed to disturb anyone.Many would be offended by a local beauty trying to seduce a 12-year-old boy. She was joking, but she was naked nonetheless, and he would have jumped at the chance to jump her bones. She also tries to tempt the local priest.Young boys are turning up missing, and there are several interesting suspects. You have to watch carefully to discover the killer. Can you?

I think this show was right on the money for me . I watched it over the plane but there  was still something so much better watching it on the big screen. The experience of watching the show in a large theatre was mesmerising. Being so close to the big screen I was able to truly experience each second as it went by. I especially appreciated the lighting, colours and tones of each scene. Everything just seemed so clear, so realistic that I was tempted to believe that I was really there experiencing the events first-hand. It made my experience more worthwhile.

No real plot , no character development , no Scorcese-level direction , but seriously , were you really expecting any ? It was entertaining nevertheless, due to its perfectly timed soundtracks, word plays, snappy dialogue and witty observations that left the audience giggling away. We watched and came out smiling. This one-time screening film has to offer enough delight to excuse its lack of richness. The eclectic spirit of the film plays homage to a fondly remembered indie favourite, proving again why the talk of a film sequel simply doesn’t fade away. It pays tribute to a cult classic.

I had the chance to watch Blind Spot in Barcelona and I enjoyed it tremendously . I thought it to  be one of the most thrilling pieces of cinema I have ever watched. I couldn't get the eerie, creepy atmosphere of the film out of my mind even after I got out of the theater. I was totally surprised when I found out that the story behind Blind Spot is loosely based on true events and an incident that occurred in the 1920's in Norway. This certainly made me appreciate it even more.

The Aristocats is really quite charming, and is rated far too low on IMDb. The songs aren't as memorable as the ones in the Jungle Book, but they weren't bad at all. The animation is really lovely, the best sequence being the landscape of Paris in general. It looked beautiful. This is probably Disney's most relaxing animation I think, and as another reviewer quite rightly said, who doesn't love cats? Another great piece of animation was O' Malley looking into Duchess's eyes, as their romance was so believable while not obvious.

This movie got better with time . I ca n't believe that it has been forty years since I saw  it for the first time! Today, I look at the same movie with an entirely different perspective. Time and experiences in life has truly enriched how I now interpret this classic. This movie was way ahead of its time when it came out and audiences found its humour innovative and cutting edge. With every viewing I can appreciate this movie more as I appreciate the tremendous effort and creativity put in to it by its creative minds.

Anyone who has seen Ali G before , should be well prepared for the full motion picture that is 'Ali  G Indahouse'. The movie brings Ali G's blend of hip hop-styled irreverence to a movie screen full of political satire and subversive slapstick. It’s a humorous and pointed commentary on issues of race and class in British society and still manages to appeal to a broad range of ages and demographics. Packed full of bold yet lovable characters, a breakneck narrative style, hilarious vignettes and hilarious dialogue - Ali G Indahouse will be an off-the-wall viewing experience like nothing else.

Great movie. Post-apocalyptic films kick ass. This one is no exception. Kept up the pace and interest without a speck of dialogue (mainly through some good character development). The fight between Reno and the Hero was tight. I also liked the use of cave paintings and medieval-like weapons to show how primitive and savage mankind had become without their technology and guzzaline. The connection between the beginning and end was a little spacey, that is, I had a hard time understanding the distances between the hotel and the opening sequence.

Whoever plays the part of J. Douglas Williamson in the strip poker scene does a wonderful job . He apparently  did a lot of preparation and makes all his motions very life like. The realism of the poker scene shows how devoted he was to the role. All his friends can attest to how much work Williamson put into making the scene look real and quite intense. Furthermore, he seems very comfortable in character, appearing totally natural, providing viewers a seamless narrative throughout the game. From taking shots to exclaiming witty comebacks, his convincing performance will definitely entertain the audience.

I viewed the original Outer Limits in real time , when first broadcast and have since viewed the entire original  series three or more times. As an admirer of the series I even tracked down some of the directors and actors to exchange notes on this iconic show and be amazed at its retro look. In each new viewing I marveled at the intricate concept stories, wonderful visions of alien creatures, evil empires and protagonists willing to sacrifice it all to face their fears and then not remember that they did so. It provided quite an important learning on fate, determinism, and cosmic possibility in their rather dark fashion.

The movie doesn't take itself seriously, and if you follow its lead you're going to have a lot of fun (as long as you don't mind your murders served up really bloody, and your horror topped with extra cheese)!This film winks an eye at every horror fan, and then gives them the finger. It knows it sucks, and because of that, it's far and away the best of the "Child's Play" series. It plays up the "stoopid humor" angle so well, you find yourself doing more than just laughing AT it, but WITH it.

I did not know what to expect when I decided to watch this documentary . I knew it was about  animals and that it promised a never before seen look into their world. So I prepared myself for something spectacular. But when I finally started the film I was astonished. Not only did it exceed my expectations, it captivated me and made me feel an array of emotions from sadness, to joy and from awe to utter excitement. This documentary was a truly mesmerizing journey into a whole new universe filled with beauty, warmth and strength that I'd have never experienced if I didn't give this documentary a chance.

Chaplin enters the trenches of WWI in this spirited comedy that never belittles the horrors of war . The rain  soaks the trenches but it cannot dampen the men’s spirits as they resolve to remain full of life while they’re away from home. Trench warfare wasn’t without laughter and much of the humour derived from ‘trench stories’ shared between the brave individuals. Despite the gruesome destruction and endless fear, Chaplin delivers much of the humour during perilous episodes. Taking risk never comes naturally but Chaplin enticed danger with humour and sly intellect.

That's right. Ohwon (the painter and the main character) is an exceptional person. What strikes me most is the message this film might address to all of you people there. And the message is sad. It says that, it's very difficult to do anything that's amazing or maybe even genius without having to obey the governments, establishment and other VIPs of this world. And even if you try, you might not be able to bear it. It is about the battle of a single person with a system. With many systems.A great film of this wonderful Korean director.

Accepted is one of the best teenage comedies I have seen in a long time . It has an original  story with great comedic performances and I was laughing for almost the entire runtime. It has been praised for the smart way it balances thoughtfulness with laughs, the great cinematography and soundtrack, and most of all the ensemble of unforgettable characters. The messages on college pressures, personal responsibility, finding a path in life and following your dreams speak for themselves. Each character is dealing with these pressures, along with social acceptance.

probably the best horror movie in 5 years.. there's been lame remakes, attempts to make you scared (when all they make you do is walk out of the theater) and movies that just shouldn't have been made. but this one is worth it. the only reason i didn't give it a 10 is because Paris Hilton is in it (but her death scene makes up for it, believe me)....so here they are.. the SPOILERS of all the death scenes in the movie..1. my favorite death scene ever - Paris Hilton's!

Mark Blankfield (from the old late night TV show "Fridays")plays Dr. Daniel Jekyll, a mild-mannered surgeon who invents a powder that turns him into a drug-crazed party animal. This was not, of course, his intent, he had higher aspirations, but he goes with the flow. This is actually a fairly stupid movie, but it's also pretty fun. Of course, once the good doctor realizes what he's done, he's ashamed, but he's also not above doing it all again & running through Hollywood as a crazed sex machine with frizzed out hair & gold chains.

Due to its predictable, second-rate title, (the one it was distributed under in Italy, at least) I didn't expect much from this movie. Thought it'd be another cheap flick about a haunted house ("LA CASA MALEDETTA" means "The cursed house"). Well, I had to change my mind just after the very first brilliant scene! The constant presence of priests and the creepy atmospheres, reminded me a bit of The Exorcist and some of its decent Italian rip-offs, but this was going to be something completely different...

Well, I guess I was in the mood for a movie that really grabbed me from the beginning. This movie wasn't it. It plodded along at a pretty slow, deliberate pace for the first 40 minutes, but there wasn't really anything in it that I was terribly interested in--there's an intriguing and mysterious feud between Jean Reno's character and an old man, but more of the first 40 minutes is dominated by the wanderings of the main character, whom I didn't know much about and couldn't really relate to at the time.

I don't see what the problem is with SOME people and their NEED for intellectual humor. You need to get your head out of your up-tight ass if you don't find this movie hilarious! If this isn't your "cup of tea", so to speak, then look at it for what it truly is- a damn funny movie. Maybe they DID set out to make yet another drugs/T&A movie, but in this case, they've truly hit the spot. It's especially funny for the Ali G fans, because he delivers everything we've come to love and expect from him.

A film about the relationship between a man and leopard that 's very reminiscent of `` The English Patient ,  '' it follows a local Puma tracker named Loretta and her unexpected bond with a local

Loretta's involvement with the wildcat initially raises hostility and distrust from her family, especially her son Timmy. The further the film progresses, the closer Loretta grows to the leopard, all the while continuing to face criticism from her family, coworkers and the nearby village. After being threatened by poachers, Loretta is inspired to use her skill to safeguard and promote awareness of her beloved leopard.

Jeff Garlin's film is filled with heart and laughter. As in Curb Your Enthusiasm, his screen persona is hilarious; but in addition we get to see both warmth and a sense of emotional vulnerability that makes the story universal. While the film chronicles his character's dreams of love, performing success, and weight loss, it will appeal to anyone who dreams of a better life. The supporting cast brings the frustrations and joys of his life to the screen in funny and heartbreaking ways. The simple joys of food, friendship, and trying once again once life has disappointed us are all themes.

The success of SCREAM gave birth to a whole new horror flicks wave. I'm happy with that, as a big fan of horror, and I liked most of those new horror films. BOC is a one big pack of horror. Colorful, fast paced and original. I see this movie more like the opening of a new trilogy (much like Episode 1 and Aliens: Resurrection) since it comes up with a new twist. Instead of focusing on the little boy-killer doll relationship we have here a twisted movie about couples. We have the sweet young lovers in contrast with the killer crazy doll-sized lovers.

Just exactly HOW director John Madden come to settle with Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz playing the roles of an  uptight accountant and a loose vagabond, respectively? Madden was drawn to the creative blend of characters, from Cage as an emotionally closed-off accountant to Cruz as a daring drifter. Through multiple discussions and rounds of auditions, it was Madden’s steady direction and admiration for the actor’s interpretive take on their respective characters that sealed the deal. Their juxtaposed personality traits generated undeniable sparks and driven from the creative prospects alone.

In Tweety 's S.O.S , Sylvester goes from picking garbage cans to being a stowaway on a cruise ship that Tweety finds himself vacationing on with his new wealthy human friend, Amelia. When Sylvester attempts to overtake the cruise ship and send out a distress call, his mischievous and meddlesome deeds manage to ruin the on-board ship schedule for the vacationing duo. Fortunately for Tweety and Amelia, their in-transit adventures bring them unexpected fame and applause, with their hijacked ship receiving support and welcomes from passengers from other boats passing in their vicinity.

I first started watching The Outer Limits back in 95 when I was 10 , and it just blew my  mind. From then on, The Outer Limits and I had an unwavering connection. While I still watched it as an adult, there was just something unique and captivating about it during childhood. In this show, horror and mystery combined with intriguing and diverse plotlines in order to tell its viewers fascinating tales, encouraging further exploration of the unknown. It’s this knowledge that I’ve carried over into my own work as a scientist today and will no doubt continue to nurture until the day I depart this universe.

Dr. Paul Flanner ( Richard Gere ) , a successful surgeon , has his wife leave him , his son  rebel , and an agonizing life -threatening tumor discover . Though his life outside of the hospital has been tumultuous, Dr. Paul manages to take care of his patients without sacrificing the ethical code he swears to live by. Though weary, he pursues alternative treatments for his own ailment, using his scientific training as a basis for evaluation of available treatments. As time goes on, he learns more about alternative remedies and remains unshakable in his belief that every life is sacred and worthy of his care and commitment to excellence.

`` Live Together , Die Alone '' is divided into three main story lines , and each one of them  has their own particular reasons for attempting to flee the island and attempt to get away. The three main characters strive to do their best to stay alive, exploring the mystery of the island, trying to use the Dharma Initiative technology to try to save the survivors, and come to terms with the force of fate. At the same time they fight to live, because ultimately there can be only one who makes it off the island, thus the adage: Live Together, Die Alone.

By convincing the Prime Minister to back the totally unsuitable Ali G as a candidate for Staines in the local  by-election. Ali G was given a second chance by the Prime Minister, though much was made of the very audacious decision that was taken by the PM in taking a chance on the young, brazen Ali G. Nevertheless, as time passed, it soon became evident that the new candidate, hailing from Staines had a grip on his community and held great appeal amongst those who felt that they could no longer recognize politics as a vital way of social change.

Documentaries in which sons and daughters seek to understand a parent and , by the process , their own lives  , these kinds of projects touch my heart. Films in which the next generation steps up to ask the questions and wants to understand the entire context and get an accurate understanding, drive home an important truth. What we did as parents, impacted our children. Whether that be postive or negative, a pattern was created in each home and this of this story is vitally important. Unspoken questions from the adult children still live today, questions the prior generations had to hope they passed on the next ones.

After seeing The Aristocats : Special Edition in a two pack with The Fox in the Hound , I decided  to buy it

After doing some research I was surprised to find out how well received the movie was. Even though it has been out of the spotlight for some time, many critics continue to acclaim it for its depth, lovable characters, and entertaining scenes. While rewatching the movie, I can still feel that nostalgia that grabbed me at first. There's so much joy and comfort from being reunited with O'Malley, Thomas, Berlioz, Toulouse and of course Marie!

This is a good film, no doubt, but with some odd aspects. Without spoiling anything it takes place in 3 places only- a Sicilian farm, the boat,and Ellis Island New York. All shots are close up so we never see a broad sweep of anything. I wonder if this was to save money? No street scenes anywhere, and we don't even see the boat except in close ups. And the music...what on earth was going on with playing Nina Simone songs, decades before they were out?

I saw this film at a small screening. Even though it had a low budget, the creative direction and intelligence of the cast helped make this a small gem of a movie. It's April 8, 1994, each of the characters are in their "mid 20's" and pursuing some kind of artistic ambition (acting, music, film, writing) when they learn of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain's suicide. They quickly get inspiration to travel from San Francisco to Seattle and attend the Cobain vigil. It's here where the film really picks up and serves up a series of funny and emotional scenes.

1969 was the year . New York City was the place . Putney Swoope was the second Robert Downey film 

to gain widespread notice in that year, a black comedy set among NYC's bohemians of the late 60s. Starring his good friend John Hatlan and Christopher Plummer as Swoope, the film developed a cult following over time for its improvisational feel. Despite minimal financial success, Putney Swoope had enormous influence in its striking use of free-form camera angles and Beat Poetry aesthetics. This gave Downey and the rest of the crew the much needed boost that set the pace for the remainder of his career.

A labor of love. Each frame is picture perfect and grabs you. Then the sheer emotion and story-telling take you through a dream that stays with you long after the movie. The director gets your heart and leads it through 100 minutes of visual poetry. You are a part of the emotional ride of the characters. I have seen this movie at 2 festivals and it got with standing ovations at every showing. The remarkable story-telling transcends nationality and language and I felt I was a part of the drama unfolding before me. The casting is as perfect as one can get.

Better than it has any right to be, this movie died a quick and painful death at the American box office. At times sophomoric, at others, bitingly satirical and witty, Jekyll and Hyde is mostly just a near perfect reflection of the times, laden with drug and sexual humor, reminding one at one time or another of everything from the Woody Allen of "Everything You Always Wanted To know About Sex" to the Mel Brooks of "The Producers", Saturday Night Live to Monty Python, Carlin to Cheech and Chong.

The Simpsons of course started off with Christmas special "Simpson's Roasting On An Open Fire" which had basic drawings and not laugh out loud jokes, but this episode has probably the first laugh out loud joke in it and from here the show just gets better and better. This episode centers around Bart who in this episode swaps on a test from Martin and gets into a school for the highly gifted, this leading to Bart mending his friendship with his Dad and losing all of his mates. The Episode is very humorous and shows what was to become the greatest show ever to come out.

Frank Langella steals my heart in everything he has ever been in ! I love watching him ! ! i 

Every performance of his is entrancing. His natural charm, wit, and captivating gaze pull you in, leaving you wanting more. And so many roles - be it comedic or dark - that demonstrate an emotional and physical intensity and an attention to detail I truly admire. What’s especially wonderful is seeing how well the roles that incorporate physical presence of an older Langella carries. It shows a generosity and an endearment with characters he plays even at such a high age.

It amazes me that production companies will sue because of reproductions they will not supply. I've been looking for this movie on DVD for a while and VHS for years. One can get all sorts of movies on line...old movies, new movies... but it all targets a particular group. This movie is very nostalgic for many. I'm not sure why I can't get a copy. Maybe if enough people will write in, the copyright holder will get a clue. It's about time for this to happen. Yes, it's date, but so is The Wizard of OZ.

I have to offset all the terrible comments . I love this movie . I own the movie and the  soundtrack and watch it as often as I can . I think it's wonderful. I have great respect for everyone who put time and energy into creating it. I appreciate the special effects and am always in awe at how beautiful they look in a completely believable and fantastical setting. I enjoy listening to the characters’ unique and talented voices and music which all tie in together to make it one complete, remarkable piece of art.

This Oscar-winning short film (40 minutes), based on a short story by William Faulkner, takes us back to small-town Tennessee in December 1941. Two brothers, one about 18 and one about 8 are looking for birds eggs (obviously a huge collectors item for boys in the South around this time). Well, the Japanese bomb Pearl Harbor and the older brother, Pete, decides to enlist. He gives his prize egg to his little brother, Willie and heads off wishing to show more emotion and tenderness to his little acolyte.

I was about 14 years old as I saw the musical version of Lost Horizon . I loved the film  from the moment the curtains rose. The musical score and the enchanting scenes drew me in. As I got absorbed in the musical, the performance came to an end. Even though the actors only had a short time to capture me with their magical tale, it remained etched in my memory. From then on I became a dedicated theatre enthusiast. Each performance was magical, be it a farcical play or a light opera.

Pity the Monkees. People always accused them of being manufactured (which they were) or being nothing more than a American knock-off of the Beatles (Again, which they were) but to the kids of the time they were real, they were important, they were legitimate. Discussions about who were better The Monkees or The Beatles were common on school yards but the critics, well they never quite bought into it. Despite recording some very catchy, classic pop tunes, the Monkess did not receive much respect for their albums.

This has got to be one of the most magnificent things I 've ever seen on film . I do  believe it deserves recognition and celebration, just like any other grand masterpiece in the realm of art and literature

I believe it is an incredible achievement and many talented people had put in an effort to create this magic. To this day, I still remain spellbound when watching the scene, like when I first watched it all those years ago. Even today I am simply mesmerised, speechless. This gem, which lies hidden amidst countless of countless other memorable works, definitely deserves more credit and love.

Duchess is a pretty white cat who lives with her three kittens in her wealthy owner 's mansion in Paris 

The duchess's life was the life of luxury; she could roam the gardens and plazas, admire the gorgeous views of the Eiffel Tower, bask in the sun in her lavish personal residence. Her kittens were pampered too, being given the very best in gourmet cuisine, treated to spa treatments and never a moment too long without a squeak of excitement to enjoy each day. From belly rubs and belly tickles, play times with soft furry toys, curling up in deep comfort on a fluffy blanket for a siesta.

An old man is riding his bike down a village road when a car comes out of nowhere , strikes  him. The old man fell down to the ground after being hit by the car, desperately trying to make sense of what happened. He groaned in pain and screamed in despair at the fact that he was struck while merely passing through. His heart felt shattered as he looked at the broken pieces of his beloved bicycle around him and he realized that life could be so cruel, one never knew when it would be taken away without prior notice.

This is a funny movie. The Bob & Eddie Show feel of it could lead to a sequel but I doubt it will make enough money. Deniro proves he can be a great Straight man again with some hilarious and spontaneous moments. Eddie was fun to watch working with people instead of CGI animals and rodents. Rene Russo- well she's just fun to watch anyway and she's played her part excellent.Some wild and unusual stunts, especially the garbage truck scene. This was worth seeing in the theater. We needed a good laugh and got many from the movie and the great out-takes at the end.

Chaplin is a doughboy in his final film of 1918 , a doughboy who can not seem to get the  respect that he desires and yearns. He keeps joining the military thinking that it will grant him the respect he desires, yet he seems to only receive condescension in the battlefields, overlooked and downplayed at every turn. Eventually, he grows exasperated and soon stumbles into his own chase for validation. Taking matters into his own hands, Chaplin puts forth relentless effort and eventual achieves recognition for his fighting spirit and fearlessness, thus re-writing his story.

As an English teacher, I appreciate films that do more than tell a story. Good films, like good literature, cause one to think, reflect and predict. This film made me do all three. Mr. Jansen takes risks and uses foreshadowing, symbolism and interesting turning points for many of his characters. I also likes the fact that despite the choices the characters make in the film, their choices do not seem as adolescent or felonious as other films I have seen. The acting is pretty good and the actors seem to share a good chemistry with each other.

Great movie . Post-apocalyptic films kick ass . This one is no exception . Kept up the pace and interest  the whole way through

The cinematography was breathtaking and all of the actors gave a top notch performance. Every scene provided details and colour that highlighted each character’s persona. The storytelling style managed to link and transport us through each character’s lives and ultimately create a great bond between us and them. I couldn't take my eyes off the screen as every turn gave me excitement, tragedy, hope and despair -all integral parts to a great post-apocalyptic story.

I thought Besson's film managed to do without words what few films have been able to do with them; Capture true human emotions. The main character's struggles, triumphs, set backs, hopes and desires are all so honestly shown that you wonder if he is acting at all. The film has a low budget and is obviously made without the glitz and glamour afforded to most Hollywood productions but that minimalism is what allows this film to transcend the stereotypical Sci-Fi labeling and become a true drama. However calling this film solely a drama would take away from the fantastic post-apocalyptic plot.

Very touching film, a great surprise to come up from Brazil, a country that usually exports features about social themes, violence, sex... Magical realism is a very hard task, and I believe João Falcão has made it wonderfully. It seems that he really didn't intend to make a realistic film, far from that. Although many people think the film was adapted from the play, he said in his interviews that he actually based the film on the book. Another mistake is to think that Falcão has been influenced by the series "Hoje é Dia De Maria".

Can the intensity of a husband's love for his wife lead him to cover up a crime,despite betrayal on many levels? Tom Wilkinson is no brutal Othello, in the setting of modern day England. So, gradually a web of deceit begins to be woven. And, we witness cycles of jealousy and drunkenness and guilt and fornication. And so the web of "separate lies" begins to fail and then hold together again. And life (and death) goes on, despite the bright flame of the husband's love and the deep despair and guilt woven into so many lives.

This is probably the second best of the Death Wish movies . Death Wish 5 is the best one.Death Wish  5 stands out because it is, perhaps, the most imaginative of the lot and had an original plot - far from the monotony of simply observing vigilantism. One of the plot points also particularly resonated with viewers as the underlying moral, justice being taken into the hands of someone capable and judicious is of utmost importance for the maintenance of peace and integrity. Paul Kersey himself featured much more prominently, since it followed the angle of professional enemy clearing - going deep down into their seedy affairs, culminating in the ending scene.

Too bad somebody did not have the smarts to release this movie to theaters. I had never heard of it when it appeared on cable. After the first shock of realizing this is not like any other movie you have seen since Bringing Up Baby you have to let it sweep you along and run with it. Not until it's over do you realize it covers issues that are not only subtle but significant. Alienation, denial, wish-fulfillment, for a start. Cathy Bates owns this movie, she's never been better.

This was a riveting film, one that really drew me in. I'm a big fan of William H. Macy, and he puts in a wonderful performance. His great likeability, coupled with the way his character breaks the fourth wall, really gave me a sense of complicity in his actions. I found myself waiting tensely for the whole house of cards to come collapsing down around him (and by extension myself, as his confidante and silent witness). It took several minutes for me to relax once the film had ended, I was so wrapped up in it.

Remember that this came out before Gulf War I, which gave us Werner Herzog's "Lessons of Darkness".Le Dernier Combat is not "Sci Fi". It's more like Judgment. I've watched it at least a dozen times. It really is a fitting companion to Herzog's "Lessons of Darkness": "And in that time, men will seek death, but they will not find it, for death will flee from them. "That someday, alas, may be today, in Iraq.

This interesting film noir features three very good performances: Sanders, Patrick, and Blackmer. The scenes between Sanders and Patrick are particularly outstanding. Demming, as the detective, is unfortunately not nearly as good. He lacks the intelligence, strength, and cynical world view of a Bogart. Had Humphrey played this part, we could have had a classic.Pace, location (a library), and atmosphere are all good. But there are a few plot holes. Sanders strongly fears Blackmer and the ruthless organization (Nazis) he represents. Yet after mistakenly killing Blackmer, Sanders seems to experience no anxiety or remorse.

Frank Langella steals my heart in everything he has ever been in! I love watching him!! i was 10 yrs old (1979) when i seen him for the first time.i eagerly await each and everything he'll be acting in. hopefully one day i can see him in person. he's very hypnotic and mysterious and that voice is commanding and strong! he is very attractive, even now at 65 he is absolutely stunning!!!! In my opinion he is the greatest actor iv'e ever seen!
